We were out and about alot of the time, however even when we were at the hotel I didnt really mind it being crowded. There were a lot of families there with kids though so I probably wouldnt recomend it for a romantic gettaway. I would definately stay at this hotel again, but I would probably only stay in the grand vacations towers as they are much nicer than the other normal hilton towers (I stayed i both).

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We have stayed at the HHV many times and we have wonderful memories here. We did purchase a time share at the Lagoon tower several years ago and we returned again this year. I did enjoy our stay as usual. The familiar setting always brings back memories and we always look forward to the new memories. Our room faced the "great lawn" and we benefited from watching wonderful free entertainment from several large meeting groups that were having functions on the great lawn. We had an incredible view of a firework display one evening from our balcony. I love the fact that there is so much to do within the village and it is away from the hustle and bustle of Waikiki. But it is walking distance to the main street in Waikiki so love the location. But I was disappointed in a few things. Our kids enjoyed the Paradise Pool and they enjoyed the water slides. But from my perspective it was much too crowded at the pool. To make matters worse, the beach chairs were packed so closely together that you can barely walk through the rows. My biggest complaint is they closed the bar restaurant at the Paradise pool. There is no food service! I still love the HHV but it is starting to lose its appeal to a certain degree. I just hope they stop building more towers - it is getting too crowded!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: My family stayed at Lagoon Tower, and went to swimming pool with my kids on 16th July 2012. As usual, I left swimming pool which contained my daugher's I-phone and glasses, some cashes on the beach chair besides pool. After playing with my kids, I found out the bag was stolen and reported to security there. while preparing reports to security and police, I found out theft cases happened quite offten. However, HGVC didn't take any action to prevent theft i.e. they didn't place any warning sign about theft, they didnt' allocate more security to watch customer's belongings, they didn't install CC camera to watch and to give warning to potential thief. How can I enjoy with my family at those area without worrying theft?Worse than all, resort manager and staffs didn't apologize for what happened and took it granted. I was dumbfounded at their reaction and thought they discriminate me because I am from Korea. Anyway, I decided to let all the people know to prevent the people from experiencing what happened to my family.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: I was prepared to love this hotel, but I didn’t like it much for reasons I’ll explain below. Despite my reaction, I can’t point to many things that were done wrong, so I decided to be generous in my rating (I wish I could have given it 3 1/2 stars). Just beware that, if you think like I do, you may not like it much, either. To put this review in perspective: this was our third visit to Honolulu (for me and my spouse) and our 10th visit to Hawaii. We wanted a scenic location convenient to major attractions such as Pearl Harbor and ‘Iolani Palace. We paid $1700 for 7 nights; this review would be much harsher in tone if we had paid the rack rate of $599/night.Prior to our arrival at the Lagoon tower, we were contacted by our own “personal concierge,” who offered to make advance reservations for us. She set up an appointment for us to talk to her our first morning. This was a nice touch. We checked in at the Grand Waikikian/Lagoon Tower lobby, were greeted warmly, and quickly received our room keys and towel cards. Other reviewers are unhappy with the towel card system: you exchange a card for a towel, and if you don’t return the card upon check out you are charged for the towel. This system doesn’t bother me. They’ve got to encourage folks to avoid leaving towels on the beach; this seems to be as good a system as any and one I’ve seen in use at other resorts.We found our 11th floor, west-facing suite to be very spacious and well equipped. We had two bedrooms, two bathrooms, and a fully-applianced kitchen complete with pans, tableware, toaster, etc. There was a large dining room table, living room with flat-screen TV and DVD player, and a small balcony with table and chairs. The furnishings did not look dated to me, although the kitchen appliances and cabinets were a bit worn. We stocked our kitchen with groceries from Foodland at Ala Moana Shopping Center, a 15-minute walk (we returned via a trolley).You’re probably wondering: what’s the problem? Well, for one, the overwhelming impression upon walking into the suite was of…the Ilikai Hotel next door. Two of the Ilikai’s wings, with their approximately 500 balconies, looked right into our balcony and windows. From inside of our “ocean view” room, only if I sat on the right side of the sofa and looked along a narrow strip in between our building and the Ilikai, could I see the yacht harbor and the ocean beyond. So I thought, hey, I’ll ignore the Ilikai and sit on the balcony for a better view. Despite being on the 11th floor, the shrieks of happy children playing in the Paradise Pool immediately below carried up the concrete and glass canyon formed by the two towers so that the sounds of their mirth, combined with the roar of industrial-sized air conditioning units, made sitting on the balcony an almost deafening experience.OK, so I wasn’t at Waikiki just to sit on my balcony; maybe I should join those kids having a great time at the Paradise Pool. This beautiful pool, open only to guests of the Lagoon and Grand Waikikian towers, has several water slides, different levels, and a spa tub that limits its capacity to 9 bathers at a time. We looped through the pool deck multiple times before we saw a single chair being vacated. While my spouse went on the slides, I waited by the spa tub until there were only 8 people inside. (Just as I entered, two more people piled in; so much for trying to follow the rules.) Both the spa and pool were packed with people. And no wonder: counting the hotel and timeshare portions of this resort, there are 3627 rooms and suites with an average daily occupancy of something like 6000 people. For all of these people, the resort advertises five pools, except that one of them (the Tapa pool) was closed for renovation when I visited and I think this count includes the sea-water lagoon, which is more ocean than pool. So it’s unsurprising that the pools should be crowded every day, all the time.In fact, crowds are the norm at the Hilton Hawaiian Village (HHV). The shopping village between the Grand Waikikian and the main lobby was filled with wall-to-wall people whenever we walked through. The main lobby was always hectic. As we walked past any restaurant after 6 p.m., we noted crowds of people waiting. We waited for one of the three elevators in the Lagoon tower every time we came and went. (This situation was worsened by the housekeepers, who attempted to move their carts by way of these same three guest elevators. Just imagine people moving groceries, strollers, inflated pool beds, and surfboards on top of the normal luggage loads and then think about adding housekeeping carts to the mix.) The check-out line at 10:00 a.m. on Saturday morning was at least 60 people deep.So the crowdedness is my main complaint about the hotel, with too few facilities (elevators, restaurants, shops, breathing space) for the number of accommodations. I’m not sure how much to blame the Hilton for this situation and how much to chalk this up to the fact that Waikiki is a crowded place. There are advantages to being at a huge hotel, however: the world comes to you. We used the Hertz desk in the Tapa Tower twice to rent a car for the day during our week-long stay. Why twice for one day, rather than once for two days? While it was a bit of a pain to go through the rental process multiple times, doing so meant that we did not have to pay for very expensive overnight parking. And when we did not have a car, we rode the Pink Line Trolley for $2 each way, took taxis downtown (approximately $15), and even used the city bus ($2.50). Plus, the Polynesian Cultural Center has coach pickups from the HHV to their park on the northeastern shore, and every tour bus on Oahu, seemingly, can arrange a pickup at the HHV.I did have some very good moments at the HHV. We arrived early enough to snag an outdoor table at Tropics Grill and enjoy appetizers and drinks while listening to live music and watching the dinner cruise ships sail back and forth just offshore. I liked seeing four penguins in a small pond along with many turtles in the middle of beautiful grounds. A five-minute fireworks program at 7:50 on Friday night was impressive, and easily viewed from the shores of the Lagoon.So would I stay at the HHV again? It’s doubtful, and certainly not during a $760M construction project that is planned to begin in 2013. According to Derek Paiva’s 2 April 2010 article in Hawaii.com magazine, the HHV will add two new vacation timeshare towers to its existing 7 hotel and timeshare towers, adding 550 more vacation condos and another 1000+ people on site per day--all without expanding its land area. If you are looking for a serene oceanfront experience, the HHV is not for you.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: I have not stayed at other timeshares so I have no frame of reference, but have always enjoyed my time here (stayed at least 2 times for family holidays since my mom bought a timeshare with HGVC - she paid too much IMO but she has no complaints). The beach is uncrowded but the sand is not soft. Parking and food are expensive, but cheaper eats are walkable. Ala Moana mall and the rest of Waikiki are walkable in under 20 min. The rooms are very nice and clean, and the beds are quite comfy. The soundproofing is fairly good unless there is a concert/wedding going on at the ground level. Laundry and kitchen areas are good and helpful. The pool is very nice but many kids splashing and yelling makes relaxation hard. Sometime it's hard to get a chaise lounge in the shade. The gym is quite good for a hotel. The property is very pretty with some shopping and animal exhibits around. The luau the Hilton provides is OK but pricey (maybe try it once but not worth seeing again).

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: They do keep the grounds nice. But there are too many towers and too many guests for the beach and pool areas to handle. It is more a shopping destination than a beach destination. Not a bad stop off point to shop and see pearl Harbour before heading to a more serene island.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We stayed in the Kalia Tower & were pretty happy with the one bedroom. The kitchen is nice with granite counters & white cupboards for a clean look. Impressively stocked with utensils, rice cooker, blender, toaster, pots pans etc. Washer/Dryer are not in the unit but shared per floor. We used a cab & stocked up on groceries saving a lot on meals. Fantastic view of the beach although set back a ways and enjoyed the balcony, it was clean & quiet..We were disappointed with all 3 pools.... at our hotel the pool was small and in shade much of the day. They had slides at another pool but they were crammed together in a small area and the kids had to wait in line to use them. Very little deck space and it was crammed with chairs. The last pool was larger and close to the beach but also crammed with chairs and we had to wait / watch to get chairs at either of these pools. Our daughter who is 11 lost interest quickly with all 3 & this was especially disappointing since we chose this place thinking she would have fun and meet kids. We did shop in some of the shops and although some were pretty expensive there were still deals. We also appreciated the complimentary DVD's/ movies they provided - more family selections would have been nice. I will end with that I felt the service was impersonal....check in was okay but honestly no warmth from our agent - a bit snobby? Also when my daughter used the phone to call my cell 3 times (after being told not to) we were charged a total of $25....I sincerely doubt we talked the 10 minutes each time it showed and the check out agent was not sympathetic in the least. I did not feel like battling over it but it left me with a bad taste.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Wow, what a place. The Hilton Hawaiian Village is a fantastic place to stay. It's huge. There are many pools, shops and places to eat. There are pengiuns, flamingos, fireworks and awsome gardens. Best of all its right on the beach. We stayed for a week in July 2012 in a 2 bedroom/2 bath apartment on the 21st floor of the Lagoon Tower. The view was magic. The apartment itself was very nicely appointed and (mostly) well maintained. It had everything you needed. The kitchen was a full kitchen with a large fridge. The bathrooms were quite good (a bit outdated - shower head a bit problematic but honestly not a problem). The main bedroom was huge, with king bed, ensuite and awsome views. The second bedroom had only two single beds (which we were disappointed about as we expected double beds). The lounge was also large and had a large sofa bed. All bedrooms had flat screen TV's as did the lounge with PS3. The balcony (Lanai) was large with table an chairs and awsome view towards Diamond Head and of Village gardens and Lagoon. We also got to see the nightly Luau from there which was a nice unexpected surprise. There is no laundry in the apartment but one on every floor with free washing machines and dryers - which we found to be a real bonus. I rented it from Chris Morelli online and was a bit apprenhensive about paying a full six months in advance, but it all work out really well. The check-in process was not a problem at all . We arrived at 9:30 a.m. and were in our room by 1 p.m. The place if full of families - this is really a family oriented resort - and Japanese! Its not very far from Waikiki - about a 20 minute walk and really close to the Ala Moana Shopping centre - you can walk there is about 5 minutes. Overall this place was really fantastic, we enjoyed every minute there and will return as soon as we can affort it. I would highly recommend this resort to families.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: The property is advertised as beach front but in reality it's a city block from the beach. The property itself is beach front but there are many buildings sharing the beach front property and other ameneties with the HGVC building with a far walk to everything. There is no pool for the building either, it's shared with another building and there is no chance of getting a chair, even far away from pool side. No chairs what so ever available. The resort itself is very nice, the beach is nice but there are too many rooms sharing the number of pools and restaurants. You cannot get into any restaurant without a reservation, long lines on beach to pay for a beach chair ($60 day for two chairs and umbrella!). Expect to wait at least 15-20 minutes for everything. It's not a relaxing resort by any stretch. The "mountain view" I was promised was city street view. The room itself was nice, but we had plumbing noise that was very loud and continued through the stay. There was also a very fowl smell coming from the plumbing. Management (Steve S) did contact us but there was no solution to the problems we had. It was a plumbing issue that had been ongoing for some time and they couldn't get the contractor to fix. It was horrible being woke up in the middle of the night to these very loud noises. I would not return to HHV again. Overall though the island was beautiful and we enjoyed kayaking, snorkeling, and hiking.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: My family of 5 accepted the invitation from the telemarketer to check out the HGVC for several days. We picked July 4th week. Wow - I have never seen so many people packed so tightly together in a pool, on a beac... , anywhere we turned, actually. The 2-room suite was our refuge from the crowds - clean quiet and reasonably well-appointed. The view was of lots of tall buildings along Ala Moana. Don't count on fast valet service - management has one valet handling everyone's cars while multiple salespeople stand around watching.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We own a 2 bedroom Ocean View in the Lagoon Tower and we use to be Honolulu residents who now live in California. We are very familiar with the hotels in Waikiki and know that this place is as close as you can get to being in your own 'place' right on the beach in one of the worlds prime locations. Remember folks most people are here in Hawaii staying in a 2 bed hotel rooms. The Lagoon Tower accommodations allow you a lot of space w/ your own lanai and the place is clean. You are also moments away from the beaches too. And yest the Hilton Hawaiian Village can get very crowded but if you do your homework, Oahu is full of great beaches & other places to spend your time. My husband and I like the fact that at night just strolling around the property, there are many spots that are very quite & private with little or no people around, heck you can even enjoy the lagoon all to yourself by moonlight! If you are on the property on a Friday night, head over to the Tapa Bar and check out singer Jerry Santos and the group Olomana. They are authentic local style Hawaiian entertainers and are a mainstay favorite with the local Hawaiian scene. Do try a luau and even locals like visiting 'Germaine's Luau when they play tourist. Sam's Club & Walmart is available for food supplies & is near the Ala Moana shopping center and offer a better pricing overall than the ABC stores located throughout Waikiki.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Our stay was from June 16-22 in a one bedroom suite in the Lagoon Tower. We are vacation club owners so our room was booked through the vacation club using our yearly points. I called the resort one week before leaving to request a high floor with a view facing diamond head and the ocean. Both requests were met and we were extremely pleased. We had no problems at all with check in. Everything was perfect.I gave the resort 4 stars instead of 5 only because a few things that were disappointing about the room. My daughter slept on the sofa bed and it was horrible. She had to layer blankets to get comfortable. The bathroom was a nice size but the lighting was terrible. You literally could not see to do anything in the mirror. The master bed was very nice though as were the large tv's. My daughter wanted to take the one in the living room home. We also had a problem with the noise from the Tapa bar every night. They had live music which I am all for but it was extremely loud in our room. I don't know if it was the way the wind blows through the resort and that our room was on the 20th floor but it was like the music was right next door. We never got to sleep until after 11:00 when the entertainment was over. I would think that would really be a problem for parents with small children. I would like to say that housekeeping was wonderful! Both times we called for something they were there within 10 minutes. One time they brought us a whole bag of extra shampoo etc. Can't say enough good things about housekeeping. Also, our room and floor were very quiet. Never heard another person or a door slam like in most hotels. Slept like a baby!!Other than those few problems, we love, love this resort. We have looked at other hotels on the island and just can't find one that is as beautiful with as nice of a beach and as much to offer. This is our 4th trip to this HIlton so we were used to the layout and large crowds but I really don't have the same opinion as some on the problems with too many people. We never had a problem getting a chair by the pool, walked down the beachwalk almost every day with no congestion, ate at Topics outside with no wait and went to the lagoon one day with plenty of empty space. We will definitely stay here again maybe try the newly remodeled Rainbow Tower. We love Hawaii and were very sad to leave!!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Aloha! We stayed in the Lagoon Tower in a 1 bedroom suite. Although this is one of the older buildings on the property, the room was nicely furnished and had a great bathroom, obviously recently refurbished. Full kitchen with nice new appliances, stop and buy some drinks and snacks on the way from the airport and use the full size fridge. New HDTV with a Sony PS3 where you can watch Blu Ray movies for free from the machines in the lobby. Our room faced Northwest toward the Ilikai hotel and marina, so we did have a pretty nice view, but not of the beach. Still it was quite nice to sit on the lanai with a glass of wine in the late afternoons.The grounds are clean and well manicured, but VERY crowded. The pool with the water slides by our tower was filled with kids so we used the one by the Ali'i tower which is close to the beach. Difficult to get lounge chairs by the pool unless you get out there at like 7:30AM. You've probably read about the towel cards in other reviews, but we really didn't mind that much although it is annoying to have to wait in line to return towels when you are wet and trying to get upstairs to shower for dinner! The walkway across the beachfront reminded me of a midtown sidewalk during lunch hour...wall to wall people. This place is not designed for moments of quiet luxury. We had a couple of meals at the Tropics Bar & Grill, also in Ali'i Tower. Seems to be a 30 minute wait for an outside table anytime you go. The pizza (Hawaiian, of course) was really good, actually better than California Pizza Kitchen's version, and about the same price. Try one! Service is non existent though, apart from taking the order and bringing the food, we didn't see our server either time we ate there. But you are on the beach with a great vibe and live music! The other food highlight was Lappert's ice cream parlor, where I got the Macadamia Caramel and my wife got the Kona Coffee ice cream. They make the waffle cones right in front of you and it was one of the best desserts ever;)EMERGENCY ALERT:::DO NOT GO TO THE LUAU!!! Well, at least not to eat. The entertainment is superb, great dancers! But I've had better food on airplanes:( Maybe the fact that this event is not on the beach (Where a luau is supposed to be) but on the roof of the parking garage should have been a tip off. It is a buffet so you have to stand and wait on line to get the substandard offering. It reminded me of cafeteria food in junior high school, especially the rock hard and obviously not-fresh (dare I say "Stinks like the dumpster at the fishing pier"?) 'Mahi Mahi'. Inedible. The poi tasted like Elmer's glue. The hand carved beef was tough and flavorless. Only the Hawaiian chicken and pulled pork was remotely good. They should be ASHAMED of themselves for serving this slop much less calling it a Luau. But again, the dancers and band were really great, so go if you want to see a great hula show, just eat first!Nice little shopping area in the middle of the 'village'. Beni Hana on premises. Starbucks in Kalia lobby. All in all, it was a good time if you are looking for a good spot for a family vacation.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: I stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village (not GVC) 10 years ago on my first trip to Hawaii and it was a great experience. I still remember how warm and friendly the person checking us in was. She thought we were visiting from one of the other islands, but when we told her it was our first visit she upgraded us to an ocean view room. Since then I've became a loyal Hilton customer and even achieved Diamond status. I've been back to Honolulu a several times and even considered the HHV for my wedding. Last year I booked an ocean view room for 7 nights with points at the HHV and they tried to give me a 3rd floor room over the pool - I would have had to stand on my tiptoes to see the ocean. The front desk person felt that she was already doing me a favor by "upgrading" me to this "ocean view" room. When I told her I was already booked in an ocean view room she demanded that I show her my confirmation. Never in my hundreds of stays at Hiltons worldwide had I been asked to show a confirmation, and somehow here I found myself, on vacation, with my little toddler, struggling with the front desk, playing musical rooms in paradise. Well after that, I told myself that I wouldn't come back and decided that my loyalty to Hilton was over. Well fast forward a year and I found myself being offered 7 nights in a two bedroom at the GVC for $1700. I'm not going to say I totally reget taking it, because I don't. But it sure did solidify my feelings about the HHV and Hilton. We arrived at 2:30 and our room wasn't ready. What? Really? It's not like I tried to check in at 10AM or something, it is 2:30PM, I just got off a very long flight. My 2 year old is sleepy and my pregnant wife is hungry. They said that checkin is at 4PM and will call us when the room is ready. No choice but to go wait it out at the diner across the street, luckily we've been here before and know there is nothing worth eating on property. 4PM comes and still no call. Everyone is tired so we decide to wait a little longer before trying to check in. We check in (no call as promised) at 4:30 and of course it doesn't get any better. Our promised ocean view room is a view of the condo hotel next door. To obtain your sliver of an ocean view you must stand all the way on the right side of the room by the sliding glass door or be outside on the right hand side of the balcony. Did I mention I'm here on a timeshare promotion as a potential buyer? Well, at least it was an easy decision. The room itself was dated. the bath tub was one of the smallest tubs I've every showered in. The handle to turn on the water kept falling off. The mattresses were horrible, I thought I caught the flu the first night because I woke up so sore. The entire property needs to be renovated. To be fair the property has some good things going for it. The lagoon is great if you have little kids or for those who want to do water sports with pond calm conditions. The beach as tiny waves, perfect for little kids. A good stretch of it starting from the jetty is very rocky underwater, it gets better as you go towards Waikiki, but never rock free. One of the most annoying things about this property is the pool towel card system. You need to a card to get a towel (one card per towel), once you return your towel you get a card back. How annoying is that? I had two towels stolen while I was swimming and when I reported and tried to get new towels they said I had to go to the front desk!!! Are you kidding me? Like the title says this will be the last.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: When we arrived at the Hilton Hawaiian village we got checked into our rooms and had 2 king sized beds.There was a TV in our room and had a standard balcony which had a amazing view of Waikiki beach.The bathroom had a toilet,2sinks,bath and a shower.The staff were lovely,we were greeted every morning by them.There are also shops in the village which had places to eat.The hotel had 2pools and a lagoon which you had to walk 3minutes to get to.The hotel was very clean and would recommend it to anyone that was going to stay there.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: we stayed there for 10 days,in feb2012,in a condo, the condo was clean,the view was suppose to be ocean view,well if you looked between the buildings at a certain angle,the beach was not nice at all,you absolutly need water shoes,sitting on the beach was painfull, since there is no sand just broken shells,the worst was the noise level, wow, it was like being in new york at rush hour,with a beach,its o.k. if your there for work, no so good for vacation

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: The resort is beautiful!!!!!!!! Amenities are outstanding. I am an owner and this is the best property I have been to yet. It is a city within itself. If I weren't in Hawaii, I wouldn't need to leave for anything. There are numerous clothing shops, eateries, coffee shops and ABC store (the one on the property has a larger alcohol selection - for lushes like me), but you will PAY. The beach and lagoon are private. The lagoon is nice for families with smaller kids (so they don't wash out to sea), but the recreation items are contracted and therefore pricey (hourly rentals for paddle boats - $40, surf boards - $40, umbrellas - $30, and lounge chairs - $15).

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We enjoyed 4 nights in a 2 bedroom unit in the Lagoon tower. It was a great location for my conference at the Convention Center. Also, great to be on the beach at the end of Waikiki. We walked throughout Waikiki and had a great time. We are owners at Flamingo in Las Vegas and have experienced many of the Clubs throughout the system. We felt the Lagoon tower unit we had needed some refurbishing--just wasn't up to what we expect from HGVC clubs.There was quite a bit of noise from the Luau that occured twice while we were there and the "beach tractor" around the lagoon every morning staring at 7am was a bit annoying. However, overall we felt the service was great and the location can't be beat. We would stay there again.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Truly, this property is so over built with towers containing THOUSANDS of tourists, it cheapens this experience to no end. Every pool is PACKED. the hot tubs are absolutely filthy and crowded. You get "towel cards" when you check in, for a limited number of towels that if you leave anywhere you will be charged. There was a 1 HOUR WAIT to have our luggage brought to our room. I highly recommend that if you seek a condo resort to go to Marriott Ko o Lina. For waikiki, stay down by the surfrider. This is the worst.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: The help here is absolutely the worst i've ever encountered anywhere in the world! The restaurants here suck!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We are Hilton Grand Vacations Club members and stayed here in October. It was absolutely amazing. The rooms are pristine and spacious. We stayed in a 2 bedroom suite with 4 adults and a child. Had two balconies - one of them looking down over the nightly luau show (bonus!) and the other overlooking Waikiki Beach. The service was fantastic, the amenities were fantastic. Of special note - I left a load of laundry in the dryer the day we left (oops) - remembered in one of our connecting airports. Called the front desk when I got home and they went up to look for it and sure enough someone had nicely folded it and left it on top of the dryer. They packed it up and sent it to me no charge! LOVE HILTON!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We (my wife and I and two teenage kids) stayed 6 nights (Mon - Sun) over spring break in early April.Overall, we really enjoyed our stay here and would definitely consider Hilton Hawaiian Village for a return trip to Oahu / Waikiki.The room was booked through Hilton.com through a normal search for a hotel room - We are not HGVC owners, nor did we book this through HGVC. We did not receive any discounts or packages, and we did not have to go to a timeshare sales presentation as a part of this room reservation. I mention this because the Lagoon Tower (and the Grand Waikikian Tower) are both HGVC properties, but for our visit it was booked / treated just like a normal hotel stay. We did have housekeeping service every day, and they did a thorough job cleaning the room, even cleaning up the kitchen and starting the dishwasher.We booked in November 2011 for our April 2012 stay, and received a 2 Bedroom 'Garden View' room in the Lagoon Tower. The rate, including taxes / fees, was about $475 USD per night.We were very happy with the size of the two bedroom unit. It has a very big master bedroom with a king sized bed, closet, dresser, large screen TV, and enough space for a large comfortable chair with an ottoman. The master had its own full bath. It would have been nice to have a seperate shower / bathtub, but instead it was a combined shower / bath. Double sinks would have been nice too, but there was only a single sink.What we really enjoyed, and where we spent most of our time, was the very large living room / dining / kitchen area. The kitchen was nice and big, pretty well laid out with full fridge, electric range, microwave, and dishwasher. Adequate counter space with a toaster and coffee maker. The kitchen was also well stocked with utensils, plates, kinves, cups, glasses, and cooking gear. There is a bar between the kitchen and dining area with two bar stools. Convenient place for the kids to sit and eat, or to serve food, or for a couple of people to sit while chatting with the people preparing food in the kitchen.The dining table was quite large, with four chairs. We had friends over for dinner multiple nights and fit 8 people around the dining table (we brought the four patio chairs in from the balcony). Living room area is good sized with a couch, coffee table, chair and ottoman. Comfortable space to sit and relax. Large screen TV with Playstation and DVD player in the living room, with free movie and game rentals down in the lobby. This was a nice touch which the kids enjoyed. May have been better if the Playstation was in the kids bedroom so we did not have to listen to them play...Balcony was not that large, but big enough for 4 to sit around the table out there for a drink and to watch the sunset. Balcony is overlooking the Paradise pool, the marina next door, and it had a gorgeous view of the sunset in the evening.The second bedroom is nice as well with 2 Queen (or maybe Full?) beds. Chair in the corner of the room, and another large flat screen TV in here. The second bathroom is also a full bath, it has two doors, one from the bedroom and one from the common / room entry area. Same bath / shower combo as the master bath, and also only one sink.Lagoon tower is nicely situated for the Paradise Pool, the lagoon itself, and then the mellow HHV beach. We wanted bigger waves so a couple of days walked about 25 - 30 minutes to the Duke surfing statue and set up camp in that part of Waikiki Beach. Not too bad a walk to central Waikiki, and the kids did enjoy the ocean / waves. It will be even nicer when they complete the beach restoration project up that way.Our kids really enjoyed the Paradise Pool with the slides. Lots and lots of kids... We had a couple of mellower swims in the older pool (Super Pool?) on the other side of the Rainbow tower.One complaint is the lack of hot tubs / whirlpools! There are 2 by the kids pool, but always filled with kids too young to even be in them. My wife did find a third one at the fourth floor pool area of the Kalia Tower. With 1300 rooms, I would think they would have a couple more hot tubs, and perhaps some kid free ones too...Between Costco and multiple ABC runs, we had plenty of food in our kitchen. With all the food we stocked up, we did not eat at any HHV restaurants so cannot comment on them. We did have Lapperts ice cream a couple of nights which was good.The room was somewhat dated in terms of decor and kitchen appliances, but this was more than made up for by the sheer size of the room. I understand they are beginning a renovation of the Lagoon Tower soon, which should bring the rooms up to more modern decor and standards.There are two shared washer / dryers on each floor, with laundry soap provided. These were very convenient to have closeby and we used them a couple of times during the week.Valet parking is extra per night, but in my opinion really worth the few bucks over self parking in that huge and very full garage.Service from everyone - front desk, valet, bell desk, concierge - was very friendly and nice. We appreciated the good service and good attitudes here.Overall though, a great stay which we all really enjoyed.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We stayed in the Lagoon Tower from 3/31-4/7. We were on the 16th floor with a 2 bedroom suite! Room was beautiful and very well equipped. We did grab extra towels and other necessities as needed.My parents arrived a day after us and upon arrival we told not to take their luggage up as the bellhop would bring it up. Well, 45 minutes later it had still not arrived... My brother called and asked how long it would be. No one seemed to have an answer so, he went down and got it and it was still sitting in the same place that they had left it?!The grounds and all areas were very clean and well kept! We enjoyed the lagoon but they did seem to nickel & dime you with charges for lounge chairs, etc.We ate at Benihana and round Table pizza. We went to Germaine's Luau where we saw celebrity Guy Fieri! It was a great show and meal. Took us an hour and a half to get there instead of the 30 minutes it should've taken. Traffic was outrageous!!We gad a great time and would recommend to anyone going! Might try a less populated island if we ever get the chance to return :)

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We go to Hawaii every other year or so and like to start our stay on Oahu. The suites at the HHV Lagoon tower are quite luxurious and spacious - particularly the 2BR lockout unit. Having the services of the Hilton was very convenient (e.g. room service). One day we sent our kids to Camp Penguin (which they loved) and got an adult day to ourselves. We also liked having the dining options of the village nearby for those days we just stayed at the hotel to enjoy the beach and pools.The location is great because you have Waikiki beach - warm and calm - outside your door. Ala Moana's shopping/dining is walkable in one direction while the Waikiki restaurants (e.g Keo's) are walkable in the other. And most of Oahu (Hanauma Bay, Portlock, Kaimuki, the Pali, downtown, etc) is a short drive away.-- New/different for this yearThey have a new system for ensuring the pools are used by HHV guests - cards instead of wristbands. It seems to be working - the pools were less crowded than in years past - and more convenient as well. They also seem to be doing a better job of removing towels from unoccupied chairs.They've stopped doing 'normal' resort valet service - instead of calling down for your car when you are ready to go they now expect you to present your ticket to the valet and then wait in the lobby. I assume they are hoping to phase out valet parking and just have everyone self park in the garage.Lastly, the village is now much less of a 'village' and more of a place to buy clothes and presents for folk at home. The toy store is closed, the book/music shop (with it's excellent Hawaiiana collection) is gone, and little 'useful' is left aside from the ABC store. Not that this is a deal breaker - Ala Moana is walkable and all of Honolulu is a short drive - but part of the charm of HHV was the feeling of being in a little self contained Hawaiian village.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: My husband and I are timeshare owners and this was our first trip using our HGV points. We stayed in a studio in the Lagoon Tower from 18-23 March. The check-in experience, lobby, and hotel exteriors were very nice. However, once we found our room (immediately next to the elevators, so we kept passing it at first). Cons of the room/hotel ammenities: Just the doors and door frames looked worn down and old. Then we opened the hotel room and there was a bad smell, either cigarette smell or just stuffy. The studio was extremely small, the carpet seemed old, as did the bath tub. The bathroom could go without the door, it was always in the way. The air conditioning was loud. The mattress was uncomfortable, the sheets harsh. When we called housekeeping to replace the towels and sheets, they just dropped them off on top of the bed without taking the used ones, they also did not even pick up the trash, which we asked them to do. The DVD that we rented from the machine in the lobby did did not work in either the PlayStation or the regular DVD player. Yes there are washers and dryers one can use for free, and they give you small bags of laundry detergent, but the laundry rooms were dirty and not all the machines worked, and the ones that did took 2 hours, plus (so wasted time indoors waiting for laundry to finish).Pros of the room: dishes, microwave, coffee maker, refrigerator, free wifi (not very strong signal, password times out), DVD player, Play Station, iPod player in the alarm clock. Decent toiletries (shampoo, conditioner, soap bars, lotion, shower cap). About the hotel complex: conveniency store on site "ABC Store" is way overpriced, as are all the restaurants in the complex. There is a Walmart in the Ala Moana center that you can get to by taking the public bus $2.50. We enjoyed the Luau. Service at the Tropics restaurant was didn't match the price tags.The complex itself is beautiful but then you walk into your room and you feel like you could be anywhere else except Hawaii, and much less on a vacation since you have to do all the cleaning that you take for granted at any other hotel.weather tip: It gets a little chilly and it rained during our stay.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: This was a beautiful resort, with many stores and pools, and right by the beach. It felt like it's own little city, hence the name "village". Rooms were very good, comfortable and very clean. It was very busy, so if you don't like that, probably not the best place to stay. We enjoyed it, and the location in Waikiki is close everything. Caveat: it rains in March, so come prepared.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Just arrived back on Saturday after staying in the Lagoon tower - I work in travel so hopefully this prepares up and comers for their stay:Room: We're a family of 4 adults and found it quite spacious and the pull out queen couch isn't so bad. Everything you would need is in the kitchen - microwave, pots and pans, blender, toaster. WIFI was on and off sometimes but worked 80% of the time. It's comp so who can complain. Request for a Lagoon view if possible for the nicer view. Maids come every few days. Washer and dryers are free as well and behind elevators. You can pack less clothing and do laundry mid week if you dont mind. Food: We went for groceries at Walmart or Foodland near Ala Moana mall (15 minute walk if you dont mind a stroll) for breakfasts and lunch. The liqour selection wasn't bad at Foodland and prices are decent - some even on sale! We didn't really eat on property, only at Round Table for decent priced sandwiches and the ice cream shop beside is delish! We went to Sensai which has 50% off sushi promo (see Menu brochure for more details), its definitely worth the wait and about 45 minute walk through Waikiki. Otherwise, there's a IHOP and Wailana Coffee House (24 hours) across the street from hotel.Parking: We parked at Hale Koa which is just a walk through the village and across the street in a multi level parking for $16 a day. You get your own card which you use to exit and enter at your own free will and there was always parking available at all hours. http://www.halekoa.com/about_us/list_services_and_amenities.cfm see parking pass ratesBeach: Very nice and the lagoon is enjoyable if you want a cleaner spot to swim. Just bought a beach mat for $3 to lie on the beach as you had to pay to rent chairs/umbrellas on beach. Lounge chairs by pool are at no cost. You cannot hold lounge chairs with towels longer then 45 minutes as resort has right to remove if unattended longer. Activities: Luau we went to on the East side of island at Paradise Cove - highly recommended but traffic busy around 4pm so leave a bit sooner to bypass on the highway OR you can call and reserve and ask for them to pick you up for $13 extra for transfers. We drove and parking is included. Very nice spot with an excellent view of sunset and 2 drink tickets included.- Resort offers daily activities such as lei making, flower bracelets, hula dancing etc Service: Was great! Any housekeeping requests were prompt and check in/out was smooth. Concierge offers great advise and any help you need. Also a computer to print your boarding passes upon departure is also available - comp also. Bell guys are always available to assist as well. Well worth it!!!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: As stated in the "Title" I've stayed in every tower and prefer this "Lagoon" tower. If you're old enough and been at the village in previous years, you know these use to be rentals and then were re-done many years ago. You would never know how old this tower really is by it's appearance. It looks brand new throughout. If you like a private pool with access to all pools then stay in Alii Tower; I read a previous view from someone who downgraded it in comparison to other Hilton Vacation Club properties. I can't compare to other such properties, so my review is only regarding the Hawaiian Village and the over dozen Oahu properties I've stayed. So continuing after Alii Tower, my next favorite would be Rainbow because of views and rooms and ease to pools/restaurants, however the elevators can take a while because of the number of people waiting to get on compared to number of elevators available. The negative reviewer above preferred Kaiia Tower, I personally don't care for Kalia. I consider it along with the Tapa Tower to be more of a businessman's Tower where you don't care about view or the feeling of Hawaii. Diamond Tower is my last choice after other hotels on the island. The Waikikian Vacation Club does not have the many rooms with a view (the one I had was supposed to be partial view, well the view was the top of boat masts in the harbor if I leaned way over the side of the balcony so be aware of "partial" go for the "view" or another tower..in my opinion.My only disappointment was the car valet because too many times there was only one valet working, so the wait was long. We were on 6th floor facing Diamond Head/Rainbow Tower which I preferred, which means sitting on our balcony we could face and hear the Luau and special events on the grass area below. Plus a great view of the Friday night fireworks (make sure you find out the time and stick around to watch...it is impressive. There were some palm trees that obstructed view so get 7th floor or higher. Our room was straight off elevator and that was no problem for noise. It was good having TV in both living room and bedroom - cuts down on spouse complaint about program I'm watching or her trying to sleep. Both are nice large flat screens. I am Hilton Diamond member and didn't get upgraded, but I got the room type I paid for and was fortunate because every tower and Hotel was full for at least half my stay (I couldn't get into Hyatt, Marriotts, Astons, etc. because of Presidents Day week-end. The Gold/Diamond members VIP breakfast is on first floor of Rainbow Tower and is a short, but nice walk. If you like to leave for work after that breakfast you might think using the main valet parking, always well staff and the morning guys run fast and the wait is not too long. There is self parking in garage and sometimes if there is a big event (like the Marine's Ball, etc.) it can be a challenge finding an open spot. The Lagoon/Waikikian is faster to drive into and out of if you're driving down Ala Moana from Airport/Ala Moana shopping center (just turn right after Iliki Hotel at stop light.).Check in/out desk was fast and well staffed. Bell Desk was fast and well staffed. I had free internet, but that may have been because of my Hilton status, ask when you make reservation, otherwise don't be surprised at $15 or more charge.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Four generations of our family stayed in two apartments at the Hilton Grand Vacations Club Lagoon Tower February 19-27th and it was perfect. Not only were the apartments spacious and completely outfitted with all the kitchen supplies we needed, the location could not be beat. It is a 15 minute walk to the crowds and noise of Waikiki beach, so upon returning to the spacious beach, lagoon and landscaped grounds of the Hilton we always felt relaxed and calmed. We rented a car and hit Costco and Safeway to stock up on groceries for the week and the bellmen were most helpful getting all our shopping up to our apartments for a $5.00 flat fee. Obviously they have done this before. Half our group paid less for a Garden View apartment while we paid more for an Ocean View apartment and while our view was gorgeous out over Ala Moana Park and the Harbour, they had a perfect view of the pool for way less money! Same side of the building. The difference as explained by the front desk is that garden view puts you on the lower floors, but for the almost $1000.00 difference I would take that! The Paradise Pool is right beside Lagoon Tower and it is hands down the kids favourite pool, so if you are travelling with kids I would recommend this location, as we could lean over the balcony and tell each other when lunch was ready! The Friday night fireworks were impressive, and the ideal place to stand and watch is anywhere along the edge of the Lagoon. Before we left I read the reviews on Trip Advisor and was very nervous about cockroaches in the room. Happily, we never saw any in either apartment, where everything was spotless.One last thing - the Grand Waikikian might be newer and fancier, but it is set back farther from the Lagoon and pool compared to the Lagoon Tower, making it harder to keep track of your kids, and making it louder because of its proximity to the busy Ala Moana boulevard.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We stayed in a 2/2 ocean front timeshare with full kitchen. It's not as modern as the grand waikikian: the front door was a little sticky, the dvd player is a playstation, but you can't beat the view. We watched the "green flash" two out of three nights. Although its at one end of waikiki, it's not isolated. We walked along the beachwalk towards Diamond Head, cut through the Sheraton, and reached the international market place in less than half an hour. Highly recommend.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: loved it there so beautiful , the Lagoon is lovely , the rooms are nice with every thing you need,the Pool has a Slide and waterfall which makes it so nice , its just Heaven I Recommend it 10 out of 10

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: I love Hawaii. I love O'ahu, Honolulu and Waikiki. I've stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village a few times. Rainbow and Kalia towers at the Hilton. Lagoon and Kalia towers at Hilton Grand Vacations. This review is about the Lagoon tower, where I am right now!I like the HHV, I like the location, I like the rooms (especially the view from the Rainbow tower). I don't eat in the restaurants here (too expensive and better alternatives locally ... like the Wailana Coffee House for breakfast).This is a busy hotel and even with "status" (I'm a Diamond Hhonors member and an Elite HGVC), there's no chance of an upgrade.I don't think this hotel, and I'm talking HGVC @ Lagoon tower specifically, is representative of HGVC (and I've stayed at loads of them). The service is NOT friendly, it's not Hawaiian.This is the second time that they have given me the worst room they could have given me based on what I "paid", and this time they said "I should have contacted them, to remind them, that I'm an HGVC Elite" ... the attitude is wrong here, it's just so untypical of HGVC, of Hilton and of Hawaii.In future, if I can't book the Kalia tower, I'll stay at Hilton rather than HGVC @ Lagoon tower ... but I do love it in Hawaii, I will be back.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: I've been staying in Hilton Grand Vacations (Grand Waikikian or Lagoon Tower) for 5 years now and they have been very consistent in offering good service and classy amenities in the room. The Lagoon tower suites has been renovated and interiors are now modern. Grand Waikikian of course have better designs, but more expensive and farther from the beach front..1) Beach front, easy access to the beach and swimming areas2) 10 to 15 minute walk to Ala Moana Mall3) Few Shops and restaurants are accessible and within the grounds of the hotel4) Tours can be easily arranged at the concierge5) Kitchen and utensils are provided6) 2 Bedroom unit is value for money for 4 to 6 guests.7) Free wifi internet in the room8) You can take a relaxing 10 min walk along the waikiki beach if you want to go to other shopping areas along Kalakaua Ave9) Lots of ABC convenient stores aroundCons - late check in, but you will be given free access to lounge in case you want to freshen up.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Stayed at the 3rd floor of the Lagoon tower. Two bedroom suite, very nice, big receiving area and a cool pantry and dining table to have a meal. However, since the room was facing the pool, and it was just above it (3rd floor) noise from the outside would always get in the room all day. As long as there are children playing in the pool, you can hear the noise.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We are on our way home from a weeks stay. The rooms were decorated beautiful. Great views of the city. We were on the 26 floor. The ocean was cool until, you got In and it warmed up. The pools were on the cool side until you were able to get use to it. Sun was hot with the trade wind breeze. Within walking distance to may shopping areas. We did take the bus sometimes for transportation. Service was great everyone was very helpful. Just one call down the desk and they brought up what was needed in minutes.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Everyone was so good, from the time we checked in until the time we left, whatever we need they were right there, the room was very clean and very relaxing to be in

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: This was our 9th consecutive year staying here through the Holidays. We arrived at the Lagoon Towers on 12/22 when our kids arrived in Honolulu. My husband and I had been staying in the Rainbow tower up until then.We were pleasantly surprised when we saw that the rooms had been updated... modern decor and soothing color palette... VERY NICE!I enjoy having the full kitchen and while I don't really use it for a lot of cooking, it is wonderful to be able to store snacks and drinks, cereal for quick breakfasts and most importantly... having the opportunity to make a traditional Christmas Eve dinner for our family :)We travel for 3 weeks so the washer and dryers on each floor are a big plus in our decision to stay here as well. It is family friendly and the staff is always welcoming and eager to assist. We were first given a room that reeked with the smell of cigarettes and they worked hard to move us around... not an easy feat as anyone who has ever visited during this time of year will tell you.We love the grounds and enjoy walking into the "busier" section of Waikiki and then retreating back into our little section of quiet and calm. The resort is so romantic and in the evenings, it is lit up with so many torches. There is a short but sweet fireworks show every Friday night.Stop by the Tropics for a drink after the beach... there is usually live entertainment from about 5-ish. The Parahna Brothers Band (not sure of spelling) was awesome and so was Henry Kapono!!!!! Try the Waikiki Cosmo... absolutely delish!Our only pet peeve... the luau done on the rooftop of the convention center becomes VERY, VERY annoying when you are forced to listen to their show EVERY NIGHT! Even with our lanai doors closed, we could still hear the noise. A bummer since my husband and I love sitting out on the balcony with a glass of wine.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We stayed in the Lagoon tower in a two bedroom suite. For a family with two collage age kids this was perfect. Nice wide screen TVs, comfortable beds, well equipped kitchen. The only problem is that we were facing away from the lagoon and towards the hotel next door. If we left the window or balcony door open we heard the drone of their giant air conditioners. This is part of a mega-village with lots of vacationers. Service is where this place fell apart. Lines for everything. We were there during the holidays, so one can kind of make an excuse. There was a long lines for check-in.We went to the concierge to book our Pearl Harbor tour, she said she couldn't help us with that and sent us to the tour desk (but she could sell us a timeshare.) The Tour desk was a long line with only two clerks and a 45 minute wait. PLAN AHEAD! Book before you go and/or directly with providers. Pros:Comfortable accommodations and excellent amenitiesBeautiful lagoon and beachGreat groundsCons:Poor service and long linesA long walk to the main action and shops of Waikiki

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Our family stayed in a two bedroom two bath suite with a full kitchen in the Lagoon Tower. The suite was perfect for our family. Two good sized bedrooms and nice bathrooms. Large living room with 2 good sized balconies. Nice view of the marina. the suite was very clean, no bugs in sight! Nicely furnished, nice thick walls that prevented sound from travelling. Worked great for our family of 5 and allowed us to entertain other family as we were there for a family reunion. Our inlaws had the exact same room 6 floors up and it was the same quality. Pools were nice. Would have liked to have the Lagoon pool heated as it was very chilly water and would have been nice to have a bar and snack bar at that pool. We were there during the entire APEC weekend and yes traffic was bad but we had access to the beach in front of the hotel the entire time. Yes Secret Service was there but did not effect us at all. Hilton did notify us just before our arrival about the traffic but could have done more to help with transportation in and out of the hotel during the weekend. Yes restaraunts are expensive, that is why we loved having the full kitchen. Nice to have lots of groceries available downstairs in the lobby. Hotel staff was very friendly and checked on us several times to make sure our stay was meeting our expectations.Overall we had a great time at this resort. Actually better than I expected considering what I had heard about Wakiki being so busy and about the hotel and about the APEC restrictions. We are HHonors members and did not book this through a time share sales office.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Booked a studio and was appalled upon arrival. For the excessive amount of money charged for what is a Hilton Grand Vacation property, I walked into a tiny room comparative to a Days Inn, with no view, dark, dismal, with no balcony. I literally couldn't find enough floor space to open my suitcase. I immediately called to reception to express my concerns and at first they weren't going to do anything. But I insisted and got upgraded to a better room, a one bedroom. It was in the tower next door, the Grand Waikikian, a "luxury" property. The one bedroom suite was very nice. It had a full kitchen, two bedded bedroom, a big tub, walk-in shower, nice bathroom and a view of a busy intersection and other buildings from its balcony, which I never used, due to the view. Hey, it was an improvement over the studio. I had to switch four days in, and they were going to make me return to the studio. Even though the general manager of the hotel had promised this would not happen. I checked online and they were selling the very room I was staying in on several sites, yet they were telling me one was not available. I refused to return to the studio, and somehow, even though five minutes before I was told by the resort manager it was impossible, they found me a one-bedroom in the Lagoon Tower. After all of the promises and the demonstrations of concern, this made me feel very badly about the management and my treatment. Yes, I was upgraded, but at such a cost? The lagoon tower 1 BR was a big step down from the Grand Waikikian 1 BR, but had all the amenities and a balcony. But for the money, I could have stayed in a luxury resort in the center of Waikiki. The property itself is huge. There are five or six towers, a mix of Hilton Grand Vacations buildings and the Hilton hotel buildings. It was extremely crowded and not quiet or restful at all. We walked the entire property to find a quiet place away from the crowds and couldn't find a single nook or cranny to get away from it all. If you want quiet luxury, the Halekalani or the Westin would fit the bill, for about the same price or less, and in the center of Waikiki. The Hilton is a 15 minute walk to the center of the action, although there is a shopping mall right on property with restaurants, shops and a mini-mart. There are several restaurants nearby as well that are much less expensive than the onsite choices. Everything is a long walk away. I love to walk so it didn't bother me, but if you have trouble getting around, this is not the place for you. The gym was 10 minutes walk from the Lagoon tower. There was a largish sized gym mostly filled with aerobics equipment. at 7am, there was not a single machine available. There are about 20 machines for what is probably 2000+ guests. The steam room/sauna area costs $17 per day extra, but gym is free. There is a nice, quiet pool outside the spa. The only quiet pool on property, but with no view and not very lush or pretty. There are four other pools and a beautiful lagoon area with a beach and a big wading lagoon. Then the beach is right there. You couldn't ask for a better spot on the beach. If you want a chair or an umbrella, you'll have to pay $30 for the umbrella and $15 per chair. You can lay on the beach for free. The big pool has lots of available chairs, but there is no shade from the sun by mid-day. There are no umbrellas at any of the pools and escaping the sun became a problem. The lagoon pool is very shady, but small and packed with kids. The lagoon pool is very pretty. Get there early to snag a chair. To use the pools, you have to wear an armband and use cards to claim towels. Lose the cards and its $10 per card. When I got the towels the guy said he didn't care about the wristbands. He only cared about the cards, so I never wore my wristband again. There are two beach bar restaurants by the main pool and they are both very nice, not ridiculously priced and offer happy hours in the afternoon.The shopping area within the resort grounds is really nice and there are lots of good restaurant choices. But the main drag in Waikiki, a $6 cab ride, is awesome for all that. Amazing shopping, every high end brand you can think of, four Coach stores alone. Great restaurants, beautiful hotels and hotel bars. Lots of fun. Staying at the HIlton was not peaceful at all. It is a city unto itself with thousands of tourists roaming around, its own traffic, and nasty patrolmen. But if you like a place that is full of life, exciting in many ways, then you might like the Hilton.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Oh dear. Ohhhhh, Hilton. No goodsies. To preface: we booked this trip after being sold on a discounted vacation by Hilton if we'd just sit through a 2-hour timeshare presentation. We knew it was probably going to be at least mildly annoying, but hey, it's Hilton, how bad can it be? We were told very clearly that we would be staying in a suite large enough to hold at least two couples with a kitchen and a washer dryer. My fiance and I were both on the call, wrote down what we were told, and he emailed it to me to have a record of the conversation that same day. Keep that in mind as you read this review, y'all.So we arrive at Honolulu airport for our very badly needed vacation having heard just prior to leaving that the APEC summit was going on at the same time. We didn't hear this from Hilton, mind you, but from a snorkeling tour company. The lovely and helpful girls at the rental car place helpfully informed us that Obama was staying at Hilton. Again, the rental car girls - not Hilton. Look, I get it that Hilton doesn't control the APEC summit, isn't in charge of security for the POTUS, and that it's really a good economic thing for Hawaii. I understand, really. But don't you think that just maybe they could have warned us far enough in advance so we could change our plans if we didn't want to be in Waikiki at the same time and have our vacation severely compromised by all the security and general hullabaloo? Even if they couldn't say exactly who was going to stay there, they could have said something generic. ANYway...So we finally arrive at HHV (after having our car searched by Secret Service) only to be told that there were no rooms with king beds available. Um... what? My fiance and I are not sleeping in two double beds, but thanks. Call your supervisor. And lo! A wild king bed miraculously appears! I'm starting to get a funny feeling at this point, because weren't we supposed to be in a suite? Didn't the nice saleslady who sold us this vacation tell us we should totally bring another couple? So with great trepidation we head up to our room, only to find a gungy carpet, stained desk chair, and totally unremarkable teensy hotel room. Not okay. My honey calls down to the timeshare concierge to find out what the sam hill is going on, and after quite a bit of back and forth about what the package includes vis-a-vis what we were promised, she says she'll call her supervisor to find out what she can do. We head down to the bar to have an umbrella drink (you know, because we're on vacation in Hawaii and would like to enjoy ourselves at some point) and wait. And wait. And get glowered at by Secret Service. And wait some more. Then she calls back. Good news! She can upgrade us to something sort of vaguely approximating the type of room we were promised for the low low price of an additional 80 dollars a night! And because they're so very nice, they'll even waive the $100 fee they'd normally charge for changing the room type after check in! Yeeeeeeah no.So we go trundling over to her office (not actually having had our fruity beverages yet, mind you) to talk this out face-to-face. And she tells us that she's superduper sorry, but the saleslady was wrong, shouldn't have told us we'd be getting anything more than the most basic room, and basically that we need to suck it up and deal, the 80 buck upgrade is her best offer. We very calmly explain our position to her - this is not what we agreed to, not what we were promised, and not what we paid for. We're not paying extra because their people messed up. We're either going to get what we were promised or we're going to check out and go elsewhere (I've already called two other hotels) and dispute the charges from Hilton to our credit cards. She'll call her supervisor again. Okay, we'll go down to the beach and wait for her call. Oh, wait, we can't go to the beach. The beach is closed due to heightened security. Sigh. Okay, can she buy us a froofy tropical drink from the pool bar, then? WHAAAAAAT? In all her years she has NEVER had someone ask her such a thing! Sputter sputter well I never! She hands us $50 in "Hilton Dollars" to spend on the property. We head out the door. Wait, her colleague says! You know you can't use those for alcohol, right? Jesus mercy, people, I tell you what. So we finally have some relaxing libations in hand (the relaxing quality somewhat compromised by the beefy men with earpieces frowning at us from every angle) when she calls back. Fine, we can have the suite for no upcharge, but they're going to listen to the tape of our call with the saleslady and if they find out we're lying liars who lie, they're going to charge us an additional $60 dollars a night for the suite. Um, the suite you were trying to upgrade us to for EIGHTY bucks a night a few minutes ago? Before you wasted three hours of our vacation and then questioned our integrity? Yeah, that suite. Which did have a kitchen but only one bedroom - imagine if we actually HAD brought another couple! How embarrassing that would have been! The ONLY reason this is a 2-star review instead of one is because we did ultimately get (more or less) what we were promised and we cooked some delicious fish tacos in that kitchen out of a mahi-mahi I caught. I won't bore you with details of the timeshare presentation, but it, um, wasn't good. We didn't buy it. I know you're shocked. Also: it's been two weeks since they told us they were going to listen to the tape. We've heard nothing. Funny, that.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We have stayed several times before at the Hilton Hawaiian Village in the Ali'i Tower. I could not book rooms this stay (later to find out because President Obama was staying in the Ali'i Tower during our stay)...so we were left to the other towers of the hotel. I booked the Lagoon Tower of the Hilton Hawaiian Grand Vacations Club. WOW!!! What a nice change! We have a 5 year old and this room was perfect for our family. We had a 1 bedroom which includes a separate living room with a pull out bed. It also has a FULL kitchen which is a blessing. Our one complaint in our past stays is that there are not many economical choices to eat in that area of Waikiki, with a full kitchen we were able to cook a little and warm up left overs. It saved a ton of money and time as were weren't waiting to be served at a restaurant. We just went up to our room and made food for ourselves. I think I will be booking this tower in the future instead of the Ali'i Tower. We still had access to all of the amenities of the Hilton Hawaiian Village. The other thing that was great is that it is near the new pool that has the water slides as well as the lagoon....which are both very popular with our son. The other thing that I really enjoyed is that they have free DVD's you can get from the lobby (which is not available at the Ali'i Tower) and free laundry services on each floor of the Lagoon Tower. Our room was on the 3rd floor facing the lagoon with a partial ocean view. Very great...felt part of the fun but also secluded in a good way. The only bad thing is that we did find a cockroach in the bathroom (which I killed) but we have stayed in the Ali'i Tower and my mother in law found the same thing there too! I did let the front desk know at the end of our stay and they did credit our hotel bill for the incident. This is the reason I rated the cleanliness of the hotel poor. Overall the room was clean except for the previous incident mentioned.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We come every year from australia to the hilton and this time we purchased a two bedroom in the lagoon tower with the grand vacation club.we find it so central to everywhere in waikiki and easy access to the trolley and buses. the resort is always clean,the staff friendly and helpful and the atmosphere very relaxing.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We stayed at the Hilton Grand Vacations Club Lagoon Tower for two nights in October 2011. We paid $395 per night in advance for the two bedroom, two-bath suite, which after taxes came to $450 per night. The room was clean and comfortable but not luxurious. The cabinets in the kitchen and the bathrooms were painted MDF and looked like they came from a big box store. The wooden front door to the suite was scuffed and gouged which did not create a good first impression. Sheets and towels were basic grade (no Frette linens here!) and the bath amenities were unremarkable. The overall experience in the room was okay but nothing special. However, the staff members that we encountered on property were helpful and pleasant. What the Hilton Hawaiian Village has going for it is a fabulous location and gorgeous grounds. For a 2 bedroom 2 bath suite, $450 a night in Waikiki is a relative bargain so I didn't feel cheated, but by the same token I wouldn't run to stay there again.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Stayed here for 6 nights in September 2011 in the Kalia Tower. We were given an accessible room even though I did not reserve one. We were advised that the view would be better in this room than in others that were available in our rate category. The view was fine -- for a gardenview room on the third floor. Suites are more than adequate for a couple and we made use of the full kitchen facilities. As parking at the hotel is expensive, we parked nearby at the marina parking lot or on the street close to the marina. Housekeeping staff did a good job, leaving many towels, and were friendly.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: One of the quality, true "resorts" in Hawaii - ie not just a swimming pool with a room attached. You could remain self-contained within the resort with heaps to do but then you would hardly know you were in Hawaii.We got our room by booking direct as travel agents only get certain classes of rooms to play with and the Lagoon Tower includes time-share suites. These offer 2br and a kitchen which for the 4 in our family was a winner. All the agents wanted us to book two rooms...On-site dining and entertainment is good, easy access on either the beach or by road down to Waikiki Beach proper and the ala moana (sp?) shopping centre is 1k in the other direction. I'd go again.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: spent 3 weeks in a 2 bedroom ocean view room, asked for a view of diamond head, got it. The room is fantastic, was concerned about the quality of the fold out bed in the lounge, my two sons 13 and 9, had to share it and they were fine. Pools are great, lagoon is fun and takes 7 minutes to walk around for exercise. Hired a stand up paddle board from down the street to save a lot of money and we had it for our whole stay, it fitted in the lift on the left. Hilton looked after us a lot better than we had previously had with another major hotel chain, who don;t seem to care if you are repeat clients of staying for a long time, won't hesitate to recommend this hotel.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Spent a glorious Labor day weekend at Hilton Grand vacations club at Hilton Hawaiian Village, Lagoon tower. Check in staff was excellent, clerk that assisted us, I think her name is Hiruko or Shizuko, was so friendly and welcoming. She was true to HGVC's usual greeting of "Welcome Home".Housekeeping staff are prompt and accomodating. I especailly like to thank Cora at Ready Line for here excellent service. Requested amenities that we needed were promptly delivered to us.Everywhere you look around, staff has smiles ready for you.Wish we could have stayed longer, 3 nights is not enough.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: By all measures this resort is top notch. Absolutely beautiful grounds and location can't be beat. All the staff, except the rude woman, at check in were wonderful. The luau, however, stinks. What a total waste of money. First of all the location is on the top of their parking garage!! no views, no beach, no nothing. My husband and I paid extra for a flower lei greeting and priority seating. When we were showed to our table we were at the end of a longish table. My husband and I were seated across from each other and both my legs did not fit under the table. I had enough room on the table in front of me for my plate. The food was awful .... oh, I take that back ... the lettuce salad and the fruit salad (no tropical fruit, strawberries and blueberries) were ok. The dance part of the show was ok, however, the host looks like he lost his way from an off the strip Vegas lounge. Very smarmy. Go to any other luau on Oahu .... do not go to Hilton's, you'll be sorry.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: My wife and 2 young kids stayed at the Lagoon Tower. I believe the "Grand Vacations Club at Hilton Hawaiian Village" includes all of the Lagoon Tower and bits of 2 other towers. Between the 3 the Lagoon Tower has the slightly better location but the other 2 maybe a bit nicer. I can't comment on the other 2. (The Waikikian is separate and seems much nicer than all of the other towers, including the hotel towers.)Very satisfied, good value (at about $250 for a one bedroom suite, which included internet) slightly more than the 4* hotels on Wakiki beach but you get a lot more for your money. If you can afford the Wakikian go there, otherwise, this is pretty good. Don't expect great ocean views, as the Dimondhead tower obstructs most ocean views, with the Dimonhead tower being a bit dated).The HHV seems to be only one of 2 (the other one is the Sheraton) properties with pools with slides for the kids, and in theory it's heated but I suspect they don't keep the pool temperature at little kid comfortable temperatures. They also allow non-guess, for a fee, to use the pool, which makes it very crowded at times. Parking is also a bit of a hassle, probably no more so than other Waikiki hotels, though.Location wise, arguably the best location on Waikiki is where the Royal Hawaiian and Duke's are, so the HHV is a bit far from that. However, it's not bad for families being a bit away from the really busy part of Waikiki.All in all, very satisfied.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Hilton Hawaiian Village Ruined our Wedding! We gave my wife's wedding dress to Hilton to steam on the day before our wedding to be ready for our special day. Instead of steaming it, they washed in in the washing machine, ruining it. They offered to get us a new dress and alter it to fit the same as the old. The seamstresses who were supposed to alter the dress were not familiar with wedding dresses and destroyed the new dress as well leaving us with a terribly fitting dress .
