Hilton agreed to compensate us for the dresses and fly us back to Hawaii to make up for the day they ruined and told us to enjoy the rest of our time on the Islands. Upon returning home, they denied ever making these promises. Do not stay at the property and patronize these people that have no integrity and do not make good on promises they make. Do not let them ruin your dream day as well.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: I stayed at this hotel with my family for two weeks. The ambiance, staff and amenities were fantastic! My favorite part was the surrounding views and the beautiful pools. There was also an extraordinary fireworks display when we were there -- the kids really enjoyed it. This is a very family friendly hotel. We will definitely be back!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Have stayed at 2 of the hotels in the Hilton Hawaiian Village complex at Waikiki in the past and wanted more room (& a kitchen) this time round. Excellent value staying in a 2 bedroom apartment rather than booking 2 rooms at a hotel. At 18 & 20 our children are too old to share a room with us!!! Having a living room and kitchen as well as bedrooms was fantastic!! There was a laundry on the same level as our room - not sure if they are on each level, but probably. The pool was very crowded, but you can use the other pools in the resort & the beach. There is also a lagoon. Easy walking distance to Ala Moana shopping centre. The GVS are on the edge of the Hilton complex, so the rooms on one side face the resort and the rooms on the other side (like ours) face the hotel across the road, but also the yacht club. The views are better than the Waikikian which is behind the GVS. Some rooms face the ocean - these of course would be more expensive. The Hilton Hawaiian Village has plenty of shops and restaurants but there are also more within walking distance. This is at the end of Waikiki beach, but only a 15 minute walk (along the beach path) to get the busy area of Wakiki shopping & nightlife. A quick tram or taxi ride if you don't want to walk. Would definitely stay here again if travelling with more than 2 people.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Our family of four stayed in a one bedroom at the Lagoon Tower overlooking the Paradise Pool. The kitchen in the room helped to keep costs of meals down, and we ate breakfast and lunch on the balcony many times. The kids loved the water slides and paddling a surfboard around the lagoon. We had dinner at a few of the restaurants in the Hilton Hawaiian Village; good food though a little pricy. We rented a car at the Hertz on site to visit Pearl Harbor and the Polynesian Cultural Center. All in all we had a wonderful time at the resort!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: This place has everything you need, beach, pool, restaurants, convenient,entertainment. But to use the facilities will cost you a pretty penny.The swimming pools are all kids friendly with none over 5 ft deep.There are restaurants within 5 minutes walking distance from the hotel, that offer better value.Do check out the bus and trolley schedules, they take you anywhere you want to go for s couple of bucks.Try the Aloha stadium flea market on Wednesdays, Saturday and Sunday if you want bargains on souvenirs.The Ala Moana is 15 minutes away on foot, or you can take the pink trolley right outside the Tapa Tower for $2each way, it has many stores and the best food court I have ever seen.Not all the floors have wifi, even if you want to pay for Internet service, so request for a floor that has wifi, for example, it is only available on the 12th floor and above at the Kalia Tower for some reason.Overall, this place has everything you need in a resort hotel, we enjoyed our stay, and the staff was friendly. Just eat somewhere else if you don't want to spend big bucks!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We were very fortunate to be on the top floor in a corner suite. Tons of room for the 6 of us. We enjoyed every moment of our stay there. Take the time to watch the fireworks by the Hilton lagoon - a special memory for us. The full kitchen was perfect for our family. We were able to relax and sit around the table eating and playing cards. Laundry facilities are on each floor.....and free!The village shops where fun to explore.Look for the penguins:)

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We stayed there from May 29 to June 4 for a family vacation. The check-in counter was very busy, but fortunately my husband is a Gold member so we had priority check-in and of course an upgrade on the room. We stayed in the Ali'i Tower which was really nice with its private pool, which we used most of the time. The only problem with our room was that the mattresses were really soft (pillow top) which we are not used to (we prefer firm mattresses). The Internet was free for members as well as water bottles.We had complimentary breakfast every morning in the private lounge for members. It included fresh fruits, various cereals and breads, hard boiled eggs, juices, tea and coffee. Even though it was repetitious, we enjoyed it because it was always fresh, plus we had a great view from the terrace.My 12 year old son enjoyed the various pools, especially the one with the slides; however, the water was a bit cold.We visited other hotels while we were there and concluded that we had picked the best hotel for our needs. We found it well kept, loved the pathway leading you around the resort and the exotic animals. All in all, we had a great vacation.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: I really wanted to write a review on HGVC. My daughter & I were completely satisified w/the 1bdrm suite we had. It was clean, neat, and roomy. The hotel staff was very friendly & helpful. I would recommend this hotel to anyone looking for fun. There was always some fun & exciting to do. The beach & pools were never overcrowded.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We rented a two bedroom condo at the Hilton for a wedding/vacation. The location was great, as well as the service and amenities the location offered. The campus had several pools, bars, restaurants and even a lagoon. The only aspect to consider is that this a very family oriented hotel. Since our group was child-less, I may have be interested in a hotel with a more adult atmosphere.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We just finished our 9th stay in Hilton Hawaiian and most of our stays were in Alii Tower except once in Tapa temporarily for a couple of days. First I like the vast space, or the complex Hilton Hawaiian has.: the many shops and restaurants. Secondly we love the location: as from here you can walk to the west and east Waikiki so easily. Needless to say it has the best stretch of beach in Waikiki, plus the multiple pools and a man-made lagoon. While I can't say for all other towers, the Alii does have great view, be that the ocean, city or garden side. I agree the hotel is older and the service in such big operation can be sometimes not as prompt. But over all I am quite happy and this is the Hilton that I don't mind to go back for the 10th time.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Absolutely beautiful property. Tall palms, beautiful beaches, protected swimming area and a lagoon for water activities. Check out the website for good tour. A busy place and especially accomodating for familys. Lots for children to do. I really can not express in words how much I love this property. Each tower is different on the Hilton Hawaiian Village property. We have stayed 5 times. Particulary enjoyed apartment condo experience. We stayed in a one bedroom in the Lagoon tower. But have enjoyed king and double rooms in the other towers. Six blocks away from city so an easy walk in. Especially beautiful when you us beach walk. Meals at hotel are pricey. The pronto pickle on site is good and priced well. Off site and near by is a wonderful greek restaurant and a local diner cafe that people line up for to get breakfast. Both on side street adjoining Grand Waikikian. In town on lewer is the yard house. Noisey like a sports bar but good food priced well.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Our week long trip to Hilton Hawaiin Village was great.Check in was done in a few minutes and check out was done on the phone.We did this as part of a time share opportunity.We went through the presentation and once we declined there was no pressure to sign on.HIlton Hawaiin Village is a large beach side resort.Twenty two acres sounds large but it's not that big you cant negotiate it with ease. If you do get lost ask any staff and they will help you get where you are going.Our room was great with a view of the marina and ocean.We only ate at two restaurants on site.Sergios and the round tabel pizza.Prices are about double what they are on the mainland.Sergios had sunset special at twenty bucks a piece for salad,main coarse and dessert.Supposedly tip is included,asked waiter about this and he said he didnt put it on our bill.I think he did this to get double tipping. Only left a couple of bucks so he either thinks we are lousy tippers or scammed another tourist.The round table pizza restaurant was busy but service was prompt and courteous.Medium pizza 27 dollars.The grounds and buildings were all beautiful and well kept.There were minor things you saw that needed repair but so does our house.The pool side show and fireworks on Friday are a must see. The show is about 45 minutes with Hawaiin singer and dancers followed immediatly by the fireworks.Fireworks about 10 minutes but right on Waikiki and great end to the day.If we go back to Oahu would probably stay at HHV.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: It is crowed..but beautiful with so much to do. 6 towers only one to have mostly all kitchens, is the Lagoon Tower. Our room is comfortable at the end of the building with a balcony ourside our great room, and one outside the dining area..How lucky we are to get this. Only draw back is the guest room is 2 twin beds (we ask for kings sheets and blankets to make it a king with no problem)..you have to walk out across the hallway hoping the other couple keeps their door shut till you finish getting ready. We have asked for many things and the resort right away brings it up.We did a timeshare presentation and Sara was excellent not giving us a very hard time. Talked and learned much from her on Hilton information. Each couple received $100 Hilton dollars to spend at restaurants and shops here at Hilton Hawaiian Village. Jimmy Buffet's Margarittaville within walking distance from our room maybe 1/2 mile. Yes if you spend money there or at their retail shop they stamp your parking ticket to park valet..right at the door, very handy. Tonight our plan is to do the Magic of Polynesia right near Jimmy Buffett's upstairs..hope it is good. We drove around some of the island 6/13/11 and to check out Polynesian Culture Center, to spend our Wednesday there all day starting at noon, and going till 9pm to do the Ambassador Luau, most expensive but that way we are first in line for the dinner and escorted all over the Center. I wish we could stay a month...we spent one week at the Hilton at Kings'land Hilton on Kona (Lavaland) and it was excellent. Wrote a review on it earlier..Loving our 2 weeks stay..

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: The Hilton Hawaiian Village is a theme park. I've been staying at this compound since i was in my pre-teens when my mom used to own one of the condos that have been converted into timeshares. Each year the complex gets bigger, more expensive, more theme-parkish and less authentic. That's not to say it isn't nice, fun, clean, and "hawaiian"... but if you're the type to look for a less touristy locale keep looking. You won't get personalized over-the-top service here as the staff is busy shuffling guest in and out all day... but the staff is Hawaiian after all so everything comes with a SMILE.All of Hawaii is a bit expensive but you should be prepared to open your wallet if you're staying and eating at the village. Also the resort is a bit removed from other parts of the island if you don't have a car. The village is better for families and has plenty to keep the kids occupied.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: I could ramble on and on about this property, but I'll keep it short and simple. Beautiful atmosphere, excellent staff & service, great location. Did I say beautiful? We have absolutely no complaints whatsoever. My wife, sister-in-law, brother-in-law and I stayed in a 2 bedroom plus condo at the Lagoon Tower from 5/8-5/16/2011 with a lovely view of Diamond Head. We can hardly wait to return. My wife Kathy and I are extremely satisfied with our decision to become owners with HGVC in 2008.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Came for a romantic weekend to Waikiki something I do once or twice a month.Checked in with a Japanese agent that spoke limited English went to our room and found that it had 2 Double Beds. Called the front desk and she had one room available with a King went to get key then moved all our things to new room then found it was a Handicap room No Tub shower leaks all over the floor, all tables and facilities set at knee level Great if I wasn't 6'3" Called the Manager Kim who promptly blamed me for the fact that I missed the fact that the room was a double I guess I missed the fine print where it said dbl on the reservation. MY fault I guess I need to be more aware of bait and switch On the last day of my stay my toilet got plugged after 4 (FOUR) calls and one hour with the final call to the Manager on duty some one finally came with a plunger.The internet is slower than some dial up connections I've been on. The most amazing thing is I stayed as a PREMIER ELITE OWNER having invested almost $300,000 and paying over $10,000 a year in maintenance fees. MY advice STAY AWAY the service was never great here but it has gotten much worse and if you are thinking of buying Hilton Grand Vacations think twice once they have your money you screwed.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Suites are roomy, spacious and clean. Love the luxury of full kitchen and separate bedroom. Stayed at Lagoon Tower with great views of Diamond Head, Luau, Beaches, Lagoon, and other towers. Love the free internet access, video games and free movie rentals. Balcony is nice and relaxing. Conceirge was helpful and always pleasant. Would totally come here again with and without kids.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We are timeshare owners in the Lagoon Tower and have been staying here once a year for 6 years now. I love this place. It's the perfect location to everything you could want to do. I read alot of comments that are negative about the crowd, the noise, the expense. If you feel that way, then my goodness get on a trolley (they pick you up & drop you off at this SAME location), or rent a car and get the heck out of the area for the day. There are many wonderful beaches on the Island that are less travelled & many local places to eat good inexpensive food (The Makai FoodCourt in Ala Moana Mall for one). You are not forced to eat on the premises or take in the sun on the Waikiki Beach. Get going! The best times we have are exploring the Island and then coming back to our Splendid Condo unit for the evening. Taking a walk on Waikiki beach at night is awesome. How can you be so shocked and surprised at the crowds, noise, hustle and bustle, expense etc. when you know you are vacationing in WAIKIKI for crying out loud? Did you do your homework before you came to stay at a place that is known for it's over the top way of doing things? I am surprised that anyone coming here would not be prepared for what they are to expect. It is not the fault of the Resort, it is the fault of the one's who don't take into consideration that you will be staying in Honolulu, on Waikiki Beach, at a Huge Resort.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We stayed this month with our 8 and 4 year olds. The Hawaiian Village was quite busy and large but had great amenities for our children. Restaurants close by, beach and lagoon, lots of pools but they were very cold. We picked the Hilton so they could be on the water slides, etc. but ended up not using the pools much because of the temperature so that was disappointing.We stayed in the Lagoon Tower in a one bedroom suite. It was very nice and clean. Decor was tasteful and to our liking. Staff were very helpful. We had a comfortable stay and it was relatively quiet for a large complex which was nice. It was nice to have complimentary DVDs for us and the kids too.It was quite the ant hill in some respects as it was a big place but we expected that. Lots to see and do on site. The children loved the fireworks on Friday night. It is worth the watch.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: My family and I recently spent 9 nights at the Lagoon tower in a 2 bedroom suite. This was the second stay at the HHV, but the first time in the Lagoon tower. We traveled with 2 children under the age of 5. My comments:Service: The service was exceptional. Everyone we interacted with were extremely friendly and helpful. The Bellman on check in and check out couldn't have been more helpful and friendly. The room: We had a 2 br suite, 17th floor, overlooking the marina and parking garage/luau. The room was much bigger than it looked in the pictures and we were very happy with it. There was plenty of space inside and out on the balconies. The kitchen had all the utensils we needed. The soft and chairs we comfortable. The bathrooms were nice. The carpets looked a bit dated, but considering how much sand and wet-feet they get on a regular basis, I thought they were fine. Amenities: We used the free laundry facilities and that worked well. The free wi-fi was great. We rented free DVDs from the machine in the lobby, which was nice. Activities: We visited the Paradise Pool at least once a day and my sons loved it. It is not heated, so it is cool at first, but we got used to it. Never had a problem finding a couple of loungers to drop our stuff. Saturday and Sunday it is definely much busier that during the week. We were excited about using the lagoon (as it was not useable the last time we were there) but it was cooler than the pool or beach, the sand is kind of hard and it seemed a little dirty (fish and birds use the lagoon too) for swimming. The beach was very easy and the sand was fun to play in. There is a band of jagged rocks about 5-10 yards out that are hard to walk on so we only visited the beach for swimming when the tide we up. The fitness center in the Kailea Tower was free for Lagoon guests and was nice.Restaurants and shops: The food is expensive in the restaurants and stores. We taxied to the Foodland at the Ala Moana Mall the first day and then mid-stay and stocked up on food for the kitchen. We ate in most meals, but did do Roundtable Pizza and CJ Deli. Both were good, but pricey. Something that might bother others, but we liked: the Luau on top of the roof of the parking garage happens Sun-Thur from 5:30 to 7:45pm. It is loud and can easily be heard from our room. We liked it, and used it as the soundtrack to our stay when it was going and watch from our balcony on many occasions. We had no desire to pay to see it, but it was fun watching from above. If you are looking for a quite Hawaiian get away...HHV is not the place for you. If you are looking for a fun vacation with your kids, I can't think of a better place to go. We had a blast and will probably go back.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Termites...yes...and other things about which to complain too.We had booked a timeshare exchange over 8 months ago for this property--a 2 bedroom condo. Upon check-in, electricity was off in 3 of the rooms, and the smoke alarm was beeping (needed a battery). This was fixed within a couple hours. When getting ready for bed, we shut the drapes in the living room, opened the pull-out couch, and lo and behold, the room was literally swarming with flying insects, about 3/4 inch long, dropping their wings then falling everywhere. All surfaces were covered with insects! First call to front desk yielded a forward to housekeeping--we were told they were termites. Housekeeper arrived quickly and armed with vacuum and bug spray. Before she arrived, however, we had decided that we could not stay in this room! Even if it were fumigated, I didn't want my young children exposed to the spray. We're not talking a critter or two--they were hundreds, all over the room. We noticed pin-holes in the lampshades (which told us this wasn't new). The room needed serious attention. My call to the manager was blocked by a secretary (?) who wouldn't put me through.. Eventually after a few more calls, the Sunday night manager called back and agreed to come see the room and to look for another room for us. When she arrived and was shown all the dead bugs on the table (they had ceased flying by this time), she shrugged and said "I'm sorry". She got onto her computer at her desk, called us back, and offered us a couple options--none equal (or better) to our room. In fact, we were placed at a much lower level, which impeded our "ocean view" (that's a stretch even on the higher floor). We had to completely re-pack all our things, empty the fridge, and hike it all down--at bedtime for the kids (and in the middle of the Oscars, no less LOL). The second room had missing appliances (which we had in the first room), cracked mugs, a broken spring on the dishwasher. It was a mediocre condo (parallel to the first one)--only the barest essentials for one meal (needed to run dishwasher every meal--but not enough detergent), loose-handled skillets--no lids, cheap cooking utensils, etc. One of the 2 dryers on the floor was broken and not repaired the entire week.I suppose that it was certainly acceptable in a way, but we don't feel we got our value from our time-share ownership exchange. Our time-share is a "#1" rating--which means we usually get amazing condos wherever we go--usually the best available. And with a 8-month time-span, I wasn't expecting to get the "last minute" quality room (even the first room was a disappointment in that regard). And I was disappointed with the way management handled this--a shrugged "I'm sorry" was all that was offered. Maybe my disappointment would have been a little assuaged had we been given a token for our troubles--?meal coupons, ?fruit basket ?champagne ?whatever. But absolutely no validation of our experience was given--which tells me a lot about the management of this property. The pluses: staff were friendly (housekeepers, concierges, desk personnel, valets, surf instructors). Pools were nice.We stayed in the Lagoon Tower BTW.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: One bedroom unit - Lagoon Tower:Shocked & dismayed that the Hilton Grand Vacation Club showcases themselves so positively when the one bedroom we were assigned in the Lagoon Tower looks & feels dismal, is dirty, old and furnished with quite ugly and depressing gold furniture & rugs. Bedroom: couldn't be smaller with only 2 drawers for clothing. Furniture doesn't fit, if you have allergies, beware. The system must be old and blows unhealthy & musty air. Opinion: Unit & Hallways shouts that the company has no money to renovate and update. If this represents Hilton vacation clubs, we will not be pursing anymore Hilton properties. Hallways: Dismal and very depressing. From the reviews I get a sense that there are towers that are modern with new appointments. Where?Service: After only being here one day, the service has been good but if how I feel when I enter the hallway and unit is any indication that your environment effects how you feel, this is a perfect example. Run the other way when booking or ask if it's been renovated.THE OPPOSITE OF elegant, cozy, romantic and charming. It's huge, not intimate and crazy with conventions. NO beach as you would know it on the property...it's a make shift man made lagoon.I will see the manager today and try and get us switched and if it works out better, will write a better review.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We bought a vacation here as a "marketing package." We wanted to check out the facility before we committed to buying into their vacation club program. It might be fun for the young party crowd but for a middle aged bohemian don't even venture because there is no adventure!The facility was clean and pretty. The rooms are nicely decorated but lack the essential kitchen tools and hotel room amenities. When we arrived, our room smelled funny. The lamp next to the couch was broken, I called to report it and it was taken away but never returned to our room. The air conditioner sensor on the slider was broken off and no phone books...no biggie, just a pain to get taken care of. According to the "sales person" the people that purchase their program are given tons of fabulous extras...really? We never saw any of them; don't you think they would want to sell you by giving you the entire extent of what they have to offer?Tons of Asians were visiting while we were there so I can't say whether this is a standard, but according to the sales guy - this is the most popular property for the Japanese and they purchase for exclusive use and they are loyal patrons that pay top price.If you have kids and love to shop this is your place. But food options and restaurants are hard to find and be prepared to walk or take a taxi or bus to get to a "normal" grocery store; ABC Stores have most of the essentials but do not have good prices or good choices.Our room was facing the noisy, noisy city and no chance of changing to a partial or ocean view because that is a price upgrade and only if it is available, which it never is. Overall...buyers beware!Honolulu has 1.4 million people and the traffic is constant and congested; if you love this…have fun! If not, I would suggest visiting a different island; at least visit the North Shore it has the island quality everyone wants to experience, at least once.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: My husband and I stayed here for our one year wedding anniversary. We enjoyed our stay and the only reason I didn't give this hotel a better rating was the customer service. Our experience with the hotel staff ranged from very warm and helpful to outright rude. This is a timeshare property. I don't think all of the towers are timeshares though. Our first bad experience was with the Hilton Diamond Honors desk. They didn't tell us the nature of the property or the fact we were booking a timeshare property. Our Diamond Honors status didn't gain us any sort of upgrades. Nonetheless, we enjoyed our stay in the Lagoon Tower, and it was roomy and nice with a kitchen, dining room, and living room. We had an ocean view room that faced the Rainbow Tower. The view was awesome. This property is huge! It looked like 5 floors od the adjacent Tapa Tower was under renovation, so you could hear construction starting around 9 AM. We shopped at ABC Store for food and convenience items. We also ate at Tropics a few times, and it is right on the beach. Expect to pay $16 for a hamburger or a chicken ceasar salad, and $10 for a cocktail. We grabbed takeout from the pizza place and the deli on the property. Both were really good. The location is great in relation to shopping and restaurant options along Waikiki Beach and judging by the number fmilies there is great for families with and without kids. This is not a quiet, romantic, secluded resort. The grounds were well kept.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Lagoon Tower was where we were able to get a time share rental for 8 days. It was a good accommodated our family of 3 woman and 4 children. Our only disappointment is that their definition of a garden view was to look onto the back street or onto the roof of the adjoining hotel tower. Heard and watched the laua every night. Could not see the fireworks from our balcony either. Children were disappointed with the view. Great pools and activities for the children and adults. We recommend it, other than to ask about the view if you truly want a garden or ocean view.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Arrived in the Penthouse with my Father, Sister, Niece (10), Husband, Daughter (14), Son (8). We were super excited because it was spacious and beautiful. Then we went to bed and the noise was awful!!! The rooms were right next to a wall that is near the elevator and all night you could here the elevators vibrating. Three of us moved to the living room where the pull out bed was located. We pulled the bed out which was broken in half (which we reported and were told they fixed it, but they did not). The next morning we reported the problems and were very satisfied when they moved 3 of us to a two bedroom suite. The only unfortunate thing was we were now seperated from the rest of our family. The first night at the new suite we say a roach crawling on the kitchen wall and there was a loud noise in the wall that went on continuously day and night. The next day we saw 2 roaches on the wall. The last night which is right now we found a roach crawling in my sons bed then over the next hour we saw 5 more big roaches. It was so disgusting!!! This is my 4th visit to the Hilton Hawaiian Village, which has always been my favorite place to stay, BUT I WILL NEVER COME BACK. I cannot believe my Dad paid $20,000 to own this time share. It is so disgusting!!! I have pictures and if I can share them I will.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Great suite room. Good location for shops and all amenities.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We stayed here as part of a package to preview the time share property. Package included rental car, which we used to visit the north shore of Oahu and the windward side, as well as a certificate for $200 toward a later stay at a Hilton property. All the staff at this resort were very friendly. Our one bedroom suite with kitchen and washer/dryer had granite countertops, dual shower heads, but the furniture seemed heavy and dated. The unit overlooked the city and street traffic made it so noisy that we never used the balcony. The Grand Waikikian was the furthest from the beach of all the towers at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. The Pro Bowl was the next weekend and Waikiki and this hotel were probably even more crowded than usual as a result. We did not eat at any of the restaurants on site. The best thing about this hotel was the complimentary hospitality suite (not private) that we used at 4 pm on the day we checked out. We had gone to the beach on the north shore and were flying out that night on a red-eye. The hospitality suite gave us the opportunity to shower and change before going out to dinner. They stored our luggage and provided cold drinks. This was a big plus.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We stayed from January 19th through the 26th. Overall we were very happy with the hotel. We stayed in the Kalia Tower. The tower is about a five minute walk from the beach. The beach at the Hilton resort is probably one of the nicest in Waikiki. There was a pool in our tower, as well as many other pools on the resort. Our children loved the pool with the water slides. Our room had a full kitchen which we used quite a bit. We found a local grocery store about a block and a half from the resort. The groceries were decently priced - way better than the ABC stores. There was a washer and dryer on each floor. We found the hotel staff very friendly and the room very comfortable. The only complaint that I have is that the rates for the long distance were completely outrageous. They tried to charge us 86 dollars for three short phone calls to Canada. The manager did adjust this after we complained. We were told the best thing to do is to buy a phone card. Overall we would recommend this hotel to families.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We stayed in a 2 bedroom premier (ocean front) condo for 3 nights. We have never travelled to Oahu before because it is in the city. The condo was very nicely appointed and recently refurbished. I would stay here again if/when I return to Oahu. The laundry facilities are not inside the condo but located near the elevators - but they are free.The front desk staff and concierge personnel were very helpful and friendly. We bought a 4 day bus pass (www.thebus.org) from ABC stores for $25 and we got our money's worth. There is a circle island bus (the 52 and 55 route) that will take you to all points on the north shore. We went to the Bonzai pipeline one day and watched a surf competition. It takes about 2 hours to get to the Sunset Beach area of north shore but we enjoyed seeing the countryside and not having to worry about driving. We could hop on and off the bus along Waikiki and didn't have to carry the correct change for the bus so I would recommend getting the 4 day pass if you plan to be there for 2 or more days. The hilton hawaiian village put on a free fireworks show on Tuesday night which was a nice surprise. People on this island are very friendly and willing to help out with advice and information. The main reason for our trip to Oahu was to visit Pearl Harbor and the USS Arizona Memorial. We really enjoyed this part of our trip. We took the City bus to this location as well. It takes about an hour to get there from Hilton Hawaiian village and we arrived at 7 am in order to beat the crowds. Anyone who complains about the price of food or activities or the fact that there are alot of people here has obviously come here without doing their research. If you want a quiet island experience you should choose another island. Oahu is no more expensive than the other hawaiian islands.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: This resort pretty much sucks. Get to are room that was supposed to be ocean front looks between the next hotel and a very busy dock. Everything on the property is extremely over priced and pretty much total crap. The property is littered with shops and restaurants that all contain EXTREMELY over priced stuff and food that was not very good and not local. When asked if we could have food delivered to the room since we are staying in the time shares they responded with "That is trespassing for the delivery people to come on the property, it's not fair to the shops and restaurants on the property. Is it fair to screw every guest of the hotel to either go across the enormous complex to eat or be totally screwed at the restaurants on the property. I obviously expected this trip to be expensive and for things at and around the hotel but the hotel basically confines you with it's complicated paths that lead to random spots on the property. The whole place is just lame, no bars or anything really on the property, not even by the pool! Went to the luau, not authentic outfits, food wasn't very good and caters to mostly Asian people. The service sucked, food sucked, show sucked and all for $110 per person! $30,000 worth of people sitting on the ROOF where this is hosted. Loudly and clearly so all of the other guests including myself can hear it every night! Place totally sucks don't waste your time and money.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We go every year to this beautiful property and this time stayed in the newly built tower.The rooms are very modern and updated ,if you will,with heated toilets and great bedding.I am always surprised at how lacking the spa services are.The spa itself I guess is a separate company (Mandara}The waiting area downstairs is co-ed which I don't particularly like and The girl that was assigned to me looked shocked when I asked for a firm massage.I think she may have been new and very young for she forgot to massage my feet,which is unheard of.I get massages 3-4 times a month and everytime we travel, and I am surprised that such a nice resort does not have better spa facilities.The sauna and rest area is quite worn and small.The people working there were very nice but I think the facility is seriously in need of an update!As for the strike,it did not make that much of a difference in our overall experience.I still would recommend this lovely resort to everyone, just don't waste your $140.00 on the massages!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: I've stayed at the Grand Waikikan once and the Lagoon tower twice in the last year. There are 4 Towers in the "village". Grand Waikikan is the nicest and the newest. I recommend this Tower over the Coral, Kalia or Lagoon. If there is no availability at the Grand Waikikan then Lagoon Tower is my 2nd choice. Tip - you can watch the Hula show from your Lagoon Tower balcony.There are several pools and they are all small - kids galore so this isn't an intimate romantic property. The beach is public and it's fun to watch the surfers.IN the Kalia Tower As a Gold & higher level Hilton member you have free access to the 2nd level pool as well as the beautiful fitness center in the building. The Mandara spa on the 4th floor is a bit dated and it's a little odd to go to the steam and then have to jump in an elevator to have your service. I purchased a HIlton "timeshare" in Orlando in 2007 for the perks - like last minute travel for $80/nt with a 2nt minimum. NOte: i don't recommend timeshares to anyone who only gets 2-3 weeks vacation/yr. But attend a sales presentation and get the perks - why not?A 20 minute cab ride from the airport was $35 in Oct. 2010. My favorite restaurant in the village is the "Tropic Grill" which is beachside with tiki torches and great tropical drinks.As a statesider, I don't vote this trip as a "shopping trip" but tons of Asians come just for that purpose and load up the elevators with their finds of the day. If you like Sushi, Waikiki has some wonderful little sushi places within walking distance. You probably don't need a car - there are shuttles, buses etc.. Parking in the village costs $25/day.It's a lovely walk thru the park to the happenin' Waikiki area bars, restaurants etc.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We spent a week at the timeshare portion of the resort. On arrival we were dropped off at the onsite bus/cab drop-off parking area. We were not familiar with the resort (it includes both a regular hotel as well as a timeshare - a total of 7 high rises) and as there was no one to ask, we followed the signs to check-in (quite a hike with all our luggage). Unfortunately the signs only pointed to the hotel checkin, not the timeshare component. As such we were directed to the timeshare checkin. After another long hike across the property with all our luggage we arrived at the timeshare, only to be told that we were at the wrong timshare building (each does its own checkin) and would need to go to our actual building to check in. After seeing the look on my face the lady behind the counter said that she would check us in and then called a bellhop with a golf cart to take us to our proper building. There should be explicit signs for the timeshare checkins!The first 3 days everything was fine - all up to Hilton standards. We were woken around 6 am on the 4th day by shouting / chanting / horns, etc and thought that it must be some college kids. When this did not stop we looked out the window (all our windows were shut but we could still hear the yelling through them) to see massive picket lines - all 1500 of the hotel emplyees were on strike for 5 days! Management tried to fill in for the striking employees with some success. Most of the activities / restaurants / bars etc were shut down as the hotel attempted to get outside staff to fill in. Guests had to make their own beds, change their own sheets and towels, etc. By the end of the 3rd day Hilton had managed to get outside housekeeing staff in though the hotel services including restaurant and bar services were still extremely liimited (there was no valet, room service, on-site luau etc). The most annoying thing was the 24 hour chanting / singing / bull horns, etc outside our building by the picketing strikers who obstructed all access to the resort by vehicle, letting in only a few vechicles at a time and then blocking the roadways again resutling in numerous delays. This chanting / shouting / horns kept waking us up throughout the nights as our unit faced right onto the road where the pickets were.Hilton knew that the employees were in a strike position but we were not made aware of it by any communication! As well, it was intimidating to walk to the hotel through the picket lines (and there were picket lines at all hotel accesses, even the one that went onto Waikiki beach).

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Stayed here for two weeks in September. Loved it. Staff were wonderful. The resort was perfect. Very clean. Bit expensive but it is Honolulu and a Hilton. Plenty of other places to eat etc. We like to walk but there is plenty of trolleys come to the Hilton if you dont want to drive. We used it a few times. Fantastic holiday and cant wait to go back.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: This is for the HGV not the actual hotel. We stay at this place every year. The rooms are always updated. Comfy beds. Great pressure in the shower. The location is at the end of Waikiki, close enough to walk but far enough away from the hustle and bustle. There are so many restuarants and bars on the property. You can learn how to surf or stand up paddle board right out front. Or snorkle and just swim. The break out front of the hotel is perfect for long or short rides. The only downside of the resort is that the prices can be a little expensive for eating and drinking. Not too much of a variety in pricing. I saw a spaghetti with marinara dish that was almost $25. Seriously.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: The Hilton Hawaiian Village was an awesome place to stay. Some of the big positives were it's location relative to the beach. As in it's right on the beach itself. Not only that but the way it's positioned it seems that only the guests from the hotel use it (though there are no barriers). There are plenty of restaurants on site and lots of activities, such as pools, water activities, night festivals and much much more. Would highly recommend this resort to anyone.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: This place was an end all be all hotel. You had everything you could ask for on site and rarely did we have to leave the "compound". I would highly suggest it for families as well since they've got something for everyone!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We stayed there before the date listedStaff so friendly there made me feel so welcomed Very cleanGreat PoolSome rooms are old but very clean could use an update but the room we had was modernGreat baby sitting serviceGreat foodBig rooms

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Spent 7 days in the Kalia Tower; toured the island for 2 days, surfed one, the 'boys' had an enjoyable round of golf and went snorkling in Hanuama Bay. Had some concessions via Virgin Holidays which you could credit in a few restaurants which were mostly a bit costly. The rooms were clean, spacious with VERY comfortable beds. The coast at the hotel was fabulous. Had a treat when visiting some of the 'Lost' locations at the north of island. Next to Sunset Beach was such a location which was navigated though a residential public pathway and surrounded by private property. Emerging from the pathway we came directly onto the beach (not suitable for swimming) to find turtles, one after the other, making their way from the water's edge up the beach - yes Mastercard somethings are priceless and this one didn't cost a penny! Touring the island was fabulous including a trip to Kualoa Range - stunning scenary used as locations in many films. Hanuama Bay is well worth a visit for those who like snorkling or just admiring the scenery. You can hire snorkling equipment there, get showered, changing rooms or sit under the shade of a tree and have a picnic. The concierge at the Hilton gave super advise and ideas for the week - thanks!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We researched several of the Waikiki hotels and booked this one. We had a general idea of what to expect, and our stay could not have been better. The staff was friendly and went above & beyond the call of duty on occasion to help us. The grounds are beautiful, lush and maintained to perfection. Shopping was fun. There are nit-picking expenses (umbrellas, etc.), but we knew about those and avoided them. The sales pitch for a time-share lasted all of 10 seconds when we politely told them we weren't interested - no other pitches. If you're young and looking for excitement, this is not the place for you - the college kids are elsewhere. The pools are average at best, but who comes to Waikiki to swim in a hotel pool? The Hilton may not represent the "real" Hawaii, but no other hotel on Waikiki does (except perhaps the Halekulani). To fully experience Hawaii, you need to hit the other islands. On Oahu, the drive along Hwy 72 (Waimanalo Beach) is as beautiful as any, and is a half-day at most. Aloha!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Stayed 7 nights-2 bedroom Condo Unit -GRAND WAIKIKIAN TOWER (7 TOTAL BUILDINGS ON THE PROPERTY). Excellent facility with beautiful condo units, well equipped with oversized bedrooms and living room/dining area. 3 Flat Screen TV's and each Bathroom had a LARGE walkin Shower! This Hilton facility has everything you need within easy walking distance, including two ABC Stores (Akin to 7/11). If the ABC store was not enough...major shopping mall with Market, only 1/2 mile away! If you are traveling with kids, there is no place else you need to visit while in Oahu. Pools, Pools with slides, lagoon and beaches. Perfect setting! Parking was easy, though expensive. Staff was accomodating and helpful. One problem...this is a time share building, still actively selling units so there is a constant state of people arriving, touring and leaving! Aside from that, it did not detract from our stay! My only complaint is the extremely HIGH prices for eating in any of the Hilton Hotel restuarants. Spent $120.00 for breakfast for 4 adults and two kids, both under the age of 4! To make matters worse..the food was only HoHum! No bargains here! Eat in your Condo Unit!!!!!!!! All in all, a wonderful place to spend a week and we would do it again but would avoid eating in the restuarants.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Traveled date: June 27 to July 3/2010.This review is only applicable for Lagoon Tower . We stayed in 1-bedroom unit facing west – view of Ilikai, Paradise Pool and Marina. We stayed in Rm 1168, did this through timeshare with Hilton Grand Vacation. From our side of the building, we could not see the Friday night fireworks. You need to face the lagoon side if that’s important for you. The location is not right on Waikiki beach. You are just to the west of Fort DeRussy so it’s about 20 min walk to Waikiki or you would want to take the trolley.In our unit, we had a pull out sofa and a separate bedroom (relatively small). Only one bathroom to share. Full kitchen, but a bit small. Lanai was a good size and had a full ocean view. Since we were just above Paradise Pool, it is a bit noisy when the lanai door is open. We weren’t on the lanai too often so we didn’t mind this. The unit may have been updated in the past 5 years since it had nice décor. The bathroom fixtures (toilet, bathtub/shower) seem to be older. We had a leak in the toilet water tank which was fixed the next day for us. The room could have used more storage/closets as we could not store our 3 pieces of luggage into the closet. We had free wifi from our room and had no problems accessing it.Location was perfect for families. We are a family of 4 with 2 boys (aged 5 and 8). Paradise Pool has 2 waterslides, 2 separate pool areas and 2 hot tubs. My kids loved it. We were there everyday in the morning. Pool opens 8:30, but slides open 10:30 (and slides close at 5). NOTE: Kids must wear flotation device if they are shorter than a specific height (check the hotel website for the exact height). They sell cheap flotation vests or wings (at the pool/towel stand), but they seem pretty flimsy. I would recommend that you bring your own life vest if you have small kids. You can always use them on the beach and lagoon. We saw lots of kids line up for slides and then get turned away at the top because they did not have flotation devices. We felt very safe (ie. with our valuables and not having to watch our kids like a hawk) at Paradise pool as there are a number of security staff checking for room cards at the entrances as well as card operated gates. Towels were given out near the pool which you can keep and use at the beach, etc.We found that the pool got busier as the day went on. Due to the time change, we were up early anyways. We went down to the pool around 9am and were able to find lounge chairs. Since the Paradise pool is to the west of Lagoon tower, the pool and lots of chairs are in the shade in the morning. We would spend the morning at Paradise pool, go up to our unit for lunch, then went to the lagoon/beach in the afternoon. We found this really easy since our unit was just an elevator ride away. There are not any close restaurants to Lagoon pool (ie. no concession stands or sit down restaurants) unless you walk to the other side of the lagoon or go to the Rainbow Bazaar. Go to the hotel website for a full listing of restaurants.We also tried going to Super Pool. This pool is closer to food options, but it doesn’t have any slides/features. There are more chairs around this pool compared to Paradise Pool and this area gets more sun.NOTE: No pool toys are allowed in any of the pools. We noticed attendants enforcing this rigorously. Even throwing a small floating football is not allowed. You can do this at the beach or lagoon.The lagoon is nice if you want a calm place to swim and rent recreation items (very expensive). They even rent sand toys. I suggest you just buy your own at ABC or at any of the tower convenience stores and keep it for your trip. You might also want to buy a beach umbrella so you don’t have to rent one. There is no shade in the lagoon or beach areas. Beach is lovely, but has some rocks/coral in the water. The beach is quite calm. NOTE: Box jelly fish alerts may appear 8-10 days after full moon. You can check the Hawaii beach safety website to see the exact warnings each morning. They can’t really predict it, so if you can schedule your vacation around this time if you can. We noticed signs on the beach re: jelly fish even when the warning was no longer active on the website. Even when you can’t swim at the beach, there’s still the lagoon and pools. Lots of options… so no worries.For food, there are many restaurants within the village. Cheap options that we found include ABC (salads, sushi, cold noodles, sandwiches, Spam musubi, drinks), Japanese noodle restaurant in Rainbow Bazaar and CJ’s in Rainbow Bazaar had deli sandwiches, burgers, etc. These were pretty good. We went to one resort-owned restaurant, Tropics, for lunch. We were very disappointed by the food (burger was plain and dry) and was very expensive.Since the location is 10 min. walk to Ala Moana Centre, we went there twice for groceries and dinner. There is a Foodland in there for groceries and deli. We tried these cheap meal options at Ala Moana Centre: Shirokiya (mostly Japanese food); food fair; and an eating area outside of Sears auto centre that had Zippy’s Hawaiian food, Japanese food, bakery, donuts/muffins and Vietnamese noodles/sandwiches. Since it is a bit of a walk with groceries, we brought our backpack and carry-on bag on wheels to the centre. This was really helpful.Hilton is a great place as there is so much to do (or not do) and so many options. We didn’t end up enrolling our kids in Camp Penguin but this would be a good option if the adults wanted to do something on our own (eg. spa treatment or scuba diving). We really loved our week here. It was paradise. My 5-year old son said “I want to stay here forever!”

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Stayed in Kalia Tower 1Br for a week. The rooms are very nice, clean, comfortable king bed in the bedroom and the kids did fine on a pull-out sofa in the living room. The tower is not that far from the pools and beach, and very close to the ABC store and restaurants in the marketplace. It is also right across the street from Wailana Coffee House which was good and cheap for breakfast/lunch. Best parts: - wide beach in front of the hotel, with a reef just in front for easy snorkeling; - Paradise Pool slides for kids; -beatifull hotel grounds with parrots, flamingos, penguins, koi fish, turtles. Also free Wi-Fi and gym usage for those staying in timeshare units. Worst: - expensive food/drinks in most restaurants onsite (although ABC Store is a reasonable option; -towel stands are only open 8-4:30 or 5pm so you have to save towels for evening swims. Overall it was a good choice for staying in a true resort with kids in Waikiki.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: I purchased a 1 bedroom Condo fpr my Honeymoon in 2006 for $23,000.00 and was told if i ever wanted to sell Hilton would be right at my side to help me get top dollar for the resale. I recently contacted Hilton abouty a possible resale and they stated that the market was soft and they could only offer me $8,000.00 to $9,000.00. and that the proprerty was not worth anymore than that. How can a property even in these bad times lose $14,000.00? I believe once Hilton has you on the line they have you and if you want out? You lose. Donny Segerstrom

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: After owning our 2 bedroom unit in the Lagoon Tower for 10 years you can't have any better timeshare than one that is up close looking at the ocean right on Waikiki Beach AND at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. However, you can get screwed over (we had that happen to us twice).But if you don't do your homework each year and understand what exactly you purchased and how to reserve another unit for the next years reservation. Learn the layout of each floor. We had room 1566 one year with a full ocean view WOW, then Rm.1565 another year w/ ocean view & a 'lock out' another (2 hotel hotel rooms put together that connect and were completely unsatisfied w/ it's hotel layout). A 2 bedroom can feel like a luxury apartment here...and a 'lock out' 2 bedroom which is 2 hotel rooms connected even w/ a kitchenette feels exactly like that...2 hotel rooms connected.When setting up and making your reservations, make sure you have the view you paid for and you don't get stuck w/ a 'lock out' unit that is just a glorified hotel room. Then check back over the course of the months pending your arrival and confirm your room details. Then when you get within days of arriving confirm again and make sure you get exactly what you want. Cover all your angles so as not to be disapppointed...because if handled correctly, it's a magnificient place to be!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We were recommendend by a friend who received a great deal for a self contained 3 bedroom apartment in the Lagoon Tower (Hilton Hawaiin Village) After being on a cruise with 2 teenagers in the one cabin this seemed ideal. We booked from Australia over the phone and agreed to the usual time-share spiel (1/2 day tour etc). In return for our time we received 60% off the price plus free car rental, vouchers etc.Of course it was all too good to be true. Upon checking in we were booked into a normal hotel room ( 2 queen beds) in a completely different tower (the furtherest away from the pool, beach etc). When we questioned the marketing dept who had originally booked us they just shrugged their shoulders and said it was Japanese Golden Week so everything was fully booked - bad luck.The treatment we received from staff at this hotel was rude and un-cooperative to say the least. We even asked if we could get a fold out bed so our daughter and son werent sleeping together. Their response was no problem that will be $30 per night. Then to top things off the marketing girl rang the next morning to take us on the time share tour. It was laughable.The Hilton chain has left a sour taste in our mouth so I would not recommend this place to anyone. Everything has a price and there is absolutely no service.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Hilton Hawaiian Village is kinda like going to Disneyland....clean, pretty, crowded & pricey. We stayed at the Grand Vacations Club for 4 nights & the rooms were very nice, not too large but Ok & we had a nice view of the city. We then stayed in the Hilton Hawaiian Village hotel (the Ali'i Tower) & had a very nice ocean view.PROS: Spotless, nice pools, convienent location, excellent service, free internet access at the Grand Vacation Club, in room coffee maker, decent food, beautiful grounds, penguins(!!), right on the beach with a small lagoon, the Ali'i tower has its own smaller pool with access limited to that tower onlyCONS: pools are unheated, charge for EVERYTHING...ie: internet access at the hotel & the most outrageous charge of all? If you want 2 chairs & an umbrella at the beach (& the hotel is ON the beach), it will cost $90.00 per day....YES NINETY DOLLARS!!!!....through the hotel!!!!, the included continental breakfast for elite status members was very limited,

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We're owners so we were upgraded to a very nice, clean, 2 balcony suite, with better view than what we had originally reserved (the mattresses were too soft. It's like a mini city, where the resort is huge, nicely landscaped, but you can ignore the upscale stores if you want to. There are ABC stores where you can buy groceries if you want to cook in the kitchen, but the foodstores are close by. Restaurants and lower price stores are available right outside the resort.The Italian restaurant on the premises had a great Mom's Day dinner with wine pairing. The wines were not fantastic but the overall experience was fun. We enjoyed our stay there, but we rented a car, parking is $24/day, and traveled all around the island.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We were in Honolulu to begin a cruise and decided to stay at the Kalia Tower as we are Hilton Grand Vacation Club members. After a torturous cab ride from the airport (rush hour traffic and a road closure) we arrived at the Hilton Hawaiian Village and a beautiful one bedroom condo overlooking the Pacific. As we settled in, we soon forgot about the cab ride. The shops, restaurants, and other amenities of the Hilton Hawaiian Village make it a great place to stay. When we left on our cruise, we wished we had made our resrvation for more than just four nights.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: This hotel is the one all the other tourists wish they were staying at! It's a high-end place to shop, with four hotel towers, four pools (including the biggest lagoon in Oahu). the Luau was gorgeous, staff is helpful. Go have breakfast across the road at wallani cafe, superb and seriously cheap! loved the hilton!Best things to do: parasail for $25, snorkel at Hanauma bay $15, walk along waikiki, Luau and get on a party boat!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We wanted a quiet hotel near the action and this was perfect. Stayed Christmas and left New Years so peak season and the resort was really busy. However, it is spacious enough so that you can find places to escape other people! We had a room high up in one of the towers with a partial ocean view and the room was silent. Although, if we had a resort facing room in another one of the buildings it might have been much louder. Room was spacious with a nice balcony and huge bathroom. The hotel is on a wide stretch of beach just out of Honolulu so there is always room to put a towel down and enjoy the sun. It is about a 10 minute walk into town and so very easy to escape the higher prices of the resort restaurants. The shopping mall is an easy 20 minute walk and so we found that we didn't need a car.Perfect resort hotel in beautiful part of the world. Looking forward to returning soon...

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: My husband whom is a Marine went to a conference and I went along with him. We decieded to stay there because of the pictures that showed the Hilton as beautiful and the location with views. I was amazed at how beautiful everything was when we checked in....thought wow this will be a great vacation. Went up to our room 1614 in the Rainbow Tower :(.......and was very dissapointed at it. Now the view was beautiful and amazing. They had us in the Tapa Tower but, we wanted to up grade to a ocean view.....maybe we should of stayed in the Tapa.Room----needs some updating that is for sure. The bathroom has no fan, mold in ceiling, back of toilet had a crack in it, plug in the wall was not even screwed in the wall.....and couldnt adjust the shower head. The bathroom smelled for the entire week. There we stains on the wallpaper, the bottom drawer in the dresser had to be lifted up to be shut. I had to call down and ask for the cleaning lady to change our sheets on day 4......I mean you could clearly see that they needed to be changed but, I had to call.....did not vacuum the entire time either.The grounds were beautiful and there was alot to do. Between the pools, shops, beach...fish, birds, peguins and flamingos. We did have a view of the Luau for 5 nights which was nice. :)It was very pricey to eat there. We did eat at Noodles a Japanese little quick and cheap eatery. We had the pizza to it was very good. $10 for a mixed drink at the pool & had to wait for 30 min for my change....she didnt get a tip.The beach chairs were $15.71 to be exact.........it was worth it to me for one day of not getting sand blast on a beach towel. My husband rented a paddle board and used it in the Lagoon which was a very nice place to sit and swim. We had a problem parking a few nights cause of weddings or the prom they had there but, other wise the parking garage was good.Everyone was super nice including the person whom we complained to on the day we checked out.....(we did tell them about it before but, they did nothing). That lady told us that they lure you in with all the stuff but, not everything is grand. Wish I new that before hand.I would stay there again...........but, not in that tower.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We (DH and 13 yo) just returned from staying at HHV in the Kalia Tower (room #1736). The 1 bedroom suite with 2 queen beds , full kitchen was nice and clean. There was also a sofa sleeper in the living room. The odd numbers are ocean view rooms and the even numbers are mountain/city view rooms. I asked for an upgrade to an ocean view room but they couldn’t accommodate me. The mountain/city view is nice but nothing like waking up to an ocean view. We didn’t cook in the units but we made sandwiches. HHV units feel like hotel living with a full kitchen versus more of a condo living like we’ve been accustomed to with timeshare exchanges. We wish there was a BBQ grill area on the property. There are public grills at a little park next to the hotel. But we had everything needed in the room itself. A lot of people complain of this Tower being so far away from the beach and pools, but we didn’t find it to be a problem. It was perfectly located for us since we spent a lot of our time off property. There isn’t a washer/dryer in the units, but there is a laundry room down the hall that had 2 apartment size washers and dryers. Only one of the dryers ‘worked’ and after an hour of drying, I removed our clothes and let them air dry in the room because they were still very damp. The washers did not spin well and left the clothes very WET. I would have been willing to pay to use a full size properly working washer and dryer. I didn’t take my laptop because previous reviews said that we would be charged for internet access. But when I checked in, the receptionist was going to give me the code to get internet access. She also said that we were able to use the fitness center as well. So it looks like only timeshare visitors have free internet access and fitness center usage.This is a large resort, so you should view a map and try to familiarize yourself with the layout of the resort. There are plenty of small pools on the property and the pool in our tower was the least crowded pool. As big as this property is, there should be at least one ‘adult only’ pool or one pool that’s 6 feet. We only visited the Paradise pool and the pool in the Kalia Tower. We really couldn’t enjoy the Paradise pool because they were extremely crowded and this was NOT during their most busiest time. We tried to enjoy the hot tub, that had a sign posted ‘max 9 people’, it was easily 20 people in there at one time. Parents were letting their kids JUMP in with their floaters. I spent most of my time ‘sun bathing’ at the pool while the rest of the family was in the pool or hot tub. We didn’t have a big problem finding chairs there. The only activity we participated in was the Lei making that cost $10 each. It was a nice! We also rented the aqua cycles at the Lagoon for $21 for 30 minutes. That was fun!There are many high end stores (Louis Vuitton, etc) on the property and within walking distance. We often visited the ABC store on the property. From reading previous reviews, we were already prepared to eat off property but ate at one property restaurant on the day of the fireworks. It was perfect because we got on the waiting list at the Tropics Bar & Grill around 6:45p; our table became available right as the firework show started. We were seated on their outdoor patio and were able to see the fireworks! We had several meals at Wailana Coffee House that is directly across the street from HHV. Highly recommended, especially for their pineapple pancakes with coconut syrup!! We also tried Due Divino restaurant that is around the corner from Wailana. I would not recommend this place. There is a nice lady standing in front of HHV every day handing out menus with a 10% coupon. I don’t mind eating at ‘hole in the wall’ type of places if the food is good. But this place sucks! I think it is suppose to be an Italian restaurant, but we went for breakfast. The waitress couldn’t tell me what the ‘black swirls’ were in my scrambled eggs. The lady who was passing out the coupons on the corner came in the restaurant serving customers without ever washing her hands. Then she cupped the rim of my glass to refill my drink with her bare hands. I was ready to walk out at that point.We rented a car for a few days from the airport on the day we arrived and dropped it off at the Hyatt location, which is walking distance to HHV. Of course we did not use the highly priced parking facility at HHV but opt to park at the public parking lot between HHV and the Marina. It’s a 24 hour limit parking lot at .25 cents an hour!! That saved us quite a bit of money! We never had a problem finding a spot either. We used Star Taxi to return to the airport on the day of departure. It cost $28 for 3 people with luggage.We walked to Kalalkaua Ave , either the street path or beach path, just about every day that we didn’t have a car. There are MANY stores and restaurants along this strip. We also took a scenic ride on the ‘pink line’ Trolley which drop off at HHV. The ‘pink line’ took us through Waikiki and to Ala Moana shopping center. During the few days we rented a car, we visited Pearl Harbor, Dole Plantation and the North Shore (twice). We went to the North Shore both ways. We tried to go to Hanauma Bay beach to snorkel but by the time we got there (9:30a), it was full and they weren’t letting anyone in. So we headed up to the North Shore. Going to the North Shore from this way, you can really enjoy the beautiful ocean scenic route. We stopped along the way and took a lot of pictures. We did a little shopping in the Haleiwa Historic area and had lunch at Giovonni Shrimp truck.Overall, we had a great time and can’t wait to go back to Hawaii.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We stayed in the Waikikian Tower which is the time share tower. We do not own the time share and have NO desire to own one. We were only asked once by the concierge to attend a meeting. The tower is so beautiful, the room modern and decorated nicely. Very comfortable. The hotel is huge so to get to the main area, the Tapa Tower, where the bus pick ups are we had to hike through the parking garage, down and elevator...it was a long way. The pools were packed, not a chair to be had. MANY families from other countries with many little kids. But we enjoyed the hotel. I did not have any time to explore but I would return here. The price was high compared to our hotel in Maui but I think it was worth it. Just bring your hiking shoes.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We stayed for 7nights at the Lagoon Tower, 2bedroom 2bath with equipped kitchen.The room - roomy and clean for the price with 2 balconies, by no means top notch, but that's what Hilton is nice but not the best.The resort - in my opinion, the best in Waikiki. The pool/slides right outside of Lagoon Tower, the lagoon, the superpool and the beach all sum up to be the most spacious of all hotels in Waikiki, and it's not even close. So even when it's busy, Hilton absorbs the crowd well.The food - only ate in the resort once for lunch at The Tropics Bar & Beach Café, Hilton is not known for it's food.The shopping - although there are plenty of shops within the resort, the main shopping is offered on the proper Waikiki strip or at Ala Moana mall.All in all, a very pleasant stay for the price with lots to do for my kids.Few recommendations: the beach umbrella and chairs are not free at beach, I believe Umbrella is $30 and chairs are $25 per day. I recommend going to Don Quijote and purchasing rather than renting if you are there for a week with family. If you have rental car, there might be better offerings than Don Quijote.If you are planning to venture out to other beaches within the island, get fresh beach towels the night before and take them on your trip, just make sure to bring them back.Some musts if you have kids: Hanauma Bay, the very best snorkeling spot for families, this place enlightened my kid in terms of snorkeling and variety of fish offered for viewing.Waimea Bay Beach, rent a boogie board at the local surf shop if you don't have one, relatively safe for kids to experience boogie boarding right on the shore. Don't think you know what Hawaiian waves are after spending a week at Waikiki.Laniakea Beach, check out the turtles sunbathing, not the easiest place to find with no signs but if you drive from Waimea Bay Beach toward the Haleiwa Proper, it will be on the way, look for cars parked on both sides of the road.Saturday Farmer's Market at Kapiolani Community College, place not only to pick up fresh local produce/fruits but also to try various local cruisine.Sunset Dinner - if you can afford it, Orchid's at Halekulani, book reservation with outside seating next to House without a Key where they have live music and hula dancing[check for schedule although they have on most nights], where else can you have fine dining, outdoor seating with sunset, live music and hula dancing? food is secondary.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We go to Hawaii every year or so and like to start our stay on Oahu. This year I took my parents, wife, and kids and we all stayed at the HHV Lagoon tower. The 2BR suite was spacious and comfortable with a great layout for a '3 generations' vacation. Having the services of the Hilton was very convenient - room service, valet parking, etc. One day we sent our kids to the Camp Penguin (which they loved) and got an adult day to ourselves. We also liked having the dining and shopping options of the village nearby for those days we just stayed at the hotel to enjoy the beach and pools.The location is great because you have Waikiki beach - warm and calm - outside your door. Ala Moana's shopping/dining is walkable in one direction while the Waikiki restaurants (e.g Keo's) are walkable in the other. And most of Oahu (Hanauma Bay, Portlock, Kaimuki, the Pali, downtown, etc) is a short drive away.In short, there is no place on Oahu I'd rather stay with a family.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Wow where to start?? from the shows,food or wonderful view..all can say is thank you for a time well spent...i came back home well relaxed, and just in aww of all the beauty that we exsperianced there..thanks!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: I traveled to Waikiki with my daughter and her family, which included my 18, 14 and 4 year old grandchildren. We were in the Lagoon tower in an oceanfront 2-bedroom unit. The rooms were spacious, updated and very clean. The view from the living, dining, kitchen and two patios was breathtaking. We overlooked the lagoon and the ocean, with a wide, expansive view. The staff was friendly and very accommodating. The property is absolutely beautiful. We enjoyed walking around, shopping, visiting the penguins, pink flamingos and the birds. We also enjoyed our daily visits to the pools, spending time on the lagoon beach and the Paradise Pool most of the time. On my departure day I enjoyed the peace and quiet of the pool at the Kalia Tower just outside of the Mandara Spa.The departure lounge was a huge plus since our flight had an evening departure. It gave us a bonus day of enjoyment at the resort and a great place to store a change of clothes, shower and change.Shopping for the basics was convenient in the Lagoon Tower shop and ABC Market. Both offer gifts with purchase amounts, so make sure to get your stamp card or save your receipts. If you can make it off-property to the Foodland at Ala Moana, you will get a better price.We rented a car for 3 days and toured the island visiting Pearl Harbor, Polynesian Cultural Center, Dole Plantation, Huanama Bay, North Shore (a couple of times), and climbed Diamond Head.I can't wait to return! Aloha

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Imagine waking up, and starting your day with a big cup of coffee on the spacious belcony overlooking the deep pacific ocean, and see whales breaching out of the water in their popular feeding grounds. WOW! Service was great, and accomadations not lacking by any means. It's a little spendy on the Hilton grounds, but its HAWAII! The five star rooms will make you wanna come back again this year!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: My wife and I stayed here for the first time. we have visited hawaii several times, and stayed closer to the main area around the International Markety Place.The rooms were great, very clean, as was the entire resort. You are staying at a hilton so you will be paying a little more, but you don't have to eat here, there are tons of other eating places close by.The pools were great, and the beach is right there, what else could you ever need.We are going back next year this time with our kids, as this resort is perfect for families.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: So we had a room booked at the DoubleTree across the street for $99 a night. When we arrived we were told that there was no upgrades available even though I am a diamond member and was told earlier in the week that one would be available. A couple more things happened (which included a SWAT team, cockroaches and a horrible view) so we decided to check out of the DoubleTree and pay the $189 a night at the Hilton Grad Vacation Club. When we arrived I realized that the room I booked was a studio room in the Lagoon Tower. The room was basically the same (non-upgraded) room at the DoubleTree. The only difference was the overall atmosphere of this hotel. This hotel is right on the water and it has all the conveniences that we desired. The room had a kitchenette but we never used it since we found a cockroach on the counter when we walked in. The pool and lagoon at this hotel were great and the VIP lounge was nice for breakfast. I found out later that next door is the Ilikai (?) and it has full condos for less of a price than I paid at the Hilton. I figured I could of booked a room there and had all the same conveniences that the Hilton offers. Probably won't come back here, especially since the Hilton on the Big Island blows this one out of the water!!!!! If you are using your HHonors points, go to the Big Island!!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Reviews on tripadvisor about this place is quite accurate. Hotel resort overall is very well maintain especially for it's size. The rooms are clean, but a bit dated and worn. Everything in the resort, like restaurants and stores are more expensive than outside the resort, except for the ABC store and a couple of others. The Ala Moana Shopping Center is only a 15-20 minute walk from the resort. There's a bunch of very nice shops and a huge food court, with some great eats. Duke's Lagoon was great for the little kids to snorkel and see some fish. It is a few degrees colder than the ocean, but not all that bad. The beach was fun. There are some areas where the beach is quite rocky but there is a place close to the Port Hilton pier where the sand is very nice. Snorkeling was alright. It's not Belize, but for Waikiki beach Hawaii, it was quite nice. A nice variety of fish were seen. Pools were great for the most part. Superpool was fun for the kids.
