The Paradise pool is heated, so the first several days it was very nice. Then the furnace broke. The water became quite chilly, but not unbearable. Overall, we had a great time. It was just a little too busy, being that it was Honolulu. We prefer the relaxing atmosphere of Hilton @ Waikoloa. But the HHV resort was lots of fun.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: My husband and I have stayed at the Hawaiian Hilton Village on 2 separate occasions. We live here in Hawaii and both of our stays were because of a function that we attend yearly in one of the ballrooms. The first time we stayed, we were in the Rainbow Tower and it was fantastic! We had an ocean front/ Diamondhead view. The room was up-to-date and full of upgrades that you would expect at this price range. Downside - we could hear everyone leave their rooms in the morning because the doors slam extremely loudly. Otherwise, very happy. However, for our second stay, they put us in the Tapa Tower and it was not great. The room was out-dated and dark. Our view was all of the surrounding towers and the street below - I think this is considered 'resort view'. The only good thing about this room was the bed (so comfortable). Other reviews are right about the restaurants, they are very expensive for a family to eat in for every meal. If you are willing to cross the street, there are much cheaper restaurant options outside of the resort boundaries.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We traded in our HGV points to stay at the Lagoon tower. I loved how big the village was and you could basically not leave the hotel as it had everything there. It was right next to the beach and a few block swalk to the main shopping area of Waikiki. The room was a large size but a bit dated. One of the windows was broken and some areas were showing its age. Staff were friendly but they really encouraged you into viewing the new tower. I loved Hawaii and can't wait for my next vacation there! Tips - Avoid renting a DVD from the machine on the second floor! The DVD was scratched and could not be watched. If you get a high floor facing the main pool you can watch the Luau on the top of the parking garage.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: The rooms are really clean and nice, i got the seaview and it's fabulous to chill and unwind near the balcony! I got a decent promotion package as well! Fantastic concierge service too!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We stayed here in January with our 2 little girls ages 3 & 5. We had a blast. The room was more than accommodating for us with children. There was so much to do and see on the grounds alone, we never had to leave the hotel once. We can't wait to go back again and experience more of the Hilton and the Rainbow Tower. I don't understand how this hotel was rated a 3.5 star. In my experience it should be at the least a 4.5 star.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: My sister, daughter and I stayed at this resort for 10 days in mid January 2010. We were off to a good start when after a small wait for our room to become available, we were shown to a well equipped guest waiting area in which we could shower, store our belongings, have a fresh muffin and coffee and relax after a 10 hr flight! Our 1 bed suite was on the 7th floor of the lagoon tower-and it was lovely! We enjoyed the clean huge kitchen, dining area - well equipped with a bigger plasma than we have at home! The view was stunning over the lagoon and out to the Pacific and everything you expect from a 4star room was there-comfortable beds, good shower water pressure, good black-out curtains, good soundproof door onto the hall (or maybe the other guests were just quiet and thoughtful?) under-utilised laundry available night and day and obliging staff.There was somthing for everyone at the HHV, my daughter enjoyed the kids club-the activities and excursions were really fun, and the ratio of carers to children was good. The water canoes and paddleboats on the lagoon were fun(a little pricey though) the water slide pool was great (and heated too). We also did the submarine trip, fireworks and watched the various animal feedings! For adults, the 10 minute walk to the Ala Moana shopping centre was really convenient, and the trolley buses at the front of the resort made it great for touring further afield. To me, I think we snagged the best deal and best complex on the strip-we really didn't want to leave!!!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Our stay was perfect in every way. We were in lagoon tower 2 bedroom oceanfront unit. We own 1 week every other year and this was our second stay. We are very happy with quality of the accomodations as well service. Village itself is fantacy world! Can't wait to go again!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: The first "Garden View" room offered to us was a corner room looking out on the roof of the hotel entrance. We refused to accept it and were transferred to another room with a view of the pool/marina/street. We were a group of five, including my parents and our 3 yr old son, and had the 2 bedroom unit. In two weeks we didn't leave the resort more than a dozen times, they have everything you need. The Lagoon tower pool with waterslides is great, pool staff were super, truly friendly and great with kids. The age group around the pool/slides was from 1-80, mostly families. We had no difficulties getting chairs around the pool no matter when we showed up, presumably as we were there during the pre-Christmas lull. The saltwater lagoon is beautiful but colder than the ocean so we didn't spend much time in it. Went to Wal-Mart & bought snorkeling gear and spent several mornings snorkeling around the pier. All in all a great experience. The single negative I would have is related to the pricing of everything inside the resort. Hilton must charge incredible rent for restaurants/shops as a meal for five often came to $300+. We ate at several restaurants and all of them were great except for Sergio's Italian Table. We waited ages in a half full restaurant for mediocre food, waited longer for drinks, only to be told to wait for approval to charge the meal to our room - all we did was wait - it didn't happen anywhere else so just steer clear of the joint. Otherwise you're in good hands. Especially at Benihana's, the ice cream parlor, CJ's for breakfast, and dinner/drinks at the Tropics Bar & Grill. The music at Tapa Bar is hit & miss. They have limited seating so show up early if you want to sit where you can see the singers. All in all a great vacation, everyone definitely went home happy.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We spent one night at this hotel at the last leg of our trip. It is a huge place with many different restaurants and shops. The pool is great and the room was very clean and spacious. There is a nice amount of beach by the hotel and fun things to do. I took a lei making class which was fun and I got to take the beautiful lei with me afterwards. There are penguins and other animals around to see - a real tropical fun spot.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: This was our third stay in the past 10 years. We had been on two other islands in timeshares. It was good to get to a real resort. The Hawaiian village provides a very nice ending to a great trip. Be sure to upgrade to the rainbow tower. Ask for a great view and high floor. We upgrades for about $85/night to a suite in the rainbow tower. It was the size of two rooms completely open. The beach has a nice calm area to swim and snorkel. The pool area was somewhat crowded. If you rent a car and have a late flight, you can keep your car in the garage all day. Leave any bags in it you don't need. (It's pricey, use your Hilton points)

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Defiantly the most classy however relaxed hotel I have ever been to in the states, it's so modern and comfortable. Been to this hotel twice and the second time was much better because of the room and tower we had been located in (33rd Floor of Tapa Tower) the best views as in the day I had the sea to the left and at night the lights of Honolulu. It was actually perfect! If I could there's a 99% chance of living in the hotel. I can't even give this hotel a negative comment, maybe a bit pricey for some but my family have no qualms in paying extra for accommodation as good as this. EXCELLENT.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: I have to say that the "village" is a very nicely designed site. Much attention to minor details that I noticed and appreciated as an artist. Hard to beat the view and location, being right on the oceanfront. Exceptional, really.The two main negative I have were: 1) it is hard to get to the freeway (H1) from there... but then again, I found out that traffic in Honolulu BLOWS, no matter what time of day it is, and 2) they really, really overcharge for everything onsite, and nothing I experienced (food, shops, rentals, parking) was above average at all. Since the place is designed to get you to just stay "in the village", it can add up if you never get off the grounds. (I did... I'm an explorer at heart.)

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: The Hilton Hawaiian is a GREAT place to stay in Waikiki. The resort has several towers, four pools, a full service spa and many shops that range from basic to high-end. Best of all, the beautiful beach is located just steps from the large pool area.My room (in the Tapa tower) was fairly large and had a great deck. Housekeeping did an excellent job each night and I felt really comfortable in my home-away-from-home for the five nights that I stayed. The animals on the property were really cool, and I loved seeing the flamingos on my daily walks around the grounds. On the day of my checkout, I was encouraged to take advantage of a complimentary courtesy room, as my flight was not scheduled until late that evening. I signed up at the front desk for a room at 6 p.m. At five of, I simply picked up a room key at the front desk and had access to a clean, stocked guest room for half an hour. It was so nice being able to take a quick shower and change clothes in a comfortable, private room before my departure.My only issue with the hotel was the quality and price of the food and beverage options. I had a grilled chicken salad and diet coke that cost $15 (plus tax and tip) at the poolside grill one afternoon. The salad had obviously been refrigerated for some time and the chicken was barely edible-- certainly not hot off the grill as I was expecting. The two other times I ate at the hotel were for breakfast. On both occasions, I had an egg white omelet with hash browns, toast and coffee, and each meal was easily over $30, including tax and tip. It's always expensive to eat out while traveling, but compared with prices at home, the markup was around 100%, which is not acceptable. I had far less expensive meals at the more glamorous, non-chain hotels further down the beach. Food and beverage issues aside, I would recommend the Hilton Hawaiian Village to anyone who wants to stay at a place with every possible amenity at his or her fingertips.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Excellent hotel, great for families, you'll find everything in one place, great view, full of narure

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: I stayed here last June, and I"m so happy I chose this hotel. after 2 months of researching and comparing hotels I decided to stay here because it's beachfront features. there were 9 of us including my 12yr old son. upon check in the outstanding service started....we requested a connecting room or next to each other eventhough I was not expecting it since i'm requesting it upon check in. And the front desk said "ok no problem" just like that! and on top of that she gave us a free upgrade of ocean view!! wow!! can't get any better than that. the room is awesome clean, and the balcony is the best....we enjoyed every sunrise and sunsets, rainbows early mornings it was really indeed paradise. we had a wedding and I ordered our lei's and bouquet, now the problem is the refrigerator was small for all the flowers. so I called concierge and ask if they can store some flowers for me, at first they weren't sure but finally they got the Bell manager and said it was ok. we left it there overnight and @ 5am the manager called my room and checked in if everything is ok and if the flowers are fine? totally unexpected! the staff really do care and i'm touched by that. the only down side is it's away from where the action is. but if you're like me that only thing that matters is the beach then you will love this place. now we're planning to go back for our 1st wedding anniversary :0)

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: My husband and I stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village for one night in October 2009 for a special event. The resort buildings and grounds were very lovely and well-maintained. We were pleasantly surprised at check-in when we were upgraded to room with an ocean view in the Tapa Tower. The room was lovely and so was the view; and, even more importantly, our king-sized bed was very comfy. Although we were only there one night, we arrived early that afternoon to enjoy some sun and relaxation by one of the 3 pools. Since we were located in the Tapa Tower and the Tapa pool was not as crowded as the Super Pool, we decided to lounge at the Tapa pool. It was a nice, quaint pool by the Tapa Bar. The only disappointment was the lack of drink and food service. Unlike other resorts, there were no servers servicing the pool for drinks or food. You needed to get your own drinks at the Tapa Bar and walk all the way to the Super Pool area to get food. It took me over 20 minutes to get 2 drinks at the Tapa Bar. Then, it took me another 30 minutes to walk to the Super Pool area, wait in line, and purchase a Caesar Salad. This took almost an hour out of my relaxation time by the pool. Perhaps, the lack of service by the pool is due to the Hilton Hawaiian Village being so vast with 6 towers and 3 pools, but when I go to a resort, I much prefer to pay tips to the serving staff and maximize my relaxation time.  Of course, the upside to the vastness of the Hilton Hawaiian Village is the choice it offers. It has a multitude of good restaurants and shops and is located on Waikiki beach.  Overall, we enjoyed our short stay and certainly enjoyed our evening event.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: The hotel is not all that nice and new. Some of the towers are pretty old. I had lots of starbucks coffee and snacks, not because I loved them but because there was naot much more worth having. The beach was very good, but busy and really not my ideal kind of beach seen as not relaxing at all. A found it crowded a dirty at times.An average holiday, could have been much better in another hotel may be.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: My husband & I stayed here as first time Hilton Grand Vacation Club Owners and first time to Hawaii tourists. We loved it! It is very expensive at the bars and restaurants but lucky us, we had a full kitchen! Next time I will bring a soft-sided cooler, buy drinks at the ABC store and take them to the pool & beach. Also, parking is only 25 cents an hour and it's one block from the Kalia tower at the Marina parking lot, much cheaper than valet and the walk was pleasant. Only problem with room was no alarm clock by the bed, don't know if it was missing or they don't provide it. Just used my cell phone instead. The Kalia tower is only hotel rooms and 1 bedrooms so not as many children as the Lagoon tower, which was nice for us! The Kalia pool was nice as was the hot-tub, only wish they had a bar there. We will be returning, it's a great place to stay!Some tours worth doing: Wild Side Snorkel Tour, Haunauma Bay Snorkel, Hawaii Food Tour and the Mai Tai Catamaran. It's also very nice at Waimea Bay and Waimea Valley. A good hike is Manoa Falls Trail.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Wouldn't think of staying anywhere else. Great resort and great location..Walking distance from everything!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: This hotel is as a large as a small town, it has all the right facilities, it is in a great location on by far the best stretch of beach in Waikiki. The spa is excellent, the restaurants are many and food is alright, the rooms are large and the view is great. Minor drawbacks: the room's decor was slightly dated, it is only so slightly off the centre of the action in Waikiki (5' walk away from all the other main resorts and main street). Value for money is pretty good: there are better hotels in Waikiki (Royal Waikikian, Halekulani, Moana), but they have very different price tags. Between Hilton and Sheraton, stay at the Hilton! The Sheraton does not have a beach at all. If I were to go back, I'd stay at the Moana if I had a slightly higher budget (uniquely charming), or probably at the Hilton again.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: If you plan on staying in Waikiki, definitely make the Hilton Hawaiian Resort one of your top choices. The resort is located on the most beautiful and widest stretch of Waikiki beach. Sand is white and soft and the beach is not as crowded as some of the other well known hotels in the area. The resort property is simply stunning with the attention to detail and beauty to the specatular landscaping. The grounds have lovely gardens, flowers, koi fish ponds and a little sand beach with penguins. Everything is so clean and well kept. Keep in mind that the resort is huge and like a small city but it's easy to navigate and find the various attractions. If you go, enjoy the beautiful resort but defintiely get out and explore the rest of the island. You don't really experience Oahu if you don't leave Waikiki.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We stayed at this hotel for 3 days/2 nights in Waikiki after staying for 6 nights at the Marriott Waikiki Beach in October 2009. (Both hotels are in Waikiki, but on separate ends of town.)This hotel is a great resort hotel located on the beach with several pools, many restaurants, and many shops. You can go to this resort and never have to leave the resort to see other areas of Waikki. If you are into shopping, you buy a Coach purse, jewelry, and also the "ABC" discount stores.Hospitality Room ... I would recommend asking the front desk for a hospitality room which allows you to stay at the hotel until your flight leaves and use a hotel room for at least 20 minutes/per person prior to your departure from the airport. Our flight was scheduled to leave at 9 PM, so we used a hospitality room from 5:00 - 5:40 PM to get a shower and a little nap prior to leaving the hotel at 6 PM.Pros:- Great all-in-one resort- Beach is great- The pools are great- Customer Service is very good- Many stores and restaurants located on-site- Short walk or commute to the convention center and Ala Moana shopping centerCons - If you want to use the fitness center, make sure you are a Hilton Honors member or sign up prior to checking into this hotel or else the charge is $14/day- Internet fees are also an additional $15/day- On-site rental car rates are very high at the hotel. We rented a car using a "promo code" from Dollar Rental Car about 3 blocks from the hotel. (We wanted to see the North Shore.) Look at the convention center travel desk for the promo codes. (Saved $40 compared to the hotel rental car rates) - If you want to see the more commercial area of Waikiki along Kalakaua Avenue, then you will have to walk about 6 blocks through some "questionable areas". I would recommend going along the beach, taking a trolley, or using a taxi.Overall, this is a great hotel. I would recommend to everyone!!!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Great hotel. Yes, it is huge and that will turn some travelers away from selecting the HHV. However, if you want a resort that has all the possible amenities and still is close to the action of Waikiki, this is a great choice. It's a short walk (along the beach to save steps) to all the other hotels on Waikiki. We had a corner room on the 12th floor, of the Tapa tower, which gives you more room than a standard room, it is a strange configuration, but that is what gives you the extra space. Our room was called a "garden view" but had a clear view (at an angle) of the lagoon and the ocean. Mix a drink, sit on the lanai and watch the sunset and the village come alive below.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Just Beautiful!! This Hotel has been the number one hotel i have ever stayed at. Very clean and elegant. Staff had great hospitality.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We were on Oahu for 10 days (our 1st trip to Hawaii) for a conference and a vacation. Our room on the 15th floor of the Rainbow Tower was large and overlooked the lagoon, the coastline, and the Pacific Ocean. View was gorgeous! The room was nicely decorated and we liked the floor plan with a counter and refrigerator across from the large closet. The only drawback was a fairly small bathroom, but it was functional and attractive. The grounds of the Hilton are spacious and attractive, with lots of nooks and crannies to sit in the shade or to watch the flamingos, penguins, other birds, and koi. Our first dinner was at the Tropics bar and grill right on the beach, and we fell in love with the location; the view was superb, the setting was casual, and the food was ggod (as were the lava flows!). We didn't eat at the expensive restaurant, but found plenty of less pricey but good restaurants at the Rainbow Bazaar across from the main lobby. It was convenient to have all those restaurants and stores (especially the ABC store) a few steps away. The best and largest beach in Waikiki!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: The resort is beautiful, clean and classy. The service at the resort was great - people were helpful, professional, and very nice. The resort is close to everything - downtown Honolulu, a very large mall, the beach, and several delicious places to dine. The famous Dukes Restaurant is also close by. It is easy to just walk down Waikiki beach from the resort. My room was a favorite at the hotel because it had 2 views/2 balconies that viewed the beach and a lagoon. Every Saturday, Hilton puts on fireworks which is also a nice to view from the beach.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: The hotel, a series of twers, covers every square foot of land it has at the entrance to Waikiki Beach. It is big, busy, often crowded and sometimes disorganized. But the personnel (at least many of them) go out of their way to help, the place is clean, the room was huge (although that partial water view for which we paid could best be seen with a mirror and by hanging off the city-facing balcony!)It is a big conference resort and handles crowds well. Very grateful for the business given the decline in tourism. Waits for meals, atc, but hey, this is Waikiki...Pools not what you will find in non-city resorts in the islands, but handle a crowd. Nice beach and a lagoon...

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We stayed in the lagoon tower 1 bedroom condo type. Check in was fast and we even got in our room early. The room was spacious, the view spectacular. Full kitchen came with a cheap dishwasher that was jammed with a chopstick. (So that's why it didn't clean very well) I didn't charge them for the repair. the rice cooker and blender were a nice touch. More options for cooking in because we spent soooo much more on this place than the other hotel that we stayed at in the area. Soaps for the kitchen along with laundry soap were provided. We didn't use the free laundry facilities because they had that musty smell that front loaders get when left closed. After smelling a couple of musty guests in the elevator, I didn't want to take a chance.The bathroom also had a musty odor. Maybe the shower curtain. But besides the slight smell (my husband didn't notice it but he's a man) the bathroom was clean with the exception of a bit of mold toward the top of the shower stall. We were promised daily housekeeping but they didn't show up after the first night. No problem though as there were plenty of towels and amenities.This is a great property if you are looking for a resort atmosphere. The lagoon was nice and the beach is the cleanest in Waikiki. Not as much riffraff as you sometimes find on tourist beaches.The grounds can be loud with the luau and all but things quiet down early and a nice romantic walk on the grounds by tiki light is recommemded. Pizza was expensive but good. Pair a small one with a salad to share to keep the cost down and the bikini fitting better. Primer drinks from ABC on the lanai will help keep the bar tab down.They make it so you never have to leave. But if you do, rent your car someplace other than the Hertz onsite. We decided on that rental for a bit more money because we thought that it would be more convenient than walking a couple of blocks. Wrong. The agent was hard to understand. The cars were hard to find.They offered no help in the parking facility. Had a heck of a time finding the secret entrance to the fifth floor for return. Had nobody to check us in. No clear directions to the drop box and they charged us more than agreed on.This would probably be my first choice for lodging in Waikiki if cost was not a factor. In hindsite, I am glad that we stayed here but with the money that we spent on this room, we could ave stayed more than twice as long at another property.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village for the first stage of our honeymoon. Travelling from the UK to Hawaii is a long journey...but we stayed in the Hilton for 7 nights. My first impression of the hotel is that is was vast! There are lots of rooms and various towers. As we were honeymooners we did get an upgraded room (with a sea view) and champagne in the room.The hotel room itself was lovely, it was very spacious with a good size bed and a nice bathroom. The pool and the lagoon on the hotel site were great, food and drink are very expensive in the hotel so we tended to eat outside of the hotel for our meals.I do have to say that Oahu was not quite what I had expected, if you are expecting to stay on a secluded island then you will be disappointed! There are lots of high rise buildings in waikiki - mainly hotels. There has clearly been a lot of money spent on the resort with lots of high end designer shops and good choices of restaurants.One thing i would avoid if i travelled there again would be to steer clear of organised trips. We spent too much time on coaches and not enough time soaking up the sun and surf. We also took a trip to the 'Big Island', this would have been fine if we had been staying longer but it was a very long day. The tour was a bit boring to be honest, we had been sold the trip by the rep at the hotel as being able to see live volcanoes - which we did but it took us hours to get there and we could only see them from a distance!I would recommend a trip to the Luau party - this was great! Its a bit tacky but you really get a feel for some of the traditions of hawaii.Overall, this was a nice hotel but it was a long way to travel and we feel slightly disappointed with Hawaii as a destination as it is much more commerical than we had expected.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Everyone was very nice and the Hilton village had everything you needed property. the beach and lagoon was nice and clean. Perfect vacation property

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Our 2-bedroom condo was great for a family traveling with a grandparent. The bedrooms were large and the living/dining room was huge. Having a full kitchen was a luxury, especially given the high prices for meals at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. Access to the washer and dryer was helpful. The balcony was wonderful, but beware of the slide pool with lots of noise during the day. The big slides close at 5 pm, so the evenings were nice and quiet. Although the new tower is upgraded, the Lagoon Tower is well-maintained and we had a nice view of the water. We have stayed at most of the hotel towers at HHV, and this condo was our favorite with the additional space and amenities.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: This place was super highly recommended by all the travel books I read. Great for kids and families, tons to do, lazy river, water slides, great restaurants and activities. Our experience was not so great. The room was beautiful and the grounds impeccable but the staff and the service left a LOT to be desired. Room service food sat out in the halls for hours on end, the valets were no where to be found when you needed your car, the driveway was too crowded and you had to wait a long time to get in to a valet and there were not enough available to park the number of cars coming in and out, the front desk staff was slow to wait on you and did not smile, it required several calls to housekeeping to get laundry detergent for the room, the activities desk did not have schedules for the whole facility and could not arrange your participation you had to walk across the whole complex and sign up in a binder, the activities schedule was VERY limited and limited only to certain days of the week, the food at the restaurants was ridiculously over-priced, the "lazy river" and "water slides" were a joke - very small and uneventful and children under 12 (even proficient swimmers) were required to wear those blow up arm flotation devices which conveniently they sold there by the pool, and there were not nearly enough seats for around the pool - you had to wait hours to get an open chair. I would not recommend a stay there to anyone! We had 6 nights at the Embassy Suites on the Beachwalk prior to switching to the Hilton and after one night at the Hilton we regretted out move! The Embassy was superb in every way!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Just returned from a week long stay at the HHV – Lagoon Tower. We had a 3 bedroom on the Penthouse Floor (24). We were assigned to room 2465. This unit consists of 3 bedrooms and 3 ½ baths. The living, dinning and kitchen were located downstairs. There was a ½ bath located adjacent to the front door. Downstairs by the staircase is a master suite with a balcony facing the Rainbow Tower / Diamond Head. This master suite had a bathroom designed for a disabled person. Upstairs were another master suite along with a third bedroom and bathroom. There was plenty of room for four adults and one child. It should be noted that the third bedroom was kind of loud due to the fact that it had plantation shutters for “windows”, which allowed for downstairs noise to come in. Also the A/C was strong, but the fan noise was kind of loud. The unit was clean and nicely decorated. It had all the essentials. There were only a few quirky things such as in the third bedroom, the battery compartment lid on the TV remote was missing. Also, they only give you one tiny bottle of shampoo per bathroom. Granted there is midweek cleaning, however with being at the beach one would need at least two to three of the hotel sized bottles. The washer/dryer were not in the rooms. They are next to the elevators on the even floor rooms. No detergent or softeners were provided. (We brought our own) The directions were in Japanese. Kitchen appeared to be well stocked with cooking pots and pans. We didn’t cook. We ate out mostly and ate some leftovers in the room. Check in was smooth. They provided us with wrist bands to get towels and use the pools. One wrist band allows you to get two pool towels. They assessed us $9.23 a day for tax to stay at the HHV. The total for seven days was $64.61. Add $30 a day for valet parking. ($25 / day if you self park) The lagoon pool was great for the kids. They had a toddler water slide, two kids slide (which only one was working) and a larger slide for the big kids and adults. It was hard finding chairs to sit down or put our towels/ items down. It took about 5-10 minutes each time, scoping for a open chair or waiting for someone to leave. One more thing, if your child is under 48 inches, whether they swim or not, they need to have floaters on the arms. They won’t let you go down the mid/lg slide without them. Bring your own or you can pay $5 where you get the towels. The slides close at 5 PM each day. Valet Parking was hit and miss. Sometimes they were quick, other times they were slow. There didn’t appear to be any rhymn or reason. Most of the time when I returned to the HHV, there was no one to greet me. I had to walk up to the valet desk and tell them I’m returning the car. There was a more mature Asian male behind the valet desk most of the time. I think he’s the lead valet or supervisor. You’ll know him because he’s the bald guy. Customer service is not his forte. He never smiles or says anything. Overall, I’m very happy with our stay at the HHV. Most of the staff was cordial and professional. To be able to watch the Friday night fireworks show from the balcony was outstanding. Very rarely does it get any better than that. Looking forward to coming back again in April.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Travelled to Hawaii this May for the second stay at the Hawaiian Village. First time we stayed in a one bedroom suite which was very comfortable. This last time we were in a two bedroom corner suite! This was beautiful, view of waikiki beach and diamond head from the one of two balconies in this suite. The staff were very helpful and pleasant despite reviews I have read. The only thing I can be negative of from the view of a mom with young adults is the pool at the new tower..............lets just say plenty of young children not a pool you can relax at. The village is located in a very convenient place with plenty of dining options close by. Cannot wait until our next visit!!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We recently stayed a week at the HGVC's Grand Waikikian and we enjoyed every moment of our stay at the resort. Our stay was a result of a VIP package that was purchased after attending a time share presentation in Las Vegas. I thought since I wanted to come to Hawaii anyway why not do it thru this program. I probably could come up with a lot of cons to doing it this way if I thought about it but the ones that come to mind are just the frequent calls to offer you more stuff and ask you by more points, etc. And then I was still required to attend a 90 minutes presentation here in Hawaii which I really didn't want to do because I knew I would be wasting the rep's time in addition to my time since I knew I would not be purchasing the timeshare. The gentleman that I met with the 90 minute presentation was nice and I think he kind of sensed from the beginning that I was not going to purchase the timeshare. I don't understand the concept. I have stayed in very nice places when I've traveled and I never spend the money that they calculate that I will spend on vacations over a prescribed time period. For the people that timeshares works for I say great but for me I don't see the value. For my cons those would be the most significant two. Everything else was a positive. The Grand Wakikian was beautiful and well appointed. We stayed in a 2 bedroom/2 bath unit with a view of the ocean. We could see it well enough from the balacony of our condo on the 19th floor. Everything about the room was lovely. If I was to complain about anything it would be that the kitchen did not seem to be as well stocked as some of the other condo type places that I've stayed. Which was fine I guess since we did not plan on doing much cooking at all if any. The washer and dryer took a long time to both wash and dry a small load of clothes. I personally have never heard of the brand but I know I would never buy one based on my experience during this vacation. Otherwise things were very nice. Things are expensive in Honolulu period and they are certainly expensive around the Hilton Hawaiian Village. You are within walking distance of lots of things and places to eat. The bus stop is near by and you can take it almost anywhere on the island. We purchased some grocery items from Foodland which is a short walk or bus ride from the hotel. We walked there once and and caught the bus another time when went back to the mall the food store is located in. The Walmart is about 2-3 blocks from the mall and if we had known that before shopping at Foodland, we would gone there because most of the stuff we got from FoodLand we could have got from Walmart a little cheaper. I forgot my manual toothbrush and brought one at first from Foodland for $4.50, only to go to a drug store upstairs called Long Drug store and found Oral B twin packs for $1.99. I ended up with 4 toothbrushes for the price of one. We went on a few tours since it was our first time here in Honolulu. The tours were not that expensives but unless you have your own car or want to ride the bus it make sense to see most of the things by using the tours. Most of the things were pretty far out and while the bus did go to most of them it would have taken twice if not three times the time as most things were far out. We went to the Polynesian Culture Center it was nice but I don't know if I would do the meal there again, the food was not good. It was passable but I would have just as soon packed a sandwich in my bag. We went to a luau at Germaine's again the food was just passable. But the shows at both places were nice. We also went on a tour that included Pearl Harbor and what is called the Circle Island tour. The visit to Pearl Harbor was an informative and solemn experience. The circle island tour took you around the whole island, with stops at various points of interest. It was a great opportunity to see more of the island than we would have seen otherwise. Te cabs are very expensive for even a short ride. We did that once just because we did not know how close the bus stop was and we had the groceries to bring back and some things were perishable. We learned the bus route quick after that short ride for $10. The people we encountered were very nice. When I first arrived I was not impressed with what I saw starting with the airport and the ride from from the airport to the resort. The morning put a whole new shine on the picture. I could see the ocean....just beautiful. I think I will come again to enjoy the ocean and try some of the water activities that I really did not take advantage of this time around.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Beautiful hotel - room was clean and spacious with a refrigerator. We loved the option of having 4 pools to go to, esp. one with 2 water slides in addition to one of the most beautiful beaches on-site. I walked all the way from the Waikiki Beach at the Hyatt back to this hotel and I must say that this portion of the beach is the cleanest and less crowded area. It also has it's own lagoon and lots of restaurants and shops on the property - you don't even need to go outside the complex. The kids loved it! Parking rate was expensive, but public transportation was right outside.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: you'd have to be royalty to not like this place. it's grand and i had zero complaints that truly matter. but don't go without a deep pocket. the shopping in the hilton hawaiian village is expensive, even pizza, it costs over $6 for two scoops of ice cream in a cone or cup and $4 for an iced coffee. but if you have a deep pocket or can survive on sandwiches and yogurt from the ABC store in the mall, then you can do it. the access to waikiki beach is a few minutes. the views from our room of waikiki beach and diamond head are perfect. we were on the 7th floor, don't go any higher than that (we were in the rainbow tower) if you are afraid of heights and want to enjoy the roomy balcony by lounging out there.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We stayed at the Lagoon Tower at the Hilton Hawaiian Village through our points with Hilton Grand Vacations Club. We are not owners here. We enjoyed the perks of being Elite travelers with HGVC, and we enjoyed the room and Oahu in general. We also enjoy the location of the hotel down the beach and away from the crazyness of the center of Waikiki. We found a way to exit the hotel by turning left and driving around the Ilikai past the marina and turning left onto Ala Moana Blvd. This is necessary until they turn on the light for the Grand Waikikian and the Lagoon towers.However, in the past we've stayed here at the Tapa Tower in a regular room and thought the facility was overcrowded and the pools (especially the super pool) unapproachable. We were encouraged by the news that the lagoon between the Lagoon and Rainbow towers was going to be renovated and a new pool called the Paradise Pool was being built. Back in 2006 when we heard this news, we were excited.After fully experiencing the Paradise Pool in all its "glory", we can say we are no longer thrilled. Our rooms were on the west side of the hotel and gave us a wonderful sunset view opportunity but most of our view was of the Ilikai next door. We could see McGarrett's balcony very clearly as we were on the 18th floor. We could also hear the pool noise as the sound travels up the side of the building very well, just like a sound barrier on the highway. Since we were hardly in the rooms during the day this was not a real problem. And on our last day we could sit on the balcony and take video of our teenagers in the pool.Our biggest complaint is the "reservation" situation that seems to happen as guest line up at 6am to reserve blocks of chairs when the pool officially opens at 8am, only to leave for the morning to sightsee and guaranteeing a seat when they return in the afternoon. Then when they tire of their sought after seats later in the afternoon, the towels are left there in a wet heap making it difficult for a late afternoon guest to know if the chairs are being used.The pool offers very little shade as well and my chief complaint is with the hotel management and their use of the lovely newly renovated lagoon. The lagoon area offers umbrella and chair rentals from 8am to 4:30pm. Most of our swimming happened after 3. The chair rental is $15/chair, the umbrella is $20 (I think). That's $45 for a comfortable chair and shade on a very very sunny and hot stretch of beach with no other shade for 90 minutes. And at 4:30, those chairs and umbrellas are politely yanked out from under and over you. So, traveler beware, if you have sensitive-to-the-sun skin like mine or just want a cool place to relax and enjoy the sounds and sights of Waikiki beach, bring your own chair and umbrella to the Lagoon at HHV. Other pool related complaints: On our last night (Friday night), the kids wanted to go over to the original super pool but when we walked over there for a quick swim it was already closed. This must have been after 4:30 because the lagoon chair and umbrella that we had was taken away and we wanted to see if we could find a bit of shade over at the super pool. However, since it was Friday the pool was closed to make way for the weekly festivities. So we walked back over to the Paradise pool, got lucky finding ONE chair and the kids slid themselves silly.The other sort of negative is only negative because we had no idea what time it was when it happened. We knew about the fireworks but we had no idea what it was going to be like from the hotel room. If we ever stay here on a Friday night again, we will be sure to be somewhere else and not in the hotel room. Since our hotel room faced away from the fireworks, we saw them reflected in the Ilikai next door.***** Here's what happened. We were just settling down after eating leftovers for dinner. We were all puttering around packing up and cleaning up. We heard this really LOUD BOOM and I thought a bomb had gone off. That was followed by more and more and we realized what it was so we went out onto the balcony to experience it in reflection off the Ilikai next door. But it was loud and the sound ricocheted off of all the buildings magnifying it. When the finale went off, the sound was so sudden and so loud that my 16 year old son jumped into the slider bumping his nose and forehead in the process of trying to get away from the noise. This was an instinctual fight or flight response. We figured since we were on the 18th floor we were probably pretty darn close to the reports of the exploding display. On a positive note, we were treated very well by all the staff. Requests were handled very promptly; from extra towels to the valet for the car. We were asked several times if we needed directions as we retrieved our car from the valet. The 2bdrm/2bath is extremely roomy reserving space for the bedrooms by not over-inflating the bathroom size which was standard hotel room sized and ample and nothing special unlike the bathrooms at Kings' Land and Kohala suites on the Big Island.On a final note, the Paradise Pool needs a pool bar and snack bar. This was my husbands biggest complaint. He couldn't get an overpriced drink while lounging at the pool and his dream vacation experience is not to have to walk across the street to get a takeout pizza. Seriously, we've been up to the Turtle Bay (which was a Hilton property and should never have been sold in my opinion, but I guess Hilton wanted to focus on Waikiki and the Big Island), and one of our fondest memories is spending a VERY relaxing 6 hours by the pool simply watching the kids play in the pool and slide on the waterslide and then come out, say their hungry and order some lunch to eat by the pool. And the view, OMG, what a place. But we can't use our Vacation Points there. Oh, Well.All in all, we enjoy the location of HHV but will know in the future not to expect much from the amenities. I have sent a review to HGVC because I believe in sharing my raves and rants with the hotel management instead of JUST raving and ranting here on TA.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Stayed 1 night in the Rainbow Tower with Oceanfront Views. Compact room with sink, kettle and smallish bathroom but for 2 people, plenty big enough. The most comfortable bed. You are at the end of the hotels here so it is a bit of a walk if you want some action but I enjoyed the walk as you're able to stop in at some of the bars along the way.Our view was in the Diamond Head direction which was beautiful at night with all the lights. Originally I hoped for a room at the very front but am glad we got one on the side as the view at night is wonderful.We had stayed in the Kalia Tower last year so thought we'd try the Rainbow Tower am glad we did. Location is excellent. The only issue is that you have leave your room at least 15 mins if you're getting the shuttle to get down there in time. I'm glad we stayed last year as we knew where to go but it could have been a nightmare if this was our first time. With so many areas at the HHV and towers it would be very easy to get confused.This was a great stay.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Five of us, including a 5-yr-old, 1-yr-old & Grandma, stayed for a week at the end of August in a 2-bedrm timeshare unit at the Grand Waikikian tower. The room was fantastic: new & clean, roomy (enough) & modern, with appropriate island decor and a nice functional little kitchen. Each bedroom had a bathroom with a shower stall (the masterbath also has a large tub open to the bedroom) and flatpanel TVs. The details are 1st class: thick, frameless glass shower doors, granite counters, etc. There is a stacked front-loading washer & dryer, Bosch, that was very handy (though, as other reviews have stated, the dryer is slow to dry). The balcony was a little smallish, and our 11th flr view had only slivers of ocean, but otherwise the room was perfect for us.  The Grand Waikikian tower is newly built on the Ala Moana side of the property. It's on the edge of the property, but that's a good thing, as it has its own valet entry away from the busier main entry to the village. So it's a decent walk to the beach frontage or shops, but it's closer to the shopping street and Marina parking. Parking rates recently increased to $24 self, or $30 valet--- steep! The self parking garage can be a dreadful zoo, especially on weekends. We valeted a few days, and parked at the adjacent Marina on other days. The Marina parking is a bargain at $6/day! The catch is that finding a space can be challenging on weekends (though it was pretty easy on weekdays). Also, it doesn't work well if you come and go every hour, or don't know when you'll be leaving (you have to choose the duration of your parking slip, and after you leave it becomes unusable), and I wouldn't want to park there very late at night (I think the cars are fine, and it's patrolled, but I wouldn't want to hang around there). We planned well and saved about $150 in parking fees. The pools are great at the village, and the newly built pool next to the Grand Waikikian and Lagoon Tower has several nice slides and waterfalls. But even though the resort was not packed all week, it seemed that the new pool was always crowded during the day. Getting a lounge chair meant arriving close to the 8am open time. Instead, we chose to swim at the lagoon and the private beach. The saltwater lagoon is great for kids. The water is calm, and you can rent pedal boats and kayaks (for about $34/hr, which is outrageously expensive, but most kids only need one hour). The lagoon sand is oddly gritty. Umbrellas are equally expensive, about $30+ per day plus tip, but a necessary luxury (the umbrellas are nice, heavy-duty, and they do all the work, digging a hole and planting it so it doesn't blow away). The beach has decent, soft sand and smallish waves (it's semi-protected from the harsh Hawaiian waves), again, perfect for kids. We didn't eat much on the property, mostly buying food at the ABC stores (we hit about five of the seemingly hundreds in Honolulu), and at the excellent Accents convenience mart downstairs in the Grand Waikikian. This store has a great variety of drinks and prepared food, including fruit and desserts, as well as coffee and sundry items. We usually stay at boutique hotels, but we really enjoyed our time at this mega-resort property. Having small kids makes convenience and comfort a priority, and this property delivers both, along with a beaches, pools, food, shopping, and so on...

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We are HGVC Elite Premier members and reserved 2 rooms in the Lagoon Tower for 3 nights. We reserved a 2 bedroom plus and also a Studio since we had friends traveling with us. We had just come from an absolutely fantastic 6 night stay at the Big Island's Waikoloa Beach Resort (also a HGVC property). At check-in we should have had a clue that this property doesn't do anything special for Elite Premiers like almost all of the other HGVC properties do, because the clerk told us the parking fee ($30 per night for valet, or $26 per night for self-park) would not be waived. We explained that it has been waived at all other properties since we became Elite Premiers and she said something about how they are trying to discourage guests from bringing cars since public transportation is available. Our studio room was right beside the elevators and we noticed the noise of the elevators right away. We also noticed the noise of the A/C unit which ran constantly or not at all. Our friend finally decided the A/C noise was preferable to the elevator noise, but said it sure wasn't ideal. The studio, other than the noise, was well appointed with a microwave, small refrigerator, coffee pot and a few dishes and sink. The bed was a king and there was a small table with a couple of chairs along with an easy chair. The pillows on the bed were foam. Towels were the small hotel variety. There was a tub/shower combo. There is a free laundry room (two washers an two dryers) on each floor and the machines appeared to be good ones. Our 2 Bedroom unit was on the 18th floor with a nice ocean view from the lanai. The unit was a decent size and looked good at the beginning. However, the foam pillows on the king bed in the master bedroom and on the beds in the 2nd bedroom were old and awful. The master bath was a tub/shower combo (having just come from an HGVC on the Big Island with a fantastic huge tub and a very large walk-in shower this was a real step down!). There was a single sink in the bathroom area along with TWO towel sets. If we'd been there for more than the two nights we stayed, extra towels would have been great. And, a newer, larger-size towel would have been nice. These are things we've gotten used to HGVC resorts. The full kitchen was well appointed and had everything we needed, except a dishwasher that worked. The soap dispenser was broken so you got a lot of soap at the start and then none later. It didn't quite do the job. The door to the lanai had a trigger thin area that the closed door needed to be in for the A/C to work. If you have the lanai doors open, the A/C goes off, which is a good thing. However it was a very tricky deal to get the door positioned just exactly in the right spot to get it to come back on. The location of the Lagoon Tower is excellent and is right in the middle of the Hilton Hawaiian Village. Pools are adequate and well kept. Pool chairs are another matter. Supposedly you can't reserve a chair before 8 AM and if you aren't there right at 8, you will not be in the race to place a towel or personal property on a chair. There's not requirement to ever be sitting in that chair and herein lies the problem. We saw so many people putting towels on chairs and then not returning for several hours. It would seem to be a good idea to have the towel guys make a round of the chairs every hour or so and keep an eye on unused, but reserved, chairs so they could be given to those waiting for a place to sit. We've seen this done elsewhere and it works very well.Bottom Line: This property needs to be remodeled. The General Manager did call us in answer to an email we wrote him and said that this would be happening next year. He said Housekeeping had just decided to go with the foam pillows instead of the feather pillows most Hilton properties use. We said this wasn't a good decision on their part. They are awful. The manager was apologetic about the noisy studio and the parking fees and did compensate us for the parking. We would really rather compliment a property than complain, but this one just wasn't up to par. We did appreciate the manager's attention to our concerns but still decided to check out a day early.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We had a group of 11 people and a total of 4 rms. Upon arrival the check in line was pretty long, but the check in counter was fully staffed. The person checking us in took a lot of xtra time selecting our rooms which was pretty difficult becuase they were sold out. He managed to get us 2 connecting rms on one floor and 2 connecting rms on another. I was so impressed! We were all in the Tapa Tower which is in the center on the village, there is a band that plays every night at the bar in the tower which you can hear from your rm, but the music stopped by 11pm.The week we were there we kept seeing on tv that a hurricane was coming. HHV was featured as one of the hotels getting ready so that they could take care of their customers, but after talking to several employees there was no real plan and no info was given to us. Our flight was cancelled and the hotel couldn't accomodate us so we moved to the Outrigger Reef down the street. it was a much smaller hotel, but very nice and they did have a letter in each rm with helpful hints. I wish the HHV could've done something like to calm our nerves.The beach @ the HHV is not crowded at all, they offer all the beach amenities, but the lagoon was way too crowded to attempt to do anything. We also didn't use the main pool because we could never get a chair. We attended the Luau which had to be moved inside because of the weather and it was just okay. I don't know if they shortened it because it was moved inside, but the menu was more extensive than most, but still my kids wished we would've gone to the Paradise Cove luau which is our usual. They have much more to keep everyone busy.Our rooms were kept very clean and they are very spacious. You don't ever have to leave, but the restaurants are pricey and there many places to eat within walking distance. The grounds are gorgeous. No free internet in your rm. Check out was pretty bad. They only had 3 people and they were in the Hilton Honors line, so anytime an H Honors member came up they were seen first. We talked to the manager, but she didn't think it was an issue. I would return but I am bummed about the lack of help when we got stuck another night.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: My sister, her boyfriend, his mother, her cousin, his great-aunt, and I spent 5 days at the Hilton Grand Vacations Club at Hilton Hawaiian Village, Lagoon Tower during the first week of July. We had an amazing time and it was our first trip to Hawaii for any of us. My parents give my sister and me a stay at one of the Hilton Grand Vacations Club condominiums (they are owners of a unit in Las Vegas) for our birthdays (they are a week apart) every year and this year, we chose the Hilton Hawaiian Village's Lagoon Tower. We did not regret the decision at all. Upon our arrival, the check-in staff was kind and courteous. Since we had arrived early and could not get into our rooms yet, they pre-registered us and gave us bracelets to go to the pool on the side of tower. They also gave us kukui nut leis, and told us where we could go to a VIP arrival / departure lounge where we could relax, freshen up, and change to go to the beach, pool, or lagoon. They contacted us by phone when our room would be ready. We ended up exploring the premises and found out that the Grand Waikikian and the Lagoon Tower shared a carport and check-in area. The Grand Waikikian is behind the Lagoon Tower and is a beautiful tower as well.It is next to the famous Rainbow Tower, right behind the lagoon, making it one of the best-situated towers in the entire village. The beach is just a 5-minute walk away from the tower, the lagoon is right in front of it, and there is a large and newly remodeled pool area right next to the tower. It is not far (a 3-minute walk) from the main shopping and dining area in the village. The Lagoon Tower is a timeshare condominium tower at the Village. It is the oldest one of the three timeshare towers in the Village (Lagoon Tower, Kalia Tower, and Grand Waikikian), but they are renovating the rooms in the tower to update them. The unit we had was beautiful; it looked like it had been renovated within the last year or two. It was an end unit, meaning it was on the end of the floor, (for HGVC timeshare owners, the room we had was a 2 BR+ Premier Ocean View) had two balconies and windows in every room along the side wall that had a view of the pool. The balcony had a wonderful view of the lagoon, the beach, the pool, and downtown Honolulu. We had the best view in my opinion of the Friday night fireworks the Hilton puts on and the biggest Fourth of July fireworks show in Oahu, as well as several other ones in the Honolulu area. The room was spacious in the common areas, such as the family and dining rooms, but the bedrooms were small compared to other HGVC resorts. In the room my sister and I shared, we had two twin beds in the room, a closet, and a TV cabinet. The closet doors had not been dusted prior to our arrival, so that took the cleanliness review down a notch. The kitchen was beautiful and had all the necessary utensils and pots to cook meals in the unit if you desired. The refrigerator would constantly leak and the issue was beyond our control as it was condensation from the cooling fans of the fridge. The service people did not answer our call for the fridge so; I knocked off a notch on service for that. Other than that, it was a wonderful unit; the room number was 567 if anyone was curious about that for requests. The Hilton Hawaiian Village Resort is very nice. It has everything there that if you did not want to leave the resort at all, you could do that. However, the island of Oahu has a lot of beautiful attractions and sights that you should explore it. The resort has quite a few restaurants at different price points and different cuisines that are worth checking out. There are many shops throughout the towers and in the Japanese- themed shopping village area as well that sell all kinds of beach items, Hawaiian souvenirs, travel items, jewelry and clothing. It is beautiful to look at and explore during the day and the evening. The beach was very nice and swimmable, but the sand is rocky where you swim, so I would recommend water/swim shoes to swim at the beach, as my feet took a while to get used to the rocks while swimming. The view from the water was nice as you could see the entire beach and the hotels from it. The water was nice to swim in on a hot day, while the waves can get a little strong at times, so you need to watch out for the waves when swimming. The lagoon is nice, but the water was way too cold to swim in there for me, and the temperature outside was In the high 80’s, normally, cold water should be a relief from the heat in that situation, but it was not. I would recommend swimming in the lagoon on the hottest days, when the temperature is above 90 degrees. The pool next to the tower is wonderful, as it is multi-level and there are several water slides for the kids to enjoy. There are several Jacuzzis as well to enjoy throughout the day. The pool is resurfaced and is a nice grey color, which gives the pool a distinctive look, matching the rocks around ii. You do need to get to the pool early, because people will reserve chairs at seven or eight in the morning to return much later in the day to use them. Checkout was really easy and short, depending on what time you need to leave. The bell desk is really efficient and helpful with your luggage at both check-in and checkout. They are also friendly and willing to give you advice on checking out some of the local favorites if you ask them. I would recommend the Lagoon Tower to anyone considering staying at the Hilton Hawaiian Village who wants more than just a simple hotel room. The condominium units are great for families and for couples who want to feel a little more at home in their accommodations. The location is ideal for all of the amenities the village has to offer. I am posting up some pictures to provide more of a visual to my review, to help those reading this review. I had a blast during my stay there and I plan to return there in the future.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: My husband was upgraded to a corner room and the view was amazing. Out one patio was a yacht club (where Gilligan's Island filmed) and Honolulu, and out the other was Waikiki and Diamond Head. The location was great for traveling around the area. My favorite part was the shops on the property. That's where we found ABC stores, and fell in love. The hotel pool was between towers and shaded early. The water at Waikiki was great, but the shore became rocky and un-walkable, even painful. The lagoon was nice to look at but freezing. We breakfasted in the VIP lounge with the most wonderful guava muffins!!! Otherwise we ate at Duke's and the Italian Table. Both scrumptious. The room was spacious, clean, and comfortable. It was hard to regulate night time temperature. There was no blanket, only a sheet and a down comforter (in Hawaii??). Overall it was a great stay.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Review of HGVC – Kalia TowerMy husband, kids and I I traveled from Philadelphia to Oahu (and later onto Kauai). We used Marriott points for our flights – a travel package including hotels at the Kauai Beach Club. We stayed at HGVC Kalia Tower in Oahu.Driving in Honolulu is extremely confusing. We drove and got slightly lost, but arrived at HGVC without a huge hitch. Check in was very easy at Kalia. We were very glad we weren’t checking into one of the other towers or hotels – it looked quite busy at the other check in area. Kalia has its own check-in area – turn right as soon as you turn into the resort – do not continue through the village. Be aware that parking is 24 dollars a day! Instead of spending that, my saintly husband parked at the Marina around the corner. This costs 25 cents (quarters ONLY – bring a LOT) per hour for a maximum of 24 hours. Be prepared to look for a spot – perhaps taking 10 minutes each time – but we always found a spot. We never ventured out in the car in the evening because we worried we wouldn’t find a spot at night. We had a one bedroom plus – meaning- ocean view (super view – though the Lagoon and Rainbow tower partially block the view – we still we were very pleased with our view and we’re hard to please in this area) Unit Features:Bedroom – Master bedroom has a king-size bed, a balcony, and a bathroom. There is one mid-sized closet in the room, along with adequate drawer space. There is a television, which we didn’t use. The bathroom a basic shower/bathtub/sink/toilet. There is a hairdryer – no need to lug your own. Toilet paper is provided.Closet – Small closet in the hall. Living/Kitchen Area – Pull out sofa, one chair, and a TV. There is a adequate sized kitchen table. The kitchen had everything a full kitchen should have.  Dishwashing liquid is provided. There is a deck with chairs off the living room.Laundry: Laundry room is down the hall – it is free and all the laundry detergent you’ll need is provided.Deck – There are 2 decks with a table and 2 chairs – 2 decks – one off the bathroom, one off the living room.. Tidy Service – One tidy service provided free of charge.Pool Area – There are 3 pools. The Kalia pool was not crowded. It is on the 4th floor – the pool was small and cold – plenty of chairs. The super pool was very nice, however you needed to reserve chairs (which I think is just an awful thing to do) by 6:30 AM for the best chairs, no later than 7:30 AM for a chair at all. I am absolutely not kidding. Then you are packed like a sardine next to the person beside you, and there is no way to move the chair to face the sun (if you’re a sun worshiper this will matter to you). The third pool was the GW pool with water slides and a small waterfall. Again, reserve chairs early – crowded. There is also the lagoon where you can put towels and lie out – but I really didn’t care for the smell of the area. The water was cold. However, there were little boats to rent, and many people seemed to be having a good time. There is a bar area by the super pool where you can order burgers and chicken fingers, along with expensive, but important on vacation, alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks. There is also a nice restaurant by the super pool (nice meaning pleasant – not fancy) where you can sit at a table and eat and drink.Beach Area – Crowded, but so big that it didn’t matter. We didn’t rent chairs or umbrellas, so I can’t give you a price. We preferred using our towels. We spent most of our time sightseeing – little time at the pools or beaches. Restaurants – There are so many – Bennihana’s (where they grill on the table – we didn’t eat there, but the prices were over 30 dollars), a sushi restaurant (mediocre), Tropics by the super pool (pleasant), pizza joints, ice cream (my kids LOVED the shaved ice) and others. The village is HUGE. I found it overwhelming and unappealing. But many people will disagree with me. I prefer a quainter (NOT less luxury – I am very into Marriott and Hilton quality), less crowded, less hustle and bustle. If you like having EVERYTHING and ANYTHING at your fingertips – you’ll love it. You can buy anything you need from bathing suits (I actually bought a nice one for a reasonable price) to food to …….. you name it! Property – Again – very, very busy. This is a village. It’s a “long” walk from Kalia Tower to the pools (long meaning it will take you 5 minutes at most). There is a gym, on the 4th floor which had ample treadmills, weights, and the like. We preferred jogging the beach, but did use it once. They asked us if we were Hilton Honors (we are) and they gave us a bracelet so it was free. I suspect if you aren’t Hilton Honors you would have to pay. The lobby is very pretty, and the staff was courteous. The concierge attempted to be helpful, but didn’t seem to really understand where we wanted to go. Her directions only got us lost.Sales/Staff – No one ever contacted us for a timeshare tour.Planned Activities – If there were any, we never saw them or saw anything about them. You can learn to surf for 90 dollars or you can walk down the beach to the left about ¼ of a mile and learn to surf for 45 dollars. We didn’t end up learning as the 45 dollar people won’t go out without 2 people – so we walked out at 9 am for nothing. There were paddle boats and kayaks for rent. Outings – We did everything on our own. I would strongly urge you to buy the book Oahu Revealed. Follow the book’s directions and you will see wonderful sights. See my picture trail below for some of the things we did and saw. We rented a car – a MUST in our opinion.Suitability: This resort is suitable for everyone. I would suggest that Kalia isn’t the best tower if you are disabled, as it’s “far” from the pool and beach. There are many kids, so if you’re looking for a quieter vacation, it may not be for you. If you’re looking for a home base with nice pools (albeit crowded) so you can sightsee – this was just fine!  Our Tours:Day One: North Shore – Follow Oahu Revealed. AMAZING beaches – fabulous sights!!! Have a ball! I strongly suggest snorkeling at Turtle Beach. We ate at Hale'iwa Joe's in the North Shore for lunch. YUM!Day Two: “Relax” at the hotel. I put quotes because we didn’t find it relaxing – too crowded. However, we got up VERY early and hiked Diamond Head. That was awesome, but not for the out of shape! July 4th fireworks with a tugger – Rick (ricoba).Day Three: East Oahu. Follow Oahu Revealed. We didn’t go to Hanauma Bay as the book suggests this day, nor did we do Diamond Head. We did these separately. We also drove out to KO olina – Marriott’s resort – to meet up with some tuggers. We much preferred this quieter resort.Day Four: Hanauma Bay – Cost 7.50 per adult. Kids 12 and under are free. Bring lots of sunscreen! You will have to wait in line and then watch a video. The snorkeling was not great at all. If you’re going there for the snorkeling, I’d skip it. It was very beautiful – and you can see it without standing in line or going down to the beach. There’s a huge hill to walk down (and then up). It was fine for us, but for those who are out of shape or disabled, there’s a very inexpensive van (75 cents down, one dollar up).Day 5: “Relax” at the hotel. We went out to dinner at Ocean House at the Outrigger which was very good. The kids loved having pictures taken with parrots. Day 6: Sailing tour. We went with Makani Catamaran (808-591-9000). You don’t see much more than the Waikki Beach, but it was very pleasant. It was only 35 dollars for 3 hours – and the kids were 2 for one. There was food (not great) and a free drink included. I do recommend this tour! Later we had dinner with a tugger (Jim – Boca Bum) at Duke’s. The food was very good!OFF TO KAUAI – Read my review of Marriott Beach Resort.See my Oahu pictures: http://www.picturetrail.com/sfx/album/view/22255025 and feel free to email me at zac495@gmail.com

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Our family stayed at the HGVC Lagoon Tower and Loved it. We had a room on the 15th floor, with awesome views of the ocean, lagoon and city. We liked returning to our room every evening, and sitting on the balcony enjoying the weather and views. From the moment we arrived, the hotel staff was very accomodating. Check in was very quick. We had a kitchen, so we were able to eat breakfast and most lunches in the room. The large refigerator also allowed us to keep adult beverages in the room. The pools were sometimes crowded, however, we spent most beach days at the ocean or lagoon. The benihana on site was good, however, did not offer a kids menu, so it was kind of crazy paying 20.00 for a kids meal. We had a car the entire stay, and utilized valet, which was expensive - but very convenient. We opted against parking next door as it seemed we always had a handful of stuff upon our return to the hotel. Loved the fact that the hotel provided a complimentary room to change after checkout, so that we could enjoy our last day at the beach/pool - since our flight wasnt scheduled to leave until 8:00 p.m. Nice military hotel next door with drinks 1/2 the price of those at the Hilton. Rooms were very quiet and free internet service at this tower.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We stayed in the Lagoon Tower from June 28 through July 8. This was a great vacation! We are HGVC owners and couldn't be happier. The staff is so friendly and they treat you great. Everyone in the Hilton Hawaiian village was friendly and helpful. If you called for towels they came right up with a smile. The property is beautiful. The new lobby is beautiful. The new pool is really beautiful. Crowded but beautiful. It was crowded for the fouth of July but still great. The fireworks were beautiful and we saw them from our lanai. Can't wait to go back. This is the best place in waikiki!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: My husband and I stayed here for part of our honeymoon. We were here 10 days staying in the Ali'i Ocean front room and I have to say, it was incredible.When we arrived - our shocking bad holiday company screwed up and cancelled our stay here (I would never recommend using Kuoni to travel with). But the staff at the Hilton Hawaiian were amazing and did everything they could to honour our booking and put us in the room we booked. As we left to settle in our room, they gave us complimentary vouchers for 4 dinners at their restaurant (which I will review on here).When we checked in, the room was stunning, HUGE, spacious, clean with beautiful flowers and fresh fruit. It was dark, so we couldn't see out. The next morning, we rushed to our balcony and got a view that just took our breathe away. From then on.. our holiday got better and better and I can honestly say that this was helped greatly by a stunning hotel with incredible facilities.Also, it is the other side of Waikiki which means that the beaches by the hotel are not anywhere near as packed.. and was still in walking distance - along the beach off course - to the main shopping and busy beach areas. Personally, I was happy just to lounge around and enjoy the area I was in.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We arrived Wednesday, July 1st. Today is July 3rd! If I'm disgruntled enough to write this after TWO DAYS... well, you get the picture! Staying on the 12th floor of the Lagoon Tower. BOTH nights so far, they have held private parties on THE GROUND below and behind the Lagoon Tower. Music SO LOUD, I couldn't HEAR the TV... TWELVE FLOORS UP! Tried calling Hotel Management at 8 p.m. THEY DIDN'T ANWSER AFTER TWENTY (20) RINGS!!! IF YOU ARE LOOKING TO RELAX IN HONOLULU...DO NOT STAY HERE!!!!!!!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: My husband and I along with our four children ages 5, 14 (twins) and 17 have just returned from 9 nights stay at the Grand Vacations Club. We had a two bedroom unit in the Lagoon Tower. The unit was great - neat and clean and in great condition. Beds were comfy, kitchen had everything we could want and our room was serviced daily. The resort itself was beautiful - beautiful gardens, great pools (our 5 year old loved the water slides at the lagoon tower pool). At the time of our stay there were no renovations being undertaken which was great. Towels were available at the pool area so we need not have brought our beach towels from home. The resort is right on the beach which is great. The only draw back about the resort is the distance from the main shopping /restaurant district of Waikiki but it really wasnt a problem as it is only a 15 minute walk along the beach which is beautiful or a quick trolley ride. The trolleys being $2 a person each way so with 6 of us it was costly but we chose a mixture of walking and trolley riding. Considering how good the resort was I would stay there again even considering that it is down the other end of the beach. We ate several times at Tropics bar and grill and found the food to be great quality although pricey and menu not overly extensive. I would like to mention that the Friday night show we thought was pretty average and there is no way I would pay $15 a person to see it. If you get there early you can sit for free to the side at the pool bar tables and see everything for free which is what I would recommend (and what we did). Staff were helpful and overall we had a super time. I would recommend the Grand Vacations Club at the Hilton Hawaiian Village to all. One last thing the resort is close to Ala Moana Shopping Centre which is great - 10 minute walk or short trolley ride. Convenience store is in the village which was great. Free wireless internet was included in room price which was also great.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We had a great time at the HGV club Grand Waikikian, we went on a package deal to visit the timeshare so we got a great price. My husband, daughter and I upgraded to a 2 bedroom, 2 bath for $1600. for 6 days, 7 nights. What a fabulous resort and room. We were in room 1502, a corner unit on the ala moana side. We had a fabulous view of the ocean and city. From other reviews on this site we opted to park off site at the marina parking, just past the entry way to the Grand Waikikian.
