It is metered, but you can pay 72 hours at a time at it is only $6. per 24 hours, the attendant is great if you are a little late and will help you out. The Hilton is $24 a night for standard parking and $29 for valet, you can get the full week for the rate at the offsite vs. just one night at Waikikian. I was a little concerned as the meter asks you to put in a parking space #, but it doesn't matter where you are parked as long as your tag is valid still. We came back early on Friday, around 10 and our space was paid for till 1, we didnt' want to have to run back out, so talked to the attendant and he hand wrote us a ticket through Saturday morning, so we woulnt have to pay for more time than was necessary. We went to Maui and stayed at the Sheraton Black Rock right after the visti at the Grand Waikikian and really noticed what a difference the hotel and staff at the Grand Waikikian made. While the Sheraton was nice, the Hilton blew it away in accomodations. The restaurants are very expensive at the village, but the Foodland at the Ala Moana mall, by Sears, is a great way to go. We did spend a lot of money at the ABC store, but the mall was great to stock up on the weekly groceries. If you want to go to the fitness center we only found one on the entire property, the Kalia building. It was nice, but surprised this was the only fitness center. I have to say we loved the facilities and ended up buying at the lagoon tower as we love hilton and felt that the timeshare was a great value.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: My husband, 2 children ages 6 & 8, and I stayed in a one bedroom unit in the Lagoon tower on the 23rd floor. The unit was very clean and well appointed. The kitchen was a nice size with an electric stove/oven, microwave, dishwasher, toaster, rice maker, and full size refrigerator. There were dishes, flatware, and glassware for a party of 4. They had the normal kitchen neccessities (spatulas, serving spoons, wine opener, etc.) and even a teflon frying pan (I think they knew I was coming). The living/dining area had a large dining table and a sofa bed that was the most comfortable sofa bed I had ever encountered. We also requested a rollaway which was in great shape and comfortable. The bedroom had a king bed that was also very, very comfortable. Our unit did not have a washer/dryer, but each floor has a laundry room to use free of charge. The tower seemed to be well built as we never heard much noise from other units. Everyone we encountered was very pleasant and helpful. We valet parked our car ($29/day) and our usual wait was around 7 minutes. One perk to valet parking the car was that there were free leis and black bead necklaces available. The property is huge with restaurants, shops, pools, beach, lagoon, penguins, and flamingos. The restaurants were a bit pricey, but the property is walking distance to many other dining options. Our main disappointment with two younger children was that the pools were freezing cold. Only one day did we find the paradise pool to be warm. Our first three days there were overcast and cool, so we didn't use much of a feature of a hotel that we enjoy most after a day of sightseeing. It was also hard to find an available chair near the paradise pool.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: My husband and I are HGVC owners and brought my parents and brother and sister-in-law to Oahu for a week. We chose the Lagoon Tower at the Hilton Hawaiian Village for our stay. We reserved one two bedroom and one studio. This was our first use of vacation points and we did a great deal of research before reserving and arriving. In addition, all but one of us had been to Oahu several times.We were impressed with the Lagoon Tower. It is a great location, right on Waikiki Beach. The tower is clean and nicely decorated. Staff was pleasant and check-in was simple and expedient. Our room was lovely, not Four Seasons luxurious, but very nice with two bedrooms, two baths, a good-sized, well-stocked kitchen, flat-screen television with DVD player, dining area, televisions in both bedrooms and two spacious, full bathrooms. Our lanai was fantastic. We stayed on the 18th floor and had a lovely ocean view (which we had reserved). We looked over the lagoon and the beach/ocean beyond.I must address other comments as I have read many on this site. I understand construction can be quite bothersome. Luckily, the HHV seems to be done with this phase. The lagoon/swimming pool is complete, so should not be an issue anymore. I always suggest that this is something that people who are travelling should ask about. I am a world traveller and have lived overseas for almost eight years. These are questions that must be asked when you book! In addition, in a "timeshare" situation like the Lagoon Tower or other HGVC properties - maid service is not available every night. If you are staying at least seven days, they clean your room once. Just as if you were renting a home or condo, maid service is not every day. Having said that, all we had to do to have someone collect our trash or request extra towels was make a quick call to guest services and voila...trash collected and new towels within minutes.We truly enjoy the freedom that renting a superior "condo" allows us...we can prepare our own meals, saving money and frustration. We have somewhere to relax other than our hotel beds. It was nice and refreshing. The property is huge with access to all Village shopping, swimming pools, and acitivites. We made use of a couple of the pools and were not disappointed. If one was busy we went to the next, or just enjoyed the beach. If it is too busy, head to the Northshore - beautiful area!In addition, people should realize that it is not the fault of Hilton that Oahu and specifically Waikiki Beach is busy - this is what it is. If you are looking for a tropical paradise, you should do more research and stay on one of the other islands like Maui or Kauai. Oahu is busy and crowded on the Waikiki Beach/Honolulu side. It is commercial and noisy, although there are still beautiful parts on the Windward and Northshore parts of the Island.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: This was our 2nd stay at HGVC. On our 1st trip, our family of 5 enjoyed a 10 day stay in the Lagoon Tower. This time we traveled with extended family ( a total of 10, ages 11-70yr.) We chose this location because there is something for everyone. You never have to leave with all the shops, restaurants, pools & beautiful beach. Like others have said, if your looking for quiet and seclusion this is not the place for you. This time, we stayed in the new Grand Waikikian tower. We had 3 units between the 10 of us, each with a full kitchen & washer/dryer(nice feature). The units are brand new and beautifully decorated but are smaller than the Lagoon Tower & it is further away from the beach. The new Lagoon area is beautiful & great for families with small children. There is also a new heated pool with waterslides that the kids enjoyed. The only problem with that pool is that it receives very little sunlight (blocked by Lagoon Tower). We new the expense of chairs/umbrellas, so for the extra $25 dollars(to check an extra bag) we brought our own chairs, sand toys, beach tubes and snorkel gear in a golf bag. Towels are provided free of charge at many different locations in the resort. Our cars were always ready, bellmen always available and requests for blankets, etc met quickly. We only went to breakfast a few times, since we had a full kitchen and the buffet is around $29/person. We never ate dinner in the village, it is also quite expensive and there are more affordable options within walking distance, by trolley($2) or a short cab ride away. We enjoy this place because it is also great for our children, ages 11, 14 & 17 and safe. They can walk together to get an ice cream, a shaved ice, hotdog, sandwich, pizza, cold drink, etc. without leaving the resort. The 2 oldest were able to walk to a Subway & McDonald's across the street. We even walked back(at night) from further down Waikiki after a night of shopping (3-4 blocks of high end stores). If you have teenagers, bring lots of money!! Our parents enjoyed the many beautiful outside areas to sit, the shops, well- maintained grounds and the beach. Every Friday night is a great free show at the Superpool ending with fireworks(get there early to get a good spot). Our only complaint was at check in. We arrived on a Tuesday(after a 12 hour flight) & when we checked in, they had put us in different towers. We had members of our family with significant medical issues & one who became very ill on the flight. It took over an hour to get us all in one tower but on different floors. We were also to have a "garden view", it was a noisy "city view" on the 6th floor. The next morning, I left my cell number for a manager to call me. At noon, I went back down & with polite persistence was able to speak with one. Due to the unexpected illness of a family member I needed to be closer to them. I also mentioned my disappointment with our "garden view". Around 4pm, I received a call that we could move to the same floor as my family & we had been upgraded to an oceanfront room on the 32nd floor with spectacular views. We would definitely stay here again-a great family resort! We have been on cruises to the Caribbean, Disney, Arizona and other beach vacations & this is our 3rd trip back to Hawaii as a family & our favorite!(last year we stayed in Maui-beautiful but quiet). We walked along the beach to see the other hotels(some don't even have a beach area) & were quite happy with our choice. Also take the time to enjoy the rest of this beautiful island.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: If you are looking at booking at the Hilton Hawaiian Village -note that only the Lagoon Tower and Grand Waikikian are the timeshare / condo units. The other towers (Rainbow, Alii, Tapa, Diamond, etc), are traditional hotel rooms. This review is about our stay in the Lagoon Tower. I read a lot of the reviews before booking this hotel, and am SOOOOOO glad that we were able to get into the Lagoon Tower. We were able to book a 1BR condo thru the hilton.com website, for the same price as many of the regular hotel rooms at HHV.Pros of staying in Lagoon Tower that differed from what I read about staying in the non-"vacation club" towers:1- each floor has free laundry facilities and they provide detergent2 - in room internet and wireless are free3 - no charge for coffee4 - no charge for safe5 - we were here for a week; having a full kitchen, seperate bedroom (so we could stay up while our 3yr old slept), and large LR/DR area was very comfortable.6 - service was excellent: we requested a rollaway bed at check-in, and it was delivered within 5 min of us walking in our door. We requested extra blankets later in the stay - again delivered fast. 7 - free DVD rentals and a "book exchange" available through the concierge 8 - tower is closest to Ala Moana mall (easy walk even for my 3yr old), where there is a Foodland supermarket for mainland priced groceries, and plenty of shopping. Since we had a full kitchen we saved tons by having breakfast on our own balcony and picnic lunches by the lagoon or beach, and could spend more on dinners. If it's too far for you to walk there are ABCs all over or you can take the trolley or bus.9 - We never got grief about pool/beach towels: just walked up and asked for as many as we needed.10 - 42" LCD tv in the living room! it's bigger than ours at home! DVD player too.11 - No line-up at check-in, complimentary macadamia nut chocolates, and fresh flower leis.Cons: none that I can mention specific to the Lagoon Tower. Some comments in general about the hotel property:- it's HUGE. If you want private quiet seclusion, go somewhere else. - restaurants are pricey, but we only ate on property once (the Rainbow Sat night buffet) and it was worth it. $29 ocean front dinner buffet (with coupon they give you at check-in), with lots of seafood, fresh fruits and local cuisine, desserts, even a chocolate fountain for making your own smores or choc dipped strawberries. Plus our 3yr old ate for free :) That's a pretty good deal for anywhere in Hawaii where dining is always pricey.- grounds are beautiful and have lots of nature to entertain the kids: penguin/turtle feeding every morning, flamingos, koi ponds, ibis, maccaws.- Lagoon is excellent for younger kids as the water is wave-free. If you prefer the ocean it's just past the lagoon. Plenty of pools if you prefer that.- beach chairs and umbrellas are rent/day: $15 and $30 each per day! Just go to Walmart (across from Ala Moana mall), and buy your own for the week at $10 and $9 each.- Free fireworks every Friday night - excellent display - made even better by how close you are to the actual launch site.- Wed/Sun luaus on property: based on guide recces we bussed out to Germaine's luau (well worth it), but we did picnic take-out dinners on the lagoon beach to enjoy the music and show of the hotel luau. Much better than sharing a table with 10 strangers and paying $90/head to do so (plus we heard the hotel luau food was mediocre).-parking is expensive, $24/nt. We cabbed from the airport ($35 for a limo), and rented a car for a couple days thru National (used Costco discount and car class upgrades) for $28/day. The National lot is less than 1/4 mile walk from the lagoon tower and open 7am-8pm, so we just returned the car to them at the end of the day instead of paying for Hilton's parking lot.We were here for a conference combined with family vacation. We'd stay here again while we have young kids and could get in to one of the condo units.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: In an earlier review of this property (2006), I had given it high marks for what is essentially an urban resort on a beach. Back then it seemed well run with the occasional long wait, but it was always clean, courteous, and well maintained. We are HGVC owners and we we return every year at Christmas week. it seems this year something has gone wrong. Even though there are way fewer guests than in previous years, the staff seems very sparse and overworked (with the exception of the HGVC sales personnel, who are on overdrive trying to sell more units). Yes, the new refurbished lagoon is now open and most of the construction seems to be done, but when it comes down to it, the difference between an aggravating and pleasant experience often rests on the shoulders of competent and adequate staffing.To be specific, when we arrived to check in at Kalia tower, there was no valet parker, no bell hop to help us with our 3 suitcases and 3 backbacks and baby gear, and a line of 8-9 cars just sitting in the driveway with a bunch short-tempered people trying to get in and out. We had to circle around a couple times because there was simply no way to sit there double-parked and unload our car without blocking people in. When we checked-in we were told there was no luggage rack either, so we had to drag all our stuff (with small children) ourselves. It's not that we minded the work, but it is a very different experience than in previous years when we only had to wait 5-10 minutes until a bell-hop came by. We had to leave our car keys with front-desk until someone could come by and park our car.The Mandara Spa facilities, which usually are clean and well-run, also seemed to be suffering. The shower drains were so clogged, I was ankle deep (wearing spa sandals) after about a 6 minute shower. With other people's hair floating around my ankles! The wet-sauna was unusable (broken) and some of the post-shower amenities (hairspray, brushes, etc. were either missing or unreplenished. But the masseuse and facialist both were as excellent as before.Our room had a terrible stink of mildew coming from the bathroom and the hardwood floors had a gritty, dirty residue (the bottoms of our bare feet would turn dark grey after walking around the room). I had liked that these rooms were usually perfectly clean, so this was disappointing. In past years when encountering workers at Lagoon and Kalia HGVC buildings or on the grounds, they would usually greet us and let us pass. This year they pretend they don't see us or other guests and amble along at their tired pace dragging their cart or equipment, ignoring the crowd of people building up behind them. I don't blame them if they do more then their usual share and are tired, but I have to say that this isn't the 'luxury' or even solidly competent resort service I have grown accustomed to at this property.It is still a great location, but if you come in the next couple of months, don't have very high hopes. For whatever reason, this is not the place it used to be.Addendum: my brother is an owner in the Grand Waikikian and he was sorely disappointed by how slip-shod the quality control was. The washer-dryer malfunctioned, the dishwasher needed to be repaired. He and his wife had to spend hours of their vacation getting people to come fix these things again and again (they didn't fix it the first or second time).

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: I booked with Expedia to travel from Manchester (Uk ) to OAHU which took in 3 flights each way , Man to Chicago to La to Oahu and back with American Airlines and I was a little worried beforehand because of the changes , but it went like clockwork and I had all the boarding passes for my party of 5 pre-printed at Manchester , we just booked our luggage in there and didn't see it again til OAHU , the flights were great and whilst there is little entertainment on AA planes they are nice and new and safe looking , if you know what I mean . So after 22 hours we arrived in OAHU and we had booked Charlies CAbs online to pick us up , again perfect , they were there waiting for us and whisked us to the Lagoon Tower . WOW , what a place . As mentioned in other reviews they are the business , we had a 2 bedroom overlooking the Lagoon and the Ocean and it had everything , all free as well apart from the coffee which had to be purchased each day . Washing machine and dryer on the landing was free as well . Rooms were breathtaking with the view , as we overlooked the party area we were treated to many shows whilst sitting on our balcony sipping a beer or two which we bought from the ABC shop . The Hilton charge approx $8 a beer plus tip whilst they sell it on site for $12 for 12 cans , pop in your fridge and away you go . Food is samey and dear , our party regulary spent $150 + for a burger meal each with a beer and 1 afters , eating at the Hilton was out unless we ate sandwiches so we walked to the Outrigger ( next hotel down ) and had many meals there , spectacular views and nice prices and nice walk . The Hilton is right at one end of Waikiki but the walk into town is brill , nice places to eat and drink there ( Planet Hollywood etc ) and top shops . We jumped the bus to the Aloa Moana centre ( $2 each and 4 stops down the road ) where we shopped a lot and drank a lot , top place . Waikiki itself is a place of contrasts , the beach is Ok , no powder white sand but good enough and the water is Ok , not blue but green , in some places it is fab in others not so . Can't take beer onto beach , must have ID on you to buy it even if you look 78 years old , can't smoke hardly anywhere even outside, unfriendly staff with no sense of humour who cant speak English , it felt sometimes like a police state gone mad . Weather in Oct was a nice high 80's if the sun was out and 70's at night , we stayed for 12 days and had 8 good ones for sitting on the beach . $15 a chair or $30 an umbrella a day take your fancy ? thought not , get along to Wallmart and buy them for $7 each . There are lots of nice places to snorkle and swim and dive etc , Waikiki is not one of them by a long shot . Surfing looked OK if you liked being anti-social , not one of them spoke to us as they walked past with their boards , they were always on there own and not one of them ever smiled , I don't know what it is about surfing but it must be better than it looks . There is no coral to snorkle over and the tides are really strong so there is nothing to see off Waikiki apart from grey sludge. It is ok to walk along and it is nice and romantic but if you are after South Pacific beaches then be prepared to travel or try another island, but be warned that , as with LA , there are people begging on the beach as it is public and they will ask you for spare $'s or cigs as they sleep rough every night due to the warm weather , they are not threatening or pushy , just a nice enquiry every now and then but the problem does exist and is off-putting . Other hotels looked nice but their beaches were tiny , it was a hop skip and a jump into reception from the water's edge , at the Hilton they have a large beach area and a gorgeous Lagoon which is fresh waterish and man made with fish etc to swim on and is safe for kids . As the holiday wore on we noticed that the island is set up for the large influx of Japanese visitors and all the main shops are staffed by Japenese staff , they do not like it if you browse and ask to look at something but don't end up buying , it was a little cheap being hassled in the hotel shops because I wanted to know a price of an item but was not interested in buying when I was told the hugely inflated price , the contempt in the guy's face was quite something . It was the same all over the island , if you look and dont buy be prepared to kick the door down to get out of the shop. This gets annoying after about 1 day . We tripped out to Pearl Harbour , got there at 8.30am and stayed for 3 hours , it wasn't too busy and was a nice way to see the Harbour and the Arizona Memorial which was moving . We booked at the Hotel and no doubt payed a little more than we should have but we felt safer doing so . So to sum up , Expedia were magic , AA were great , Hotel was fab but really expensive , beach and water was not as advertised in the brochures and the vagrants and beach bums were a shock , Honolulu is mainly Japanese orientated an was extremely up-market and the food was burgers or starve and as long as you followed the 1001 rules and regs of the Island then all was OK , so all in all I would rate this as a 6/10 holiday , wouldn't go again but glad I did to see it for myself .

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: This hotel was the busiest hotel I have ever stayed at. There was a long line just to check in ...thank goodness for the Hilton Honors line. It's like a little town in and of itself. It's very hectic yet fun...we came from four nights in Kauai and were a little shocked at the congestion and the crowds. But we are city people and loved being back in the swing of things. You literally don't have to leave this village at all...there is shopping, eating and pools pools and more pools. We stayed in the Rainbow Tower. Great views...2 balconies in our room. The room as just ok --- no frills, basic room with a small bathroom. Carpet was a little dirty but the bed was the standard Hilton bed. Food was outrageously expensive ($14 burger) at the grill by the pool, and the bfast buffet was nothing to write home about. The noodle shop in the village was tasty and cheap. We ventured to many sushi stops outside of the village. It was a nice stay. I would stay again because I like the hustle and bustle of the hotel. If you don't like crowds, noise and people, then stay away.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We stayed at the HHV Lagoon tower in May 08 as a timeshare vacation exchange and had a fantastic time. The rooms are absolutley beautiful. These are timeshare units so they have everything you could possibly need. We stayed in a 1 bedroom lagoon view room. View was awesome of the newly renovated Duke Kahanamoku Lagoon. Full kitchen, comfy bed, large sofa bed, upscale tropical furnishings, free washer/dryers on each floor. These are like the apartment you wish you could have in Hawaii! Staff is super nice and helpful. Concierge desk in lobby as well as complimentary juice in the mornings. Super pool is very refreshing and there was always a chair. Beach fronting the hotel is great. Now you will find better beaches around the island but this is the perfect Waikiki Beach. Not too crowded but not isolated. Couple of different stands for beach rentals that were actually reasonably priced! ABC store on property as well as luxury shopping like Louis Vuitton, Prada and Dior. It is a busy resort but we never felt like part of a herd or anything. The only issue I had was the parking. The $$$ was outrageous. Now we vacation in Hawaii several times a year and I know that every single resort/hotel charges for parking as it is outsourced but the HHV was almost double what we normally pay. The gentlemen working the valet are always courteous and willing to give any info needed though. As I said, this is a beautiful resort and we will definitley stay here again.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: My sister owns one of the time shares in the Lagoon Tower so she was nice enough to let me and mom stay with her during her vacation with her and her husband. First let me just say that you never need to even leave the hotel area - everything is right there on the grounds. From great food to shopping at Dior! It's all right in the complex. There are 4 towers in the hotel. Our hotel, the Lagoon Tower was a bit back from the beach and was behind a small man made lagoon that you could swim in. There were baby baby fish in the water but they didn't bother you. There are several outside bars to have a drink at with live entertainment! The grounds are beautiful with coy ponds and flamingos. The beach was a short walk away and they were always nice and clean. In the hotel there is a mini store that is stocked with anything you could need. Every morning there were pitchers of ice cold lemon water or a fruity guava drink (boy I miss that) waiting in the lobby. Each floor also has its own washers and dryers. I loved that because I hate to go home with a suitcase of dirty clothes. The balcony was very spacious with a table and chairs. The condo had a kitchen, a livingroom, two bedrooms and 2 baths. The master had a queen size bed and the guest room had 2 twin beds. All very clean. Diamond Head is visible from the Rainbow Tower and from the beach.The grounds had lots of sitting areas, bars, an ice cream palor, a pizzeria, a small diner like restaurant with alcohol and many many many shops. The street that the hotel is on looks like Rodeo Drive if you go down 1/4 mile. Everything from Gucci to Ferragamo. Planet Hollywood to Cheeseburgers in Paradise. They had it all. There were also cheaper stores for souveniers.We had breakfast and dinner at the Rainbow Lanai restaurant. We sat right next to the coy pond that runs along side of the place. True relaxing paradise! OK now for the things I didn't like. The place is so expensive it is really ridiculous! I paid $15 each DAY for a chair and $30 a DAY for an umbrella to sit by the lagoon! The reason why they said is because the state owns the small part by the lagoon and that it is a public piece of property. I liked the lagoona area better than the pool or the beach because it was quiet and not many people were there so I paid. I also didn't like the fact that their pools are so so small! That place is huge - you think they would have more pool space. (Slightly larger than a person's in ground backyard pool). The pool didn't seem that clean to me either..kind of slimy. However the chairs were free there but too crowded for me. At the end of the stay they charged $280 for parking and room taxes. For 6 days of parking I thought that was a bit much. Also while we were there construction was going on and it woke us up at 6:30am every morning and the view from the room in the back was all construction! Things I think you should see while staying in Oahu.Waikiki BeachHave breakfast at the Outrigger Hotel (short drive away and only $10 a head)Visit the aquarium -the zoo was a waste of timeGo to Diamond HeadEat at the Top of Waikiki Restaurant (it is a revolving restaurant) the food is awesome and well priced.Drive to the North shore where they surfWe rented a car and drove all the way up the coast & around-(beautiful)Go on the Cattamaran at the Outrigger HotelWould I reccommend this place- YES! It is a wonderful place to go if you have the money to spend. To me, Hawaii was in once in a lifetime chance so it was worth every penny spent!If you like check out my photos on Flickr under people. Carole Hawaii08The pictures are of Oahu and The Big Island.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: The Hilton Hawaiian Village has become our annual wedding anniversary trip the past 4-5 years. Our last three stay have been at the Lagoon Tower, and as usual, it was a great escape, check in a breeze, staff alway friendly, Norman the valet always greeted us by name and with a smile each time we arrived and departed. Ted and Kacey at the Tropics and Hua Tree bar, I consider aloha embasadors of the Hilton Hawaiian Village, they are always upbeat, friendly and they always ensured our needs were met. Though the construction for the Grand Waikikian and the adjacent pool is on going, it was not an issue. Our room was listed as a garden view, but it over looked the great lawn, lagoon and the ocean beyond. Matter of fact it was only one lanai over from our room last year that was listed as ocean view. The room contained everything we requred, it was well kept and clean. Since we were there for ten nights we received two room cleanings instead of one, which is what you get when you stay for a week. The grounds were beautiful as usual, the recently renovated lagoon turned out great, last year it was just a big construction pit, and the years prior to that it was a mucky body of water no one would dare swim in. Now the lagoon is great place to lay out, and a nice place for the little ones, warm, calm, clean water. Even though the Hilton beach is not crowded compared to the rest of the Waikiki beaches, the lagoon is also a nice place if you want to be a little more isolated from the number of folks on the beach. Yes, the food, drink and parking are expensive at the village, we utilized the ABC stores and Sam's Club to stock our room for our stay. To me parking is the extremly over priced, but we know this ahead of time and include it in our budget. There are plenty of options out side of the village for food, drink and parking. A car rental is a must, even if for just one day. A drive around the island, over to the north shore, have lunch at one of the numerous shrimp trucks, stop at Hanauma Bay, Waimea, Haleiwa and numerous other places. It is a nice relaxing change to get away from city for a day. We're already making our plans for next year, can't wait to go back!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Our family of five (three children 12 and under) stayed in a 2BR at the Lagoon Tower at the Hilton Hawaiian Village (the Grand Vacations Club tower) because we wanted the central location and the on-site amenities of the Hilton Hawaiian Village and we weren't able to guarantee adjoining rooms in the other (hotel) towers.The timeshare/condo we stayed in was beautiful, new, well-appointed and spacious. My favorite part was waking up (early...we were still on EST) and seeing the surfers at dawn on Waikiki Beach from the balcony of our room(s). One word of caution is that many of the "extras" at the HHV are pretty expensive. In addition to the $25 (or more?) daily parking fee...it costs $40 for a beach chair (per day, but no partial day rates available) ($200 total per day for beach chairs for five!); $20 per 1/2 hour for a kayak on the lagoon; $90 pp (plus tip) for a 2 hour surfing lesson; $20 pp for a lei-making lesson. We realized when we went off-property that the prices were lower elsewhere on Waikiki Beach (even at other hotels) and much lower elsewhere on Oahu.To be fair, we also enjoyed the free extras. The kids really enjoyed the penguins and the penguin and turtle feedings. We were disappointed to find that the Bishop Museum no longer has a small site on the property of the HHV.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Rooms are always clean and comfortable. Good views of Diamond Head and the beach.Great location, close to every thing you need, also easy to get in and out of down town.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We had a terrific stay at the Hilton Grand Vacation Club last week. The 2 bedroom unit was beautifully decorated and we were on the 19th floor and had an incredible view of the ocean. The kitchen was well stocked - even though we didn't do any cooking. The only negative was that there are no bbq's at the resort - as we like to cook in occassionally.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: My new husband and I had the opportunity to stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village for our honeymoon from January 5th through the 12th of this year. I must say, after reading some of the reviews on this resort, I was extremely anxious to arrive to either confirm or deny the comments of other travelers. I am happy to report that our stay at the resort was met with pure optimism and an amazing experience.We arrived at the Hilton late in the evening on a Saturday after a long flight from New Jersey. My parents are Hilton Grand Vacation Club members, and were gracious enough to give us their timeshare for our honeymoon as a wedding present. Therefore, we stayed in the Lagoon Tower. When we got off the shuttle, our bags were taken immediately to our hotel room without hesitation nor pressure to be tipped. We were guided to our tower and immediately checked in without any problems. I had heard on this site that the resort was currently under construction in certain areas, which is true. We were lucky to be placed in a room on the 14th floor facing the lagoon and the ocean instead of that. We had a fantastic view from our room, where we were able to see almost the entire resort as well as the water. The room was very clean, as well as the balcony. My only complaint concerning the room was the bathroom, where I was expecting a separate tub and shower after staying in other 1 bedroom condos through Hilton in the past. However, this is not a necessity.The places to eat in the resort can be very expensive. However, with the location of the Hilton being in the midst of Waikiki, dining options are endless outside of the resort. I would recommend dining at Bali at the Sea in the Hilton, due to the quality of both the service as well as the food. It isn't cheap, but if you go at 6pm Monday through Thursday, ask for the Sunset Dinner Special, where you receive a special menu with dining entrees at a reduced price. As for the resort itself, it has absolute character and appeal. I found it to be absolutely beautiful, whether you were at the beach or on the sidewalk on Kalia Ave. The service was fantastic. We were always greeted whether we were arriving or leaving our tower in the resort. Questions were always addressed on the spot and handled accordingly. I would definitely recommend this resort for couples despite past reviews saying it is more family oriented. Vacations are what you make out of them. Yes, there were families with small children at the resort during our stay, but in no way did it hinder our awesome experience.I must say that I'd been monitoring the progress of the construction around the Lagoon Tower since reading reviews about this in the summer, but for the most part the construction has pretty much passed. The lagoon itself is completed and gorgeous. The Grand Waikikian, which is the new tower in the resort, is diagonal and behind the Lagoon Tower, so it does not create an eye soar. If you book the timeshare for a week in Hawaii, do yourself a favor and request for a room with a lagoon view. Mention that your vacation is a special occasion of some sort (i.e. honeymoon, anniversary, significant birthday celebration...anything), and this will increase your chance of having a room with a view.  If you're looking for an active honeymoon full of activity as well as relaxation, the Hilton Hawaiian Village and Lagoon Tower will provide just that! Enjoy!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: I used my timeshare points as I own a different HGVC in California. Lucked out and booked on someone elses cancellation for New Year's eve.At first glance the place is impressive and continued to impress. The prices at the shops and eateries are steep but so is everything else on Waikiki beach.Stayed in a studio in the Lagoon tower, only paid my booking fee of $49 plus room tax o $7 (total of $56)for 4 nights as I already purchased the timeshare. Used 1300 points. The studio was right next to the elevator so i worried, but no noise!!! A little bit of construction noise in the am as they are building right next door but overall very, very delightful.You use all the hotel property as it is adjacent, two minute stroll.The staff was great, brought towels and toiletries right away as we had no maid service in the timeshare rooms.Fun shows at night on the weekend, easy airline check-in kiosks, easy pick-up for tours as the HHV was always the first picked up and the first dropped off.They also suggested a hospitality room on our last day as we had 10am checkout but did not fly out til late at night. They gave us 40 minutes in a room to shower and change after our day. We also had our luggage brought up to the hospitality room so we could pack souveniers we bought and get clean clothes.All in all, a great experience!!!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: The Vacation Club is a nice alternative to the Hilton Hotel at Waikiki. It is on the same property but is based in its own 23 story building. If you can afford to pay $60 more than the cheaper hotels in Waikiki, this one offers a lot of comfort and convenient access to the beach. The car parking is expensive at $26.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: The hotel is big. There are a number of different hotel blocks, shops, swimming pools, restaurants and bars. If you like spectacular sea views of Waikiki, then you need to stay in Rainbow Tower, preferably on the upper floors e.g. 28 to 31, and sea facing so room numbers with 00's e.g. 001Pro's: The hotel has everything. Shops, pools, entertainment especially on friday night with fireworks, restaurants and is located at the beginning of Waikiki beach. The staff are very friendly and helpful.Con's: The restaurants are expensive. Continental breakfast is $20 and $26 if you want a hot one. Drinks are expensive with a beer costing $7.59 a bottle for Stella Artois. Want to rent a beach umbrella? That's $31 a day. Internet access? How about $12 per day or $18 if you need VPN. I tried looking for free sites and it was difficult. Parking is $20 per day.Tips: Use the ABC stores which are located in the village and all over Waikiki. Eat out. There are lots of good, cheaper restaurants than what's available at the hotel. I recommend Top of Waikiki, which I thought was going to be expensive but turned out ok. It's a rotating restaurant. The Cheesecake factory is also reasonable but be prepared to wait 50 mins for a table.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We stayed here through RCI. We did 5 nights in Oahu, 5 on Big Island and 5 on Kauai.The hotel is part of a LARGE Hilton complex there. We also stayed in the Rainbow tower (which in my opinion was even better).This hotel is located close to the airport (not close enough to see or here thank goodness) and has a HUGE about of shops, restaurants, bars, swimming pools - the long and the short it's got everything!The location is right in town but on the beach. Easy access to everything though we found we couldn't live without a hire car to really get out and see everything (don't forget your US Sat nav - it will work if it's half decent!)The beach is real nice, they do tours off a pier there too. They gave us free wifi too which was very useful. Te grounds to the hotel are very well kept, they have nice ponds and waterfalls and you can have breakfast next to some rather hungry carp!My only gripes were valet parking was horribly expensive ($25 a night!) and the self parking wasn't much different.I'd definitely stay here again, though if you have the choice, Rainbowtower is better (Ocean facing too). Oh and try Roundtable Pizza on thegrounds - v good imo :-)

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Stayed in the Lagoon tower for 5 nights. With tax, the nightly charge was $360. We had a one bedroom condo promoted as having an ocean view. Coming in from the curb late in the evening involved walking up a few steps with many suitcases. There is no convenient ramp to bring the wheeled cases up. Check-in was reasonably quick. Our room was on the side of the hotel, so there was indeed an ocean view...if you walked out onto the balcony and turned to the right. There was not an ocean view out the window of the unit.The tower faces the rainbow tower on one side, but the rainbow tower has an outdoor bar with fairly loud music until 10 or so each night. So you get to hear loud music instead of calm ocean breezes. The alternative, on the other side, faces a construction area and parking lot. For the week we were there, there was little construction work going on, and therefore little construction noise. The room itself is perfectly comfortable and well stocked with kitchen appliances and accessories. It isn't luxurious, but is perfectly comfortable. There is a pullout couch in the living room and a queen bed in the single bedroom. The bath is accessible to either room without anyone having to go through the other bedroom area. Housekeeping was excellent and the staff was friendly and accommodating. Checkout was quick and accurate. Overall, it was a perfectly comfortable and convenient location, but I don't think it had the luxury and relaxation factors one would expect for the price point.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Hilton Grand Vacation ClubLagoon Tower Oahu HIReviewer: Mark and Irene Bryant, Ogden, UTDate: Oct. 13-20 2007We have just returned from a week at the HGVC Hilton Hawaiian Village, Lagoon Tower, Oahu, HI. The resort is magnificent and we have never experienced such incredible service before. We took three other couples with us, to celebrate Renewal Of Vows - 25 Yrs Anniversary. . We stayed at the Lagoon Tower with its own concierge . We enjoyed the Saturday evening Show at the Pool. My husband had a massage a tThe Spa in the Kalia Tower, and we enjoyed the fittness center.Restaurants are great. Our daughter who performed the ceremony also made up the flowers, and the flower shop was very helpful Room service provided our reception platter.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: I bought into the Hilton Timeshare system through Florida and used my points to reserve a 2 bedroom / 2 bathroom room at the Grand Vacations Club - Lagoon Tower portion of the hotel. The room was wonderful. They have free internet, free coffee, free laundry including the detergent and the room was quite and always comfortable.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: stayed here for a week. traded a friend for a week at my marriott time share deal. great living space. be aware construction begins at 7am and it is LOUD! I would wait to stay here in about a year or so once the lagoon is completed. Staff is courteous, hilton still one of the better hotels, VERY Crowded. It was great for my attendance at a conference so we were up early but not for a relaxing time...try maui....

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We are new owners, bought one week HGVC in Las Vegas in Sept 2006. This was our first HGVC vacation. Being new to the whole reservation bit we dilly dallied until March to make our reservation. At that late date we were not able to get 7 consecutive nights in the Lagoon Tower. We could only get 4 nights in the HGVC Lagoon Tower and converted our remaining HGVC points into Hilton Honors points and reserved the other 3 nights in the Hilton Hawaiian Village (Tapa Tower). We reserved a 2 bedroom ocean front premier suite in the HGVC Lagoon Tower which according to my reservation confirmation go for $900+ per night. After a long day at the beach on day 2 we returned to the HGVC suite to find we had received no housekeeping. My husband contacted the front desk and was told that you have to stay a minimum of 7 nights in the HGVC in order to get housekeeping! WHAT!!!! So, each afternoon we had to stop at the front desk for towels and shampoo for the 4 of us (my husband, myself and our 2 teenagers). By the end of day 3 the garbage was stinking and overflowing and we had a pile of smelly wet towels the size of Diamond Head on the floor. We did meet up with housekeeping in the hallway every morning and they seemed very nice and very hardworking. The staff at HGVC made no effort to make us feel special. As a matter fact, I found them to be somewhat distant and aloof. Already we’re wondering if we made a mistake buying with Hilton. We plan on contacting the rep that sold us the week and ask why he didn’t tell us about the lack of service. We have been looking to buy a second timeshare but we’re sure not going to by more HGVC. We asked for a room on a high floor when we made our original reservation and on one other occasion and we got a room on the 6th floor – gee thanks! (IF ANYONEOUT THERE KNOWS THE TRICK TO GETTING A GREAT ROOM, PLEASE CONTACT ME!) The construction went on 7 am to 5 pm every day but Sunday. It didn't bother us too much because we didn't spend much time in the room. However, it was very loud so it made spending time on the lanai a bit unpleasant. We watched the fireworks on Friday night from our lanai which was nice but short (about 5 – 10 minutes).A couple other comments:-The Outrigger Catamaran was worth every penny. We showed up for the 3 pm trip and we had the whole boat to ourselves and the crew was wonderful. Played great tunes for us, drank champagne, sat on the net and got splashed and best of all we had several dolphins swimming and jumping right along side of us. WOW!! We couldn’t tip the captain and first mate enough . . . it was absolutely fantastic!!!-The Sunset Dinner Cruise was just average (food wasn’t that great).-Our two teenagers took surfing lessons with Pacific Soul and loved it. Had to pay $50 to get the pictures though (all of them on CD) but they were great pictures!- There is NO authentic luau on Oahu, sorry!- The book Oahu Revealed was “spot on” when they called the PCC “cheesy”. Way too much participation and we spent way too much time there. Ever heard of a Luau-cafeteria style? Not what I had envisioned at all. I recommend you do the self tour and see the “Horizons” show at night. The fire dancers made the show worthwhile. -Rent your snorkel gear and boogie boards from Snorkel Bob’s. We got it all for the whole week real cheap. Spent a lot of time at the HHV beach which was crowded but nice. We also hit the North Shore beaches which were unbelievable. Just kept the snorkel gear in the car and we were ready to go! In spite of the HGVC we did enjoy our vacation by just being together and having fun as a family.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We just returned, spent one week in Honolulu in the Lagoon Tower on the 23rd floor. The view from our balcony was just breathtaking, straight out looks to Diamond Head and side view is of the beach ... it was just amazing. I had my morning breakfast and coffee on the balcony every day! Yes, there's construction. The city is building a humongous pool, but it did not detract in any way our appreciation and pleasure of the property. It's so convenient. We actually watched the July 4th fireworks right on the beach front - it was amazing!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We just stayed 2 nites in a 1 bedroom unit at the Kalia Tower and 4 nites in a 2 bedroom at the Lagoon Tower. This was our 1st stay in the Kalia tower and 3rd time in the Lagoon tower. We were not disappointed. We heard no construction noise in the Kalia Tower and even though our room looking completely over the construction site (12th floor) in the Lagoon tower we were not inconvenienced in the slightest. One morning it was louder than normal but we were already awake and headed out the door when it started. The rooms were exceptional. Rooms were impeccable and I am extremely particular. The service could not have been better. I would highly recommend this location and our family will definitely stay here again.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: My family recently spent a week at the Lagoon Tower of the Hilton Hawaiian Village. Although we are owners at the Waikoloa Bay Club, bechose to spend some time on Oahu this trip. We were on the 11th floor and although our room overlooked the construction on the lagoon, our view was still magnificent. Our unit was spotless, and spacious. Both the dining area and front room had huge sliding glass doors with attached balconies. We had breakfast in the room daily, since we have food allergies, and breakfast out is always a problem. We made use of the free laundry facilities on our floor, with soap provided by Hilton. My daughter and her husband travelled with us and love to snorkle. They loved Hanauma Bay., which is about 30-45 min away from the hotel. They got there early, at the suggestion of the concierge, and had a great time. The hotel has manyrestaurants, but the area is loaded with lots of affordable (for Honolulu) restaurants. If you like gourmet food, Roy's newest Honolulu location is within walking distance. Good tourist sites in the neighborhood include the Army Museum at Ft. DeRussy. If you're military or retired military, the Hale Koa is right next door with a good PX, and nice luau. All in all it was a great place to stay. I strongly recommend it.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We are HGV owners and booked our stay in Honululu 18 months ago. We had stayed at the HGV property in Honululu before, and enjoyed it, but this time it was very disappointing. Our thirty minute flight from Kona to Honululu took 8 hrs due to a security breach, so we left the HGV in Kona at 10 AM and did not arrive at the HGV in Honululu until almost 7PM. We were exhausted when we checked in. The room was comfortable and the views from the room were stunning. -- we were ready to recover from the wasted vacation day between Kona and Honululu.  We headed to Foodland for groceries, and when we got back there was an event on the lawn in front of the hotel. The master of ceremonies was mic-ed so high that even with the balcony doors closed, the curtains drawn, and our own music playing we could still hear him. Calls to Conceige, front desk and guest services got the same: "we cannot do anything about it" The event on the lawn ended at 9 PM but the music at the Shell Bar behind the lawn at another Hilton tower played until midnight. Monday morning a 8AM construction work began. The lagoon and another tower are under construction -- it's a long term project that erases the sound of the wind and the waves completely. We talked with guest services about moving rooms. They were polite, offered to show us another room when it was cleaned at 4PM, took our cell phone number, but we never heard from them again. This was one of those work harder on vacation than you do for a living experiences!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: As a Hilton Hhonors and Hilton GVC member, I had high expectations from this holiday village resort when we spent 5nights at the Lagoon Tower. What a major dissappointment. When this was booked in Sept '06, we were not aware of how much the construction work would impact on our vacation. This included dust, the loss of a pool, no access to lagoon and continual traffic/construction noise throughout the day. If you are unlucky enough to get a room (we had a 2 bedroom on the 8th floor) that overlooks the contruction site, then do not expect to have a long sleep in the morning or a nap in the afternoon, this site will be a major construction site for some time to come.Negative - Added to this we felt the rooms required a refurbishment, with wallpaper peeling off the wall in the bathroom. The lifts were VERY slow, with 15min waits the norm. Resort has too many buildings, rooms and people, hence everyone is packed into a very small pool area, with access to beds limited. Everything on-site is expensive, including parking, food, drink and beach sunbeds.Positive - Right on a fantastic beach. ABC store on site. Easy walk to main shops (every designer brand available) and places to eat. Free internet access. Door men, bell hops, valet and maids were all excellent.General - Oahu is not what we expected from Hawaii. The high rise buildings and bumper to bumper traffic in and around Honolulu has totally ruined what we dreamed would be a paradise island. Thankfully we drove up the west coast and to the north shore, then visited the Big Island and got the feel for the aloha spirit.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: The HIlton Website is in error when it tells you there is minimal disruption from the construction noise at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. IT IS HORRIBLE!! We just spent a week in a Lagoon Tower unit that was so impacted by the construction noise in the Lagoon that we could not keep our balcony doors open during the day. Several days the construction started at 7:00 AM in the morning and continued until 6:30 PM at night. Complaints to the Hotel management were met with apologies -- but no one seemed to be in charge of the construction schedule. To add to this noise problem, the Hotel now rents out the "Lawn" area in front of the hotel. On the Friday of our visit we had the pleasure of listening to 1,000 vitamin salesmen discuss their sales success for three hours. This sound was amplified in both English and Spanish. What should have been a vacation in paradise turned out to be one continuous headache. Dennis and Pauline Bregante, Kentfield, CA

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Our family spend a week at this property from April 8 through April 14. We had an excellent time. The construction was on-going but very manageable. Our 7 year old was thrilled that he could watch the surfers and the construction trucks every morning as he ate his Coco Puffs on the balcony. The rooms were perfect and the staff was very accomodating. The bellman gave us terrific advice as to which resturants, shopping and sightseeing destinations. He he gave us directions to his personal favorite grocery store. This resort is beautiful and has everything you could wish for on site. There were things for the Grandparents, parents, teens and children. The fireworks show on Friday night was a big thrill. Another plus to this property is the "community" bus stop and trolly pick location on site. It was a wonderful vacation and we can't wait to book for next year.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: I went to the Hilton today to see the timeshare. The lobby smelled like a cesspool, and the place had dirty dishes about. The rooms are dated, and looked like something you would find in a one-star hotel. The toilet is right next to the bathtub. There is construction on-going, and guest are warned about the constant noise during daytime hours. I wouls suggest another property.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: You could have a very very disappointing stay construction BIG NOISE and DUST both to the front, and to the side. The big noise is from 7:00 am to 5:30 pm so prepared for a VERY NOISE disappointing stay.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Lagoon tower is in the middle of two construction zones. The Waikikian (a new high rise) on 1 side and the re-build of the lagoon on the other. The elevators were constantly slow, and one of the 3 was down for most of the week. We walked down and up the stairs a few times rather than wait more than 20 minutes! The village is great, but food is expensive. $16 for two coffees and 2 muffins at the Tapa Bar. Other towers would be a better choice until the construction is completed (2008).

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: This hotel was beautiful in it's day!!! THe Grand Vacations CLub is located in the back of the village, which is isolated from the rest of the village. If construction is your thing, this this is the place for you!!!!!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Just got back yesterday (12-8-2006) from a weeks stay. This was just a wonderful place to be. We were on the eighth floor of the Lagoon Tower. Yes, there was alot of construction going on, however we were gone during the day so I hardly noticed. The hotel, beach, and Island are so beautiful you will be out too. Some of the hotel restaurants are kind of expensive, but Red Lobster, Outback Steakhouse, Kobe Steakhouse, Benehanas, The Wakalai Coffee House, and Eggs'n'things are just some of places within a block or two. As far as beach goes this is the best on Wakaki. Hilton rakes it every morning so its nice and soft and there's plenty of beach right on the property. You won't have a problem finding a place to put an umbrella and chairs in the sand like we witnessed as you walk down the beach towards Diamond Head. For you that like to get up early to walk, jog, or meditate this is diffinetly the place. We were at the beach every morning by 5am and have never felt safer. There are plenty of hotel workers getting the place ready for the day and plenty of vacationers out there enjoying the beautiful mornings.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: I am a Hilton Grand Vacation timeshare owner. This was my first trip using my points which was very simple to book the stay. We stayed seven days at the Lagoon Tower. Employees were very nice and helpful at all times. They had a lot of activity and tour information available for the island of O'ahu at the concierge desk. They personally called the places and helped you schedule your tours. We did the O'ahu Nature tours. They have about 12 to choose from, but we choose to do only 3. They take you to the best places in O'ahu and give you a lot of information about the island. We visited the most beautiful beaches, waterfalls, gardens and views there is to see. Since we had an idea of what the island consisted of we used our free days to do our own sight seeing. we rented a car and revisited Lanikai Beach, the best beach in O'ahu. Very private and the sun rises in between two tiny islands. Upon our arrival we went straight to walmart and bought plenty of snacks, drinks, wine, beer, etc. Since the room had all the essentials needed to cook, we had dinner at our patio that overlooked the beach. We watched the sun set every night. There is a great place to have breakfast called Eggs and Things. It is about a block away from the Hilton and the portions are Large. Both times we went we shared our entree and had plenty of left overs. I am looking forward to future trips.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We were not disappointed about this place. Every one has different perspectives.Since we are Vacation club owners in Colorado, we opted to stay here for a week. This was one of the best places on Earth.The service was was perfect. the complex wonderful. The main pool can get crowded, i understand that outsiders stop by for the day to use it since there is no one checking to see i they are staying on the property.We stayed at the Kalia Tower and were not disappointed. The staff was very friendly and professional. We had a two bedroom apartment with a balcony. Kitchen was clean, bathrooms were clean, and we also had internet connection included. They even had a Cd with Hawaiian songs for us to listen to. Yes the lagoon pool is closed for a serious rebuild and yes they are doing construction in the area, however your have access to three other pools in the entire village.Overall, looking out of your windows and balony and seeing the sunset and ocean makes you forget the construction. It was kind of fun to look over your balcony and see some workers having a two hour breakfast.Being a HGVC owner has its advantages and this village is one of them. Seeing the ocean and the docks, the shops. Check out the TAPA Bar. This is part of the orignal hotel from back in the day. They even have a wall of photso and history about the place.We will make sure when we go back next year to stay in the same place again.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We are HGVC owners at this property and on previous visits have always enjoyed our stays. this year was the exception. The property is as always very comfortable and accommodating, but at present there is a great deal of building work going on both to the front, where they are building an underpass for delivery vehicles etc, to the side where they have closed Lagoon Tower swimming pool so as they can build a new super pool, and to the rear of the property the most noise, from 7:15 am to 5:15 pm were they are building the new tower due for completion in 2009.The noise levels whilst we were there in Sept 2006 was very disturbing and made sitting on the balcony uncomfortable to say the least, no conversation could be had. Add this to the building work going on were they are rejuvinating Lewers Street area and if you are a first time visitor, or are not prepared for this you could have a very disappointing stay.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Just returned from a 7 nights stay at the Lagoon Tower and the experience was horrible. Because they're building a new tower right next to the Lagoon Tower, all around the building have heavy constructions. They begin work at 7AM - 5PM and you can hear all the drilling and banging in your room. Extremely bothersome especially when you're on vacation and suppose to be free from all disturbances. You can't even enjoy the private pool next to the tower because of the noise. It's our first time at the Lagoon because we had purchased a timeshare promotion but because of that we were stuck in the building with no options to move into any towers! Big regrets for doing that! The overall Hilton Hawaiian Village is beautiful. When you book, make sure you go for the Ali'i Tower where we stayed last year. The amenities and services are so much better there. Also there're constructions by the Rainbow tower so beware when you book. Maker sure you ask for the side that's away from the constructions or high floors otherwise you'll be really diappointed.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We returned yesterday from our long anticipated trip to Hawaii . Now a little jet lagged and reflecting on our week there, I feel a little melancholly as I type this. I feel it necessary to let everyone know who may be going to the Lanai Tower at the Hilton Hawaiin Village, you need to be prepared to hike to the beach. Despite the information given to us as we booked our stay as "Beachfront" with an oceanview, we were given a room overlooking the parking deck on the backside of the complex. So instead of waking every morning to enjoy our coffee on the balcony overlooking the beach as we were told , we were less infatuated with the view of a busy city street cluttered with noisy traffic and a parking garage for a nearby hotel. And yes, we did try to change our room within minutes of seeing the accomodations only to be told there were no oceanviews available. If you are a family with small children, lugging sandtoys, boogie boards etc to the beach, be aware. By the time you finally make it to the sand, despite the fact you have wondered thru a host of upscale shopping and eating establishments, you pray no one has forgotten anything or your time in the sun will be diminished by at least another 20 minutes as you make the return trek back to the hotel. For me to say the complex was beautiful would be an understatement. Everything there was immaculate. Over the top one might say. The pool was tropical, with a Hawaiin presentation of some sort most every night, the beach was clean, and overall the room accomodations were wonderful. It is just extremely dissappointing to be told one thing and receive another. My best advice for anyone staying in the Lanai Tower is to get everything is writing, triple check accomodations before you leave if you want to be able to see the ocean and pack your hiking shoes. If you want to be close to the beach, ask for a different building.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Lagoon tower the best!! ocean view from lanai was beautiful spent many of the ten day trip starting out there. I was not a time share holder and was not bothered to be one which was great, the service was good. It helped so much having a washer and dryer.. compared to prices of hotels rooms having a suite with full kitchen was worth the money.defenitly high price on the grounds but you are in hawaii and on vacation and food was excellent especially the new york deli and rainbow lanai breakfast. Only needed car for few days everything else can be seen by foot ,bus, taxi or tour from hotel. Being from florida and living on the beach at first yes waikiki may not seem so grand to some in the other views but once you see the north shore or beaches by bellows airforce base which is open to public on weekends it truly reminds you of why you went there in the first place, even though I loved waikiki beach the sunset and night time life of the beach are the best. Also something not much responce on is the audobon gardens and waterfall worth the look. So as you can see no complaints from our group of four which are military and could haved stayed next door at the hale koa for a third of the price. would do it again and book lagoon tower because it truly was worth every cent..

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We have justed returned from our vacation in Hawaii and we really enjoyed our stay at the Hilton Grand Vacation Club. We booked a 1 bedroom condo through the hotel and it was perfect for the family, 2 young children (3 & 6) and 2 adults. The kids enjoyed sleeping on the sofa bed and we had a separate room with a King size bed. We were on the 5th floor facing the Lagoon and the view was amazing. We could even see the fireworks from our room on Friday night. We are not timeshare members so we received maid service daily as well as use of the free laundry facilities, including soap. The kitchen was well equipped with a kettle, toaster, rice cooker, pots, pans, microwave and all the dishes and cutlery you need. The only two negative things I can say is that sometimes the elevators did take a while to come, but you are on vacation so what's the rush. The other thing was that the maid forgot to clean our room once, but we contacted them and they came right away to clean.This is a wonderful place to take kids, they loved the pool which is fairly shallow deepest is about 4 1/2 feet. The beach area is great for them to play, large beach area and calm water. As for the restaurants they are very expensive, but if you purchase an Entertainment Book there are several coupons in it for the resort restaurants as well as other activities.We bought groceries and ate breakfast on our lani (patio) everyday and for lunch on several occasions we went next door to the military hotel, it was much cheaper and good food, except the fish burger! If you need to buy groceries go to Foodland in the Ala Moana Shopping Centre it is cheaper that some of the other stores. If you ask for a membership card it is even cheaper, anyone can get one.If you have small children and they are not great swimmers the Atlantis Submarine excursion is perfect for them, our youngest son is 3 and not comfortable in the water, so he was not able to snorkel. We took him on the submarine and he loved it, we saw tons of fish and well as green sea turtles. It is not cheap to go, but again if you have an Entertainment Book there is a coupon for it. Children must be 3 feet tall to go on.One of the most enjoyable nights we had was going to see the Magic of Polynesia with illusionist John Hirokawa. The kids thought it was amazing as did we. There is also a coupon for this in the book.This was one of the best vacations we have had with the kids and we would definitely stay there again.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We just returned from a 7 night stay in a 2 BR in the Lagoon. We are timeshare owners but still like to put in our two cents. The first four nights we stayed in a 2 BR corner unit facing the Rainbow tower. We were on the 6th floor and the lanai had wonderful palm trees that were at our level - very cool. Also because it was a corner unit, we had another lanai off the dining room. The unit was very spacious and living room quite a distance from the bedrooms. Nice kitchen area with pantry. Last three nights were supposedly upgraded but was far from it. Room needed some definite upgrading, faced the harbor but also seemed really too close the other hotel property next door. The living room was a lot smaller, dirty carpet, smaller bathroom and tattered furniture in master bedroom. We did get a couple great sunsets from our lanai but even the lanai was smaller -- what upgrade? But, all in all a lovely stay, nice to get away to the lagoon pool also ask about the hospitality room to shower before flying out (it's at the hotel)Also if more than 4 people, ask about the stretch limo to airport, in coupon book, for $29 pick you up right at Lagoon tower.(otherwise shuttle is $8 per person and you have to lug your suitcases around to Tapa tower.) Staff was wonderful, unbelieveable but they remember your name after and a couple of days and always have a hello and smile on their face.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: The Hilton is a collection of towering blocks around a tiny pool. At ground level there is a maze of shops selling designer goods. First impressions is like staying in Manhattan with a few more trees. This is the second impression as well. Expect a pitch to sell you a Hilton time-share at the welcome meeting. Everything in the Hilton can be found outside the Hilton at half the price but if you are the sort of person who want to stay in a complex for everything then I suppose you deserve to pay over the odds.  The beach is swept daily and the hotel is located right on the beach front, however it does matter which block you are in for views. The room we were in was large by European standards with two double beds and a small bar area. Filter coffee is provided, but you have to pay for the coffee. Internet is provided, but you have to pay for the internet. You can park overnight (for a fee). Get the idea? Everything is $5, hence the staff motto 'The only thing free is the Aloha and the morning newspaper'. There is a pretty sterile attempt to soften the concrete by importing in a (very) few penguins and flamingoes. It is well-situated for bus routes and all buses on O'ahu cost $2 and are air conditioned but are very infrequent (it is not unusual to have to wait more than 30 minutes for a bus even in rush hour). To get to the Arizona Memorial (Pearl Harbour) walk out of the hotel to the right and catch bus 20 or 42, this takes about an hour with frequent stops. Rather than book trips, I would advise you to rent a car on the Internet from Dollar and pick it up at Hale Koa Hotel (which is the next-door hotel to the right). This costs $60 a day instead of $60 per person per trip. The service at the Wailana Coffee House (out of the complex and turn left) is excellent and the prices are very reasonable and the food is always hot and filling but can be let down by the presentation. To summarise the Hilton is an overpriced concrete jungle. Other than laying in the sun, you will get most enjoyment from this hotel through your attempts to escape from it.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: Just back from an excellent total of 8 nights (in two seperate stays) in the Lagoon Tower. First three nights with my family of four in a One Bedroom Suite. Sofa Bed and Roll Away in living room still left lots of room to move around.Last five nights I was booked in a Studio, but was upgraded to a One Bedroom Suite at no additional cost.Both rooms were on 18th Floor, with excellent views towards ocean and downtown Honolulu. Room was very clean and well maintained.As a transient guest (not a timeshare owner) in the Lagoon Tower, we received daily maid service, in addition to free wireless internet service and as much coffee as we needed. Suite kitchen facilities were well equiped and the appliances looked brand new. Also, never had to wait for the free laundry machines located on the floor either. Service was absolutely wonderful in the Lagoon Tower. Staff was very friendly and there was NO timeshare sales pressure. It was far less hectic than in the main (regular) hotel towers. Lagoon Tower pool was also very nice and much less crowded than the main pool. Only downside is that there are only 3 guest elevators for this 23 story building and no staff service elevators, thus during peak use times, the waits can be quite long.Grounds of the whole Hilton are beatuiful. Restaurants and beach services are VERY expensive, but there are other nearby, off-property, affordable restaurants and beach rental services within a short walk.I highly recommend the Wailana Coffee House for breakfast. Fast and cheap, it's hard to beat their All You Can Eat Pancake Special for just $4.95!All in all, a wonderful stay. Will look forward to returning in the future!

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: 6 Night stay in a two bedroom. WHAT A WAY TO VACATION. The Master bedroom was extremely large, the second bedroom had two full beds. Seperate bathrooms and a sofa bed in the living room. Five stayed very comfortable... Entire family loved it.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: We just returned from a 6 night stay at the Lagoon Tower. We had a 1 bedroom suite that had all the dishes and pots and pans that you would need to feed a family of 4, including a crock pot, toaster, fullsize refrigerator and a stove with ovens. The coffee was free and there were small containers of soap, a laundry basket for the washer and dryer down the hall which was free, too, broom and dustpan, iron, and ironing board, and a dining and living room area. We had a room on the 11th floor with a balcony which had 4 chairs and a table. It overlooked the Rainbow Tower, but also had a beautiful ocean view. The king size bed was very comfortable. The maid only comes once during a 7 day stay, unless you pay extra, but they provided us with fresh towels when we asked. There is a small pool and a sauna tub just for the use of the Lagoon Tower people. The best pool is the Super Pool and of course there is the wonderful sandy ocean beach. Towels are provided for swimming in all areas. There are many shops on the property, the best priced one is the ABC store, which has just about anything you would need. There is a Coffee Shop across the street with reasonable prices and good food. The restaurants on the property are pricey, but two are recommended by most travel books. The military resort next door lets you use their snack bar to buy hamburgers, salads, ice cream, etc. which are very reasonably priced.The attractions desk in the lobby was very helpful and booked us a circle tour of the island with a stop at Pearl Harbor and lunch on the North Shore, which lasted about 9 hours. It was very good. They also booked a trip to the Polynesian Cultural Center, with a luau which lasted 11 hours. The luau food was just okay, but the 7 islands were both educational and fun to visit if you like learning about the culture of the people. There wasn't enough time to do all the areas as completely as I would have liked. We did not use a car at all as we spent time enjoying the water, and walking into the city, maybe a 10-15 minute walk. The only drawback to this resort is the long wait for the elevators on check out day, everything else was wonderful. I forgot to mention that there is an airport shuttle that will take you to the resort for $8 one way or $14 roundtrip, which you just walk to at the airport, or you can take a taxi.

hotel_name: Hilton Grand Vacations at Hilton Hawaiian Village
review_body: I was hesitant about the entire Hilton property after reading many reviews on this site. Let me just say that this is one of the best hotel properties I've been to in a long time. We stayed in the Lagoon Tower. We had a 1 bedroom suite and an adjoining studio room for 4 adults. The bedrooms, main room, bathrooms, furnishings, kitchen were wonderful. Maid service doesn't come each day, but whenever we needed towels or more coffee they brought it up immediately. Our room faced the Rainbow Tower and the view was fabulous, and each room has a lanai which we spent the majority of time when in the room hanging out on. One complaint we had was the noise of taxis & garbage trucks around 7am. One thing they did not do a good job of planning the resort to have these service vehicles away from guests. However, it did not detract from our stay in any significant way. Another downfall on the Lagoon Tower is the elevators which you will end up waiting for during peak times. The super pool was great. Chairs were hard to come by if you got there between 11am - 2pm, but we always ended up finding room to sit as a group. We did not bother using any of the other pools, as this one had a much better atmosphere. The beach is amazing, and I highly recommend getting up (when you hear the noise at 7am) and going for a walk on the beach at sunrise. The restaurants and bars are overpriced as any hotel will be. For lunch, consider walking next door to the Koa Hauna hotel pool. They have great prices on burgers and you can bring them back to the Hilton pool! For dinner, we always went elsewhere in Waikiki or into Honolulu by taxi.The hotel has a Hertz office on site, which we used for renting a car to go to the North Shore for the day.
